If you like RPGs at all I think you owe it to yourself to play this game. The world is filled with story and lore, lots of hidden things to keep you entertained. Plenty of fun and unique dialog that you'll find yourself wanting to experience and not just skip. In some ways the open ended nature of the game and the fact that it's totally willing to let you kill yourself as many times as it takes to teach you something reminds me of D&D. You're given tools and problems and set free to solve them and move through the story organically. The combat is turn based, deep and tactical.    You'll find yourself creating strategic synergies with your team and relish the creative ways you can defeat your enemies (funny deaths with teleport alone could keep me occupied for hours).  That said the game will punish you if you rush in with reckless abandon rather than carefull engaging. I recommend saving often :)  The game is a blast co-op if you don't mind waiting for your friends to take their turns, controller support is top notch, the  graphics are beautiful but not at all taxing for mid grade machines. This is a game crafted with a lot of care and polish and it deserves your time.

A true piece of art, the best RPG I've played since Dragon Age: Origins.  I didn't play this game much yet, but I've been following its development, as I did for D:OS1. You've got everything you'd want from an RPG: good story, interesting universe and characters, tactical (and even one of the best I've seen!) combat system - varied skills to use and a lot of combos between different characters - true replayability. And fun multiplayer (even if I'd advise to play only with friends you can trust).  So I'm only going to focus on what you may actually not like much:  Set up. There's a lot of dialogues - they are rather good, and they are voiced. But there are many of them: if you're not too much into that, you'll miss a quarter of what the game has to offer, at least.     The game has a thing for silly stuff. Like in the previous opus, dialogues are very "facetious". It's a mix of jokes and serious stuff, you have to be prepared for absurd deaths and brutals happenings, but if you can't handle anything else than fashionable so-called "dark fantasy" you'll be disappointed. D:OS2 is colourful, baroque and lively, and also features cannibals and living deads, even if you can create ugly meat ball that explode on your enemies (and friends alike, thanks to friendly fire).     Character building. In DOS2, it's not a straightforward process. Sure, you can pick all deafult options and you shouldn't have too many problems - but if you don't enjoy doing things like selecting skills that go well together and/orcrafting, you'll also miss a good part of the game. It's not just about choice between different "specialities", it's really about elaborating strategies and enjoying battle plans. If you're ok with all this, you're likely to enjoy this game. You'll also need a lot of time, obviously, but the "quest log" is sufficiently well done to not lose you if you can't play a lot, and you don't need a lot of time to learn the game (everything is pretty intuitive, you don't need to spend hours on a wiki to know what does what or why you can't do X). TLDR:  Put 100 hours into one playthrough.  A phenomenal RPG experience that is a breath of fresh air.  Even at full price this game is well worth it.  Some pros, neutrals and cons for some quick pointers.  My views and such will be included after but can be ignored if wished.   Pros: Only $45 which is a steal for the amount of content you get. Very lengthy game, 4 world areas with multiple quests in each of them. Servicable story, interesting but nothing mind blowing, same goes for the lore. Lots of side quests to do which can put you in some interesting situations. Very well written characters, this goes for followers and NPCs. Lots of dialogue and options for you to navigate conversations, and every line is voiced too! Very good, tactical, challenging combat.  Lots of ways to approach each encounter. Diversity in how to play characters.  No defined "roles" and its easy to completely change a character at any point after the first main area. The entire game is playable in co-op which can be drop in drop out.  Works with up to 4 players.  It even has split screen! Also comes with an Arena multiplayer mode for PvP and a Game Master mode to play D&D with friends.  Basically infinte replayability. Along with that as a bonus they included the Engine for Divinity as a free download.  You can make your own mods, maps, scripted dialogue, etc.  It even has native workshop support to easily upload to. Steam workshop support for easy access to mods.  Neutral: These neutral comments are going to be mostly preferencial for people.  Not a problem for me but I can see how it can be a problem for others. No handholding whatsoever.  Not really an issue for me and some may wonder why this here.  For some I can see an issue with some quests.  There were a few times where I wondered how the game thought I would have been able to figure out certain things.  If you get stuck just have the wiki open, I certainly used it a few times and it was very helpful. No handholding also extends to combat.  Combat can be really challenging at times, almost borderline unfair.  However once you learn all the mechanics of the game and learn how to be scummy it is really satisfying to beat a challenging fight. In my opinion there were a few quests that were poorly designed.  Kinda goes with the point of no handholding, a few of the ways to complete some quests were really convoluted.  Not that many of them which is why it's neutral and not a con.  Cons: Bugs, lots of them.  There are many quest bugs in this game which cause quests not to close out properly.  In my experience I would say there were around maybe 15 or so in total.  Kind of annoying when you fail a quest just because it gets bugged out.  Also the recorded dialogue cuts out randomly some times.  However Larian have been releasing patches so hopefully most of the bugs will all be ironed out eventually. Overall this game was phenomenal, loved almost all of my time with it.  At $45 which gave me about 100 hours on a single playthrough it was absolutely worth the money.  I was surprised I enjoyed it as much as I did since I don't really enjoy isometric RPGs with this kind of combat.  I tried Pillar's of Eternity and could never finish it.  Really it's the combat that prevents me from playing games like this.  However Divinity's combat is extremely well done and I enjoyed it when I learned the in's and out's.  This game is certainly not for everyone, for those that don't like challenging, slow, turn based combat this isn't for you.  If you don't like long winded, role-play driven, lore heavy dialogue and questing this game isn't for you.  If you don't like a lack of handholding in your quests this game isn't for you.  If you like all of the above or are looking for an amazing RPG that says ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• all to modern tropes then I can say with certainty you'll enjoy Divinity: Original Sin 2.  Honestly at full price this game is worth it, on sale it's a must buy.  Hopefully more people will continue to buy this game and support Larian, they fully deserve it and I can't wait to see what they'll do next.

Disclaimer: the following text is totally unbiased and non sarcastic!  I have some gripes with the monetization of this game. It's clear that Larian hasn't enterend the realm of 2017 yet and DOS2 is really not up to par with todays standards: 1. DOS2 retails for 44.99US$ or your regional equivalent. A modern game with high production values, which DOS2 clearly has with its beautiful atmospheric graphics, its incredible well written story, an amazing voice acting performance, a grandiose orchestral soundtrack, dozens hours of content and deep tactical gameplay should retail for 59.99US$. 2. No pre order bonus. In the beginning of the game you meet a black cat with its own small storyline, but totally not essential to the grand story overall. DOS2 has tons of sidequests with their own story and those go further than the bland "go fetch me 10 wolf pelts" sidequests. Those sidequests make the game so much more engaging and rewarding to play. That black cat could be easily cut from the game and offered as a pre order bonus, which would be a good incentive for people to buy the game upfront without knowing if the game is any good. After launch you offer the black cat as a 9.99US$ DLC and make some more money out of it. 3. DOS2 comes with 6 origin stories, 6 unique characters, which greatly changes how you will experience your travels and adventures throughout Rivellon. This enhances the replayability of DOS2, but knowing this game is in one playthrough already al least 70 hours long this is perhaps a bit much to offer at a base price of 44.99US$, which really should be 59.99US$ (see point 1.). As you can take only 4 characters in your party, offering 4 origin stories in the base game is more than enough. You can easily cut two, say Beast (a Dwarven Pirate) and Fane (an Undead), and offer them in a Digital Deluxe Special Edition for an extra 20$: - Divinity Original Sin 2: Pirate Edition for 79.99US$ with Beast origin story - Divinity Original Sin 2: Undead Edition for 79.99US$ with Fane origin story And of course you bundle this all together in: - Divinity Original Sin 2: Gold Edition for 99.99US$ with all 6 origin stories 4. DOS2 doesn't have a season pass. Will Larian just patch and add extra content for free? 5. DOS2 makes you play and enjoy the game without cutting corners through microtransactions. If a character in your party dies, you must make sure you have a resurrection scroll to revive him/her or have enough gold to buy one from the NPC's in the game. There is no ingame store that let you buy ingame items or ingame gold for real money.  Despite these 5 points of criticism DOS2 is a fantastic game. It's one of the best cRPG's ever made and playing this game you feel you're playing something special. This truly is a classic: 10/10!

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a phenomenal experience anyone who is a classic RPG fan will love.   The overall appeal of Larian studios masterpiece is in its complex RPG systems, dynamic combat and world-changing character choices that synergize together to create an unforgettable experience. There is a ton of replayability because the world dynamically adapts to the choices you make. From the missions you decide to do or not, to the fights you start for no reason, this game really is yours to play however you would like.  They also have great controller support, a fantastic crafting system, a truely unique multiplayer experiance, complex weapon and armor mechanics and a wide range of skills and abilities to choose from. Not to mention the increasing number of mods already available from the community.  There are some downsides, like the inability to re-specialize early on (already fixed by mods) and the overall difficulty seems to be a little unbalanced. Every fight is difficult, requiring you to really think before you act.  Overall I would give Divinity: Original Sin 2 an 8.5 out of 10.  If you want a more in-depth look at the gameplay and other features of Divinity: Original Sin 2 Check out my new youtube channels review here: https://youtu.be/ARmHfLZFqvY

Gamer's game Most games these days are over after playing it ~30 hours, I was positively suprised that it was only the end of 1st act in the game and 2nd act seems to unfold even more content to explore and to beat.   The game has this bit of a typical rough beginning, where you are a prisoner and have to start working your way into freedom. I'm not sure does it help to introduce the gaming mechanics that well, since some of the first obstacles in the game require already hard exploration or knowledge of your surroundings. But I won't go too much into the game's internal story settings and themes on this one. Instead I'll just give quick look for those who are interested in the game, but find it hard to get started.  If you are a casual rpg player, this game is best to start in co-op with your friend on medium difficulty. The game is playable/enjoyable initially in single player as well, but you'll have to get used to manage alot with the inventory, skills and spells early on. One of the aspects that makes many lose the interest to these kinda games when playing alone. But those few well written NPC friends makes sure you'll get a feeling of unity and comradeship while you progress in the story. The game has also this welcoming feeling to those who haven't played the first game, without referencing it too much.  Combat is turn-based and it isn't around every corner, but when you find it though, it usually lasts slightly longer than in many other games. I remember one ambush encounter in a forest section took like 15 minutes active fighting, and that was after we came back to it with better equiptment. Dialogues and random banters are high also in this game, which all seems to be voice acted from the "AI's" side to give more lively touch to it. And you can example easily play 2 hours and all you did was few conversations.  The game also offers eventually challenge for more hardcore players, who would get bored if the game would be too easy. Hardest difficulty (Tactician) requires quite alot backtracking and unconventional tactics sometimes to overcome encounters with the builds you might have at disposal. And eventually if you're feeling confident enough you can try the real hardcore mode (Honour) where losing all your characters ends the game and removes your single save file.  I'll try to overlook some of the negative sides in overall since some can be patched later and some are build so deep in the game mechanics it is more of a "depatable" thing. Like personally I would like magic to be more meaningful and more costly to the caster, so it doesn't become a norm in the world for elements to go chaotic in every fight. But I guess it's something you can expect in a Divinity's world.  Nontheless this game is true to the older adventure/fantasy/rpg games, where you'll get minimal hand helding and have to figure things out by yourself. No-one is master in the beginning, but everyone can learn to fare better. Some events can be solved with pure violence or with smooth talking, the choice is often yours.  -Even if you'll never finish this game, it is worth a try.   9/10

This game is the ultimate cRPG. You can just feel the passion and dedication that has been put into this game. It‚Äôs the only one that actually innovates the genre while others are still stuck redoing the 90s. Don‚Äôt get me wrong - I used to love these games back in the day but 2D worlds and antiquated combat systems of infinity style games just feel dated by now and D:OS 2 really improves upon these main shortcoming of the genre.  The main strength of the game lies within its fantastic combat system. Turn-based is the absolute best fit for party based combat that allows for incredible depth. For every encounter there are multiple approaches to consider and the way abilities interact between each other and the environment is just awesome.  Another great thing about the game is how much player freedom it allows. A lot of quests have many different ways to solve them with various outcomes. Not reaching an ideal outcome in a quest will not hinder your progress but the story will just play out differently.   The visual and sound design is truly top notch and does a great job of getting you immersed in the game world. The fully 3D world with rotatable camera is a treat to explore.  It is designed with gameplay first approach and I absolutely love it but that said the story and characters are still fairly interesting and open up a plethora of moral questions that do not always have a clear cut right or wrong answer.   The game‚Äôs lack of hand-holding and signposting mostly feels like a breath of fresh air but can get a bit frustrating at times. Of course that‚Äôs only because the tendency in recent games to overdo it has conditioned us to think less for ourselves so overall I find the direction here to be positive.  The amount of content this game offers is certainly impressive and well worth the cost.  Overall I‚Äôd say that while there certainly is room for improvements Larian has done a good job making this masterpiece that has found a place among my most beloved games of all time. Therefore I would rate this game with a nearly perfect score of 9.5/10.

Game that tops the oh so beloved by world Witcher 3, hands down. I've been planing on postponing writing this review to the moment when I complete the game whole, but after realizing I got a pretty strong grasp on it, I figured there's no point in waiting and the time has come to add my own brick to the game pras wall.  If you feel disappointed by RPG games praised by the reviewers and gaming community lately (namely The Witcher 3 or latest Fallout installment) you should give this game a go - with captivating story, interesting characters, dynamic and tactical combat, and character development that actually feels rewarding and meaningful it reaches out for the title of turn-based RPG game of the dacade.  I've bought the game on official release, not having played the early access before, only the predecessor. And I got immediately sank in the world of Rivellon - realizing that I pumped as much as 40 hours in marely 10 days.  Thanks to the compelling gameplay, you get sticked to the screen, not wanting to leave - promising yourself every half an hour, that you only gonna get that last quest completed, that last cave explored, that last bad guy butchered. There aren't any meaningless quotation marks on your maps, which give you mundane quests of the "here's the key, use it to open that chest 10 meters from you, to get your dull loot" likes (*cough* I'm lookin at you, witcher*cough*), every character feels purposeful or interesting at least, with witty, funny and FULLY VOICED dialogues of highest quality, every location hides its secrets, leading you towards surprising outcomes, interconnected areas and such - simply exploring the world with no handholding and silly marks never felt so rewarding and enjoyable, holy heck.  Combat system really adds to it, with its fresh approach to the encounters - not only will you need to pay attention to the health bars, but also to the environment, as most spells will interact not only with another spells, but also with the puddles on the ground, the mist in the air, the fire eating your enemies' bodies. The fights are so satisfactional! If you are seasoned player, or turn-based RPGs veteran I definitely suggest you start your first blind new game on tactical difficulty - it's actually dificult, but also greatly amusing.  The story and quests are really good, a noticable jump forward since the first game. Not only NPCs you meet on your road, but also so-called "origins" characters are interesting. Each with his own story and mission to fulfill in the world of Rivellon - you really start to like your companions and grow bonds with them.   But not only your mates are accompanying you - there's a great soundtrack in this game, which breaths a captial "A" into your Adventures. New composer did an excellent job with creating the OST. He didn't fill the boots after Kirill Pokrovsky - and oh, we should not want him to! - he made something with his own vision, and may he be praised for this, as he did an amazing job on it.  Last, but not least - the game offers you a multiplayer experience with up to 4 players - while not necessary to experience the storry whole, it really adds a pinch of spice to the game. With its diverse combat you will definitely have a great deal of fun with your friends - so if there's an option, I highly recommend going for it.  For a word of closing this review - big shoutout to Larian, for delivering one of a kind game, and satisfying not only kickstarter backers needs, but also these of people who didn't track the game development process at all - and concurrent players counter is a prime example of that. Kudos!

TLDR:  Put 100 hours into one playthrough.  A phenomenal RPG experience that is a breath of fresh air.  Even at full price this game is well worth it. This game is the ultimate cRPG. You can just feel the passion and dedication that has been put into this game. It‚Äôs the only one that actually innovates the genre while others are still stuck redoing the 90s. Don‚Äôt get me wrong - I used to love these games back in the day but 2D worlds and antiquated combat systems of infinity style games just feel dated by now and D:OS 2 really improves upon these main shortcoming of the genre.  The main strength of the game lies within its fantastic combat system. Turn-based is the absolute best fit for party based combat that allows for incredible depth. For every encounter there are multiple approaches to consider and the way abilities interact between each other and the environment is just awesome.  Another great thing about the game is how much player freedom it allows. A lot of quests have many different ways to solve them with various outcomes. Not reaching an ideal outcome in a quest will not hinder your progress but the story will just play out differently.   The visual and sound design is truly top notch and does a great job of getting you immersed in the game world. The fully 3D world with rotatable camera is a treat to explore.  It is designed with gameplay first approach and I absolutely love it but that said the story and characters are still fairly interesting and open up a plethora of moral questions that do not always have a clear cut right or wrong answer.   The game‚Äôs lack of hand-holding and signposting mostly feels like a breath of fresh air but can get a bit frustrating at times. Of course that‚Äôs only because the tendency in recent games to overdo it has conditioned us to think less for ourselves so overall I find the direction here to be positive.  The amount of content this game offers is certainly impressive and well worth the cost.  Overall I‚Äôd say that while there certainly is room for improvements Larian has done a good job making this masterpiece that has found a place among my most beloved games of all time. Therefore I would rate this game with a nearly perfect score of 9.5/10.

If you played and enjoyed Divinity Original Sin, then you will really enjoy DoS2. It's got all of what made the first game great but has improved on almost every part of that, though I must say my intial save didn't start off that great, my main character I manage to whack myself with my staff in combat hurting myself more then the enemies did, I then get a Lizardman and immediatly light a "black cat" that is following me around on fire and then my lizardman on fire, and then I forget how the trading system works and sell all my items to a vendor for nothing in return forgetting to drag the money into the trade window. Definitly a lot more enviornmental combos a lot earlier, like very first fight Rain of blood to spread blood around and cause the enemies to bleed, then corruptionto turn the blood into a poison cloud and poison the enemy, so right off the bat they are bleeding and poisoned and wet before they even get a chance to attack and then when you have lizard man you can then light that poison cloud on fire to cause it to explode to do more damage create smoke and break line of sight. Not a bad little combo for right off the bat.  Conversations have a lot more options with race and origin story adding in more dialog options. A tension meter for when there have been a lot of crimes like theift and murders in an area which effects NPC behaviour, so even if you don't get caught in the act of stealing it could make it harder in the future.  All in all it feels like a much better game (hard to say when the first game was already great) but definitly one where if you liked the first you will love the second, if you didn't like the first odds are there is nothing here that is going to magicly make you like the second unless it was a minor thing that you didn't like that caused you to not like the game (like say not enough dialog options for different characters).  Not much else to say other then the EA is like the first DOS EA, only play it if you don't mind only having access to act 1, if you want to enjoy the entire story all at once for the first time then hold off till the game is actually released.

Boys, girls. My time on this game was largely spent offline due to deployment which I was fortunate enough to be able to download this immaculate game on  release. A buddy and I grabbed two Xbox controllers and leaned in close to my 15in laptop display and got swallowed into the incredibly fleshed out world fast. I had anticipated this game ever sense its announcement and avoided the early access so that I could indulge in the full experience once it was finished. It was completely worth the wait. I thought that the first Original Sin was amazing, and found mass improvements that I didn't even know I wanted in this new iteration. Everything about this RPG is done so right that so many other games fail to do. If you love Pathfinder, or DnD you'll be right at home with this game. You're steadily guided along a linear world with open exploration aspects that is just enough to satisfy. A lot of RPGs as of late choose to opt for big massive open worlds with maps littered with locations and pointless side quests that are meant to make you feel like you're in control and fail. This is what Original Sin 2 does right. I say the game is linear because it is, but in a very healthy way for an RPG. You're taken to new areas with each progressive plot line quest you complete with the right amount of extra stuff on the side that ties into the main plot either immediately or eventually. Which I love. There were plenty of times where my buddy and I looked at each other and were amazed at either what we were doing, or what the story had come to so far. Fights were grueling and some were drawn out. But with each difficult encounter, a sense of accomplishment rushed over us. A lot of fights are more like puzzles more focused on how you approach the problem at hand rather than just smashing your way through though that's also a valid option. Strategy is key here, and presetting your characters can be the difference between success and death. Something I absolutely loved was the ability to experiment and restat my characters early on in the game and have the ability to do this as I please throughout. Allowing me to mix up my strategies for each new area and enemy I came across if I wanted to. A lot of the stats you improve and traits you take are clear and meaningful. Each class has an applicable role in everything you do inside and out of combat. Skill checks are made pretty frequently and arent the end all be all if you fail one. There are several ways you can approach impasses along your journey and often times are made pretty clear. Nothing was funnier to me than when I got my hands on the teleportation pyramids and could cheese my way through certain places to progress. Sometimes the game even rewards you for trying creative approaches. The visuals here are lush and gorgeous. Environments seamlessly blend together, although on the world map it may not look like it does. You'll go from smashing voidlings to being pummeled by dragons and everything in between. When I started reading reviews calling this "the greatest RPG ever made," and even "the greatest GAME ever made," I had to  try it. The reviews reminded me a lot of The Witcher 3 and it was for the same reason that I bought and played that game way back when and it's now considered my favorite game of all time. So yeah, I got a little excited.  Then I played the game and I felt kind of disappointed. It seemed extremely difficult and I wasn't used to getting the cold shoulder from a game. By that I mean compared to most games this one does not hold your hand, you won't get arrows pointing you in the direction you need to go, everything you need to know is actually in the dialogue and/or read in notes and books (and sometimes a rare hint from the narrator). I kept feeling confused on where to go and who to talk to and the quest system seemed kind of clunky and hard to understand at first.  I'm ashamed to admit, I asked for a refund at about the hour and a half mark. Then I went a couple days thinking about the game and that I couldn't believe I couldn't get into it. And then I thought about it again and again and realized that something was nagging at me and I couldn't stop thinking about it.  So yeah... I bought the game again. I looked up tips this time around on which characters people like in their party and which skills really help early game (Lone Wolf changed everything for me). And most of all I had to learn to slow down, stop running through rooms like nothing matters. This game made me change the way I approach video games. I started to appreciate the detail and get into the story, and I have to say, the story is absolutely amazing. The characters are all interesting and the situations I found myself in during certain points in dialogue had me on the edge of my seat.  Now I'm 40 hours in and I can confirm, absolutely one of the greatest RPGs ever. And I haven't even had the pleasure to experience co-op with a friend. 10/10

Pretty good RPG with a classic feeling to it. A lot of content and a lot of replayability. The fact that you can play it with a friend and give him control over characters (4 party members, so we played 2:2) is just awesome and led to many laughs. I would recommend it and I'll just highlight 3 aspects of the game that were memorable about it in the good, the bad and the ugly (okay, the neutral).   The good: I hate any tactician turn-based game. Often they're overcomplicated. But this one? This one was ... definitely complex but somehow I came around to like it. Everything made sense and learning how things works by setting EVERYTHING ON FIRE was a fun experience. Gameplay is just fun, making a builds and testing them out was great, there's a lot of possibilities to go around. Lots of things to find, lots of ways to resolve an issue, lots of surprises. If gameplay is what you're after then you won't be disappointed.  The bad: BUGS. Oh my god the bugs. Not many - true, but one extended turns in a certain boss fight to make it last forever for enemy to finish his turn. Another one made me lose about 15 hours of progress, because I couldn't access "home-base" waypoint and had to load older save. And yet another - by a chance we found out a bug that can make you immortal duplicating an Idol that ressurects you for no cost at all so you could gear up your whole team with immortality idols and pass the game in easy mode. What the hell. Larian fix your game, bugs in key moments are not acceptable, especially after the game came out of early access.  The neutral: Story and lore. Honestly only story for your companions was any good and made you care. Overall the game is about ego trip to become divine and often we were in a pretty good spot to not care about anyone else than our own quest to power. Factions and key characters even when they started as good, sooner or later they ended up not so rightous to a point I didn't mind killing most of them. Never felt there was any greater incentive to be "the good guy" or choosing "the lesser evil" in this game. The whole world felt not worth fighting for. Maybe that is the point? It's not bad, it definitely had some depth to it, but still felt "meh".

7.5/10  I played Divinity: Original Sin 2 with a group of friends as a Persuasive Lizard, focusing on Summoning and Geomancy. Though the boulders and oil that can be thrown with Geomancy are effective, I initially focused on it to serve as a healer for our Undead tank. Undead are healed by poison, so your party's usual healer can't help them out. However, Geomancy also gave me access to Fortify which I could use to restore physical armor, and Artillery Plant, which was my favorite thing in the game. Artillery plant is a summon that exists in the Geomancy tree, whose level is determined by your Summoning skill. In the game, your most powerful skills cost "source" to cast (sort of a special type of mana). By the end of the game, you will be able to possess three source points at a given time. Source is rare to come by during most of the game, and even towards the end it's not necessarily unlimited. Artillery plant costs a single source point to cast, but then it can cast an extremely powerful spell called "Acid Spores" every two turns, among other strong abilities. If your character were to cast "Acid Spores," instead of the summon, it would cost you two source points every time!  The type of discussion you see above is what makes Divinity: Original Sin 2 so exciting. How can you support the other characters in your party in combat, and what is the optimal way to use your source or action points? If a member of your party has the "Loremaster" ability, you can examine enemies to learn their abilities, talents, and resistances. If an enemy reduces and redirects damage dealt, you may want to attack his friends first. If he has the opportunist talent, you do not want to walk away from melee range as it grants him an attack. If he has a fire resistance of 150%, fire will heal him. You want to constantly take stock of enemy composition and the skills of your party.  If Divinity: Original Sin consisted of a more linear story with more combat encounters, and lasted about 2/3 of its current length, it would be a 10/10 game for me. However, as it stands, I have a few gripes.   Although I'm sure that many players appreciate the ability to complete quests in multiple ways, I just found it frustrating. Some of the solutions are obtuse, and require a lot of poring through documents. Some of the late game puzzles, like pulling levers in a certain order or playing the enormous "pipe dream" game, were just tedious. There are many many quests, and in a multiplayer party it just felt like I was always receiving experience from somewhere because someone in my party was progressing on one of the many many quests in my quest log. While I'm sure some might say that I should've played with a different group of people, there are so many quests with so many solutions that often we made quest progress by aimlessly walking around.   Another issue I had with the title is just how quickly my character advanced. Each character has a maximum of 40 in an attribute, a maximum of 10 in each skill or combat ability, and a maximum of 5 in each civil ability. Each character in our party maxed out at least one of these categories well before the end of the game. In addition, the highest tier of skills in the game become available at level 16, also well before the endgame. Though perhaps others are drawn primarily for the story, this severely hampered my enjoyment of the game. After learning all skills I was interested in, maxing my summoning and my persuasion, I just didn't have as much to look forward to.  I enjoyed most of my time with Divinity: Original Sin 2. The argument could be made that this type of game just isn't for me, but I enjoyed the combat so much that is was worth some of the other irritations.

I just finished my first playthrough last night. Let's get this out of the way: this game is something special. It improves on almost every gripe I had with the original (mainly just story and pacing) and just knocks it out of the park. This is a new gold standard for what a modern RPG should be.    What's Good The companions are memorable, well-written, and have realistic motivations that make negotiating their place in your party really engaging as you strive for the end-goal of the game. (I mean, it makes sense, you can play them as the main character if you wish!)  Combat rewards creativity, exploration, and experimentation without ever feeling like it's unfair towards the player--some fights are tough as nails, but they're just puzzles that you've been given an entire toolbox to solve. It's incredible just how many viable strategies you can employ to build a party and the myriad tactical decisions you can make in combat with those interactions.  Some of the quests and puzzles are pretty inspired--I'm a DM for tabletop group and I can appreciate how hard it is to make a puzzle that's challenging and feels organic to its context while delivering on fun. So hard to do, and 90% of the quests and puzzles in D:OS2 deliver. The quests often have multiple paths to resolution, which can be incredibly satisfying.    (Minor) Gripes I only encountered a few bugs over the course of my game and none of them were show-stopping. (A few dialogue options that didn't make sense because of my choices; quicksave reload breaking a script in combat and requiring rollback; a few quests not updating / reflecting change after I made major progress in them.) The lion's share of these happened in the last two major areas of the game--which I totally understand given the sheer scope of the game.   Long story short: there hasn't been an RPG this rich in a long time. It's worth every penny of the price tag.

Larian turned gold to lead, but this game is probably worth it, provided that you know what you do.  First off, choose wisely your play level. I chose tactician as a veteran of RPG. I was well served. Indeed, tactician it is! But it doesn't say that you should also scratch every single little advantage that you can (steal as much as possible, stack on potions etc.) in order to be well prepared for the last fight. It also doesn't say that you shouldn't expect your characters to be heroic! Indeed, in many situations at that level you will have to resort to cheesy tactics such as some characters fleeing the combat to recover skill timers, heal, then come back while the combat has been frozen because you left one character or invocation hold it... Or by reloading consistently because you were not prepared for a nasty surprise in a combat and had nothing left to deal with it; so you reload, come back with smart prepositionning and the combat will go smoothly. I remember a fight against some outrageous horror -helped by numerous cronies, all of them more powerful than my characters despite being one level above-, which I easily lost head to head, then won after reloading, placing my characters far enough, engaging with invocations and keeping my characters far enough -actually out of combat- that I could always cast a new invocation when one died. I finally won that fight without a scratch. Smart ? sure. Pleasurable ? Hardly.  So unless you like going very slowly, always moving like there is a fight at the next step (or reloading often), managing inventories to be sure each character has the absolute best equipment, has the necessary consumables,  and so on (i.e. total micromanagement), skip the tactician level. At normal level, the game is going to be challenging enough for most players. Especially the last combat, which I never finished -I have done quite well in the first part, but am hopelessly outnumbered in the second part. I probably know what is wrong, but I won't be going back batching the potions that I am missing, respecing my characters to more useful stats, traits and spells, changing runes for more useful ones etc. you get the picture for tactician level.- So, I won't know the end of the story line I chose, and I won't change my storyline just so the last combat is easier. That's a bit sad.  And NO: YOU CANNO'T CHANGE THE DIFFICULTY LEVEL DOWN! That's a real shame!  Also, there is no excuse for larian in turning an excellent character development/combat system into the mediocre thing that it has become. In that respect, Original Sin 1 was way better. The current system has clearly been designed in order to foil the player and outrageously favor the opponents. You cannot inflict secondary effects (blinding, stunned etc.) as long as the target has magical or physical armor (a new protection that comes above your hit points.) This means that the first rounds of combat are always going to be damage dealing: you won't have any crowd control coming until you've done some attrition first. Worse: the system favors teams which choose a damage type and stick to it. I made the mistake of wanting a balanced party: the result is that I am too weak for the last fight. Actually in some fights, I had characters standing aside, watching the combat go because they did not deal the right kind of damage...  After all this has been said, I still recommend this game because the story looks good, the world is well developped and generally speakig as RPG go, it stands on the top if you don't fall into the trap where I fell.  EDIT: I finally found the courage to do what I said I wouldn't do, and of course finish the game. As expected, I had to respec my characters, and decided to go for lone wolf. The advantage in lone wolf lies not in the power of the characters (they indeed are stronger, but you have overall less firepower), but in the fact that you don't have to bother about the survival or such and such character, as well as reducing the drain on your consumables (you use two instead of four for a similar effect.) The fight was easy [SPOILERS (light) AHEAD] mostly for use of the special tea sold by Mrs Kremm, combined with at least +50% full elemental protection potions and five star dinner -i.e. all elemental damage did heal me, which both let me remove most healing spells as well as use my own offensive spells for healing-, the pawn and duck duck goose (for good movement, not mentioning spells.) Other talents which I thought would help did not (guerilla) [END SPOILERS] ; I changed my main character from pure mage to hybrid melee (fighter) / mage, helped by an archer/assassin ; as explained above, this was a choice to favor physical damage over magical damage, choice made necessary by the difficulty of that fight. I of course had to spend considerable time to prepare the characters and the consumables, buy or craft the required potions and books as well as redistribute equipment. The trouble is that in that fight I did not recognize the character(s) I played consistently from the beginning (no respec before the end), which is annying (to say the least) for a RPG! The other trouble is of course that I could not have to feeling that the hero was well above the other contenders to deserve my victory. Indeed, the stats of all other human opponents were consistently above those of the hero. Understand who can!

I don't usually play Turn Based games; when it comes to RPGs, I'm more of an free actions kind of guy (Gothic, Dragon Age, Witcher etc). However, a colleague told me about Original Sin and I've purchased D:OS EE and had a blast with it. Unfortunately, I arrived late to the party and didn't get a chance to help Larian with their kickstarter for D:OS2, but I did pre-order it (which I almost never do). And I'm glad I did.  The goodThere are some good changes to the first game: - you can choose your companion's class when you recruit them - you can respec your character and your companions at almost any time! - if you respec, you don't lose your learned spells/skills - you now have a skill bar with many slots at the bottom of the screen - summoning, hands-down one of the best class in the game; summons can really turn the tides of battles, especially since they can be infused with different elements - full voice acting (I know EE also has that, but the original D:OS didn't)  The so-soThere are also some changes, let's call them neutral; some I've learned to like, while others not so much: - physical and magic armor: you first have to tear through your opponent's armor before you can apply any CC to them; this bothered me a lot at first, when I didn't have the means to get rid of their armors easily, but, as you gain more skills and spells, it becomes less of a problem; there are still some weird things about this system, like you fight an attack dog and it has physical armor for no reason (I mean, I understand when a human enemy has physical armor because he has a breastplate, but a naked dog?) - you have to spend skill points on Memory, which increases your skill slots; I didn't like this at first, because I'd want to spend my points on other attributes; however, it isn't as bad, as you receive free Memory slots when leveling up at certain levels - Source Points; I still don't like this mechanic as some of the best abilities are now locked behind the need of source; these good abilities already had the disadvantage of using more than 1 Memory Slot, but you also need Source to cast them; of course, you can steal source from enemies or corpses, but enemies can also steal you source - a bit of spoiler ahead: the companions that are not in your party at the end of the first area will die, so you cannot see their storyline for the remainder of that playthrough; in my opinion, this is horrible game design, but I guess it helps with replayability - your party members can leave you permanently late in the game, depending on dialog choices, even though you had a good relationship with them (high attitude) until then; I was shocked when this happened, because I don't understand what the point of companion attitude is - new game modes: PvP and Game Master; I haven't tried these yet, so I don't know if they're good, but they're there - it also comes with a free Map Editor  The badThe game also has some bad parts, of course: - I didn't play it when it launched because I was sure there were going to be bugs. I've waited for a week or two and a few patches and played it without major technical issues (though I did have a 100% crash in an area that had a lot of lava around, but lowering the graphical settings resolved that). - on the gameplay side, as many have pointed out, the last part (Arx) isn't as good as the rest of the game, but it's not really that bad. There are some weird fights with respawning enemies in a certain embassy, but those can be avoided by sneaking. P.S.: When writing this review, I'm just before the last fight, so I'm not sure what that's like.  The uglyRed Prince and the lizard kin. They're ugly AF.  VerdictThis is a must buy for any gamer who likes party-based RPGs.

This is an absolute gem. It is absolutely incredible. The graphics, the story, the gameplay, the comedy, you name it. I typically find top down cRPGs rather boring but this is definitely one of the top 10 games I have ever played. Time will tell where it lands but it is incredibly good.  There are plenty of full reviews out there so read those if you want a general review. Here is what I specifically like about it: Larian loves its players and it shows.  They really do. In DOS2, you can customize this game to make it the game you want to play. For example, I am not a hardcore CRPG guy. I like a more casual experience and I also want to play this with my partner, preferably without having to cash out for a second copy. While that might be difficult for most games in the genre, DOS2 lets us set the difficult to Explorer (which feels perfectly balanced for us) and play coop in split screen. It also allowed us to redo our builds after the first act so that any mistakes made could be adjusted without having to start over again. It also autosaves plenty, so we could easily recover from any mistake.  I could easily see how I could play DOS2 by myself and love that too. Or to play it with 3 friends who really love hardcore games. In fact, this is the closest any videogame has ever come to being a tabletop pen and paper roleplaying game IMHO.  Can't wait for DOS3.

What a brilliant game.  I am not a great fan of turn-based RPGs (or at least wasn't till now) but D:OS2 really changed that. The combat system is simply epic, both in terms of visuals and dynamics. It is so much fun to fight with strategies and due to the well-balanced difficulties, most of the fights are very exciting.  Exploring is also incredibly fun. The game has maps of decent sizes but more importantly, each act is generously full of well-scripted contents. You never know what you will find but you always know you will find something that makes your exploration valuable!  The story is quite compelling. Side stories, however, are often even more compelling. Additionally, all characters you meet have a personality that speaks to you on a human level. The attention to details for creating such a lively world should really be appreciated. Even animals have individually established personalities that make meeting them much more fun. Similarly, the dialogues are of the same quality. Very good voice acting and very well written lines.  The open-world aspect is, again, very good. The number of options you have through the gameplay is vast and unlike most other open-world games, your choices actually matter. Abundance of options applies not only to your choices of progressing through the storyline but to each part of the game. Almost everything expects some decision from you.    Graphics are very stylish and they look really good. Just by looking at the screenshots you can tell that this is a game with a fantastic world that will immerse you 100%.   The price is completely worth is without a doubt. You can easily expect 100-110 hours of gameplay from D:OS2.  In my opinion, if you like the genre of RPG at all, don't even hesitate to buy this game. This is a RPG masterpiece.

Early Access Review:   Original Sin 2 is what exactly what every RPG gamer has been looking for - there's a potency to its' immersion that every EA title should aim to hit. This is the caliber of gaming you (EA devs) should truly attempt to employ!!!! It's an absolute masterpiece of Early Access gaming. A true game of D&D mixed with chess.......Larian said they posted this game on steam with a laugh, and I know why!! Ok I'll stop with the hype and explain.   (Graphics, optimization, controls, gameplay, sound.)   Graphics/Animations: 10/10  Right from the jump you notice how polished the world and characters look. From beautiful landscapes to fluid animations, I love it!!!! Nothing left to say here! Excellent job!   Optimization: 10/10  No loading screens.. LIKE EVER during your gaming experience! Excellent work!   Controls: 9/10  No complaints other than the restriction of your camera angles. Part of the experience is viewing a gorgeous and artistic world... You can never look at the sky....and view your character from better angles.. sad. Although, you can rebind your keys, you can rotate and zoom in - You feel like you're in control. Great job!   Gameplay: 9.5/10  This is where the bulk of the game lies. From story to combat - the immersion starts with the world appearance and story narrative, then ends with a blast with its' combat delivery. The combat is spaced out making you feel like you're not always in a chat box, and you'll be satisfied in casting, buffing or even simple melee attacks.  You can be whatever you want to be. Unless you want to be an orc...you can't be an orc - BUT what you can do from what they have to offer makes you feel like you're totally in control of your character's person.   Yes, customization is quite limited. I like my rpgs to let me customize my character to the "T" ... and this does limit you in that aspect to a certain extent...better than most games but coming from MMOs you may be disappointed. Given a more customizable character and maybe even adding a few other races .. you'll never play the same character again. Character creation is key in this type of genre - still ... Excellent work!   Music/Sound: 9.5/10  The sound and music is fantastic! ... I'd still love to hear a larger variety of music during gameplay...This will probably end up being a 10 simply because they will add voice acting and more music throughout the future acts. Excellent job!   Overall: 10/10  The story, the adventure, the combat, the scenery, the ..... oh you get it already!!!! What a phenomonal game. RPG lovers, MMO lovers...hack'n'slash lovers... VIDEO GAME LOVERS! You'll love this. I wouldn't post my first review on steam if I didn't believe this to be a game for everyone on steam. Do enjoy! Thanks Larian!

One of the best games I have ever played.  Several bugs and lack of features make it fall just short of that #1 however.  My main concerns are in multiplayer. You have to play as the hosts party characters and not your own. That means playing an archer with a level 2 bow, all stats in wits and other useless talents. There is also an endless amount of bugs with multiplayer. For example, if I am host and start a multiplayer and someone joins me as say The Red Prince and I save, restart whatever, that character then becomes bugged. Instead of reverting back to The Red Prince after that player leaves, he bears that persons name and is unable to be reset, or even dismissed. You normally can talk to npc's in your party and say you want to go your seperate ways and recruit another party member, nope. bugged.  Another example is I use one of my npc's for dialect options since they have persuasion stats and my main is undead. Someone joined the game and took control of MY character and when I leveled up he butchered his stats and skills and those remained on my character after I kicked him and / or restarted the game.  These things make multiplayer extremely frustrating and have forced me to start brand new games probably about 6 times now. I haven't even been able to get through act 1. I am very wary to play in multiplayer due to all these reasons and despite preferring multiplayer in it's theory am forced to play single player to avoid game breaking bugs like those i mentioned. I wish I could provide some feedback or get some kind of bug fix on this bug I don't see an option for that. Thankfully the developer is very involved in the game and will probably fix this at some point. I am now hoping that a user created mod will fix many of these issues in the future (thank god this game has mods)  Despite all my frustrations this game is absolutely incredible in every other aspect. Everything is voiced, every npc which is amazing. Graphics are good (not great) especially for this type of game. Quests are actually fun and not all fetch they actually have lore. There is an absolute freedom: you can kill every npc and still proceed with the game. The gameplay is some of the best ever. This genre has been ruined in the past decade with games like the Final Fantasy series dropping the traditional turn-based combat for an active combat. Yeah, thats nice in some circumstances but it is extremely boring hacking and slashing repetitively just like every other game. The combat in D:OS2 is calculated, and detailed. Everything is listed and heavily focused on strategy and statuses. The game encourages using environments such as high ground and environmentals like barrels and puddles in order to gain favor in battle.   The best part of the game is the fact it's challenging. The default difficulty will probably be too hard for average gamers and those not familiar with the genre or the first game. There are two higher difficulties on top of that which are extremely challenging (I normally play on the highest difficulty in every other game) The next best thing would be that the developers aren't EA, Ubisoft, Activision, etc and force paywalls on an incomplete game and don't support the game after launch. This dev actually cares and I have personally downloaded atleast one patch per day and they have already stated that they are going to implement being able to use your own character in multiplayer which is something I look forward to. Can't wait to see what's next for this game.

THE STORY: This is by far the most densely rich lore I‚Äôve played through from any game I‚Äôve played, where almost everyone and everything is connected in one way or another. Creating a living and breathing world, where one‚Äôs actions and decisions will affect their adventures through Rivellon. The part where this game shines the most, is how it gives the player choices on how they want to advance the story in any way the player chooses to play. Choose to be good, evil, just or whatever mood you choose, this game adapts to it and guides you to the end that your choices led to. While I‚Äôve only completed Fane‚Äôs Story (in the moment of writing this), the endings it gives you will satisfy however you played. While you can choose how your adventure ends, the game lets you know how those actions will affect Rivellon in the future. The reason why I love this story is how grim and real this story plays out, no one is truly good or evil, it‚Äôs all a grey area, but it‚Äôs your choice on how you want to navigate in it.  THE COMBAT: There was never a dull moment every time I went into battle, or stumble on to one. While combat is turn-based, pre-battle is when things become interesting. Some approaches I found to be more fun is laying out traps and pre-emptive attacks on unknowing enemies. I can go into combat with my enemies clinging on 5% health and wipe them out with one attack. This is true liberty that this game gives to players, it gives you the tools and it‚Äôs up to you on how to use them. And this is just combat, skills can give a creative twist to combat. You can chain attacks to deliver devastating blows to your enemies or toy around with them by unleashing various Statues Effects and skills that can either immobilize them or transform them into chickens. All this creates a simple yet complex toy box you can play with. Finding out what seems fun and effective will make you want to seek out the next battle and unleash your battle plan.  THE MUSIC: I do not, in any way, have any complaints or criticisms about the music. The only thing I can say is that it is Divine. The music makes Rivellon and in turn makes you believe that it is a real place and these characters who live in it are part of a giant play. The 4 instruments that you can pick (while you build your character) creates the mood in how you want to play and you can change it any time you want.  This is the best RPG for this generation. While there are quite a few bugs the developer needs to fix, this doesn‚Äôt affect how much I love this game.

A wonderful game with a great (if flawed) combat system, fun characters, an interesting world with deep lore and most importantly it has a full co-op story experience. You'll want to replay this game with new character ideas or to test your knowledge of the game in tactican or honour mode. But if I thought DOS1 was brilliant and needed changes, then I must admit I feel the same way about DOS2. My main issue being that the combat system filters you to certain ways of playing which DOS1 did too but DOS2 does in different ways. Party of 4? Stick to either physical or magical damage focus for all, as mixing stats makes both weak or one side essentially useless (but doable on explorer mode). Party of 1 or 2? Hit that Lone Wolf talent on character creation and you'll have the most fun the game can give. To an extent you can mix damage skills quite well and not have a bad character.   With that said, you'll have many hours of fun making characters that work and even those that don't (which you can thankfully fix after act 1).

Divinity: Original Sin 2 reawakened sensations I haven't felt in many years. This is definetly one of the better games I have played in a long time. If I am being fairly honest, I did find the combinations of genres a tad bit peculiar, I do however enjoy the core genres a lot seperatly (RPG, Turn-Based Strategy, Story Rich, Character Customization), so I decided to give it a shot anyways. I was a bit reluctant to pay +45$ for it, but holy‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•am I glad I did. I do have a few Issues with the game, but they are heavily outweighed by the positive aspects (+ for positives, - for negatives).   + Fantastic setting  Now I have no prior experiences with the early/earlier title(s), but the game did a splendid job of introducing me to all the different kinds of political strife, discrimination predujice, as well as the fanatical religious zealots. I quickly became aware of the kind of world my character was living in, so I could more easily integrate the character I wanted to play.   + Beautiful landscapes  The maps are by no means short of details, with the next accessible area being even more astonishing than the first. I can't even fathom how many hours went into designing these places.   + Intriguing story	 I will make this one brief & completely spoiler free. The story is absoloutely captivating in almost every aspect.   + Loveable cast of characters  All of your potential followers (with the exception of Mercenaries), all have their own unique storylines, and backgrounds, with your game experience changing depending on who you choose to bring with you along for the ride. Personally I was especially intrigued by characters such as Lohse & Sebille, but should you decide to try out the game for yourself, you might yourself intrigued by other characters.   + Side activities, rewards & exploration   The game does a great job of keeping you busy, there is never a lack of stuff to do. Honestly 50% of the time you will probably have +10 unfinished quests in your journal. The game also does an even better job of making sure you are properly rewarded, and that also accounts for exploration. Matter or fact the game almost encourages you to explore & do side quests, because the game gets exceedingly hard if you don't make sure to gain a few levels.   + Regretting class choice? No problem homie.  Did you initially choose a stealthy assassin, but you'd actually rather play as a blazing pyromancer? Not a problem the game has got your back. After the 1st Act you are able to change reallocate your stat points, afterwards just get some new suitable equipment and you are good to go.  Now I could go on and on, about what I love about this game, but I also want to get into some of the few issues I have with the game.   - Normal difficulty is too hard at first (for newcommers).  Now I am by no means a hardcore gamer, like I previously was (I am more of a casual these days), but I personally found the earliest stages of the game too tedious to play through on the normal difficulty, and I ended up getting a bit stuck at one point, so I had to lower the difficulty until I could establish a solid foothold. However once I did get a foothold, I went back to the normal difficulty, to find it to be perfectly suitable, but an interresting challenge.   Tag values.  (For the unintiated "tags" are basically character descriptions. E.g. you choose wether your character was an established educated noble, or a battleready savage) Now no playthrough should ever be the same, which is why I can accept some missions only being accessible with certain followers. What I cannot accept is some character tags granting access to certain quests, while others are pretty useless apart from a few entertaining dialouges. For instance, during Act 2, you will be barred from certain quests if you don't have the scholar tag, whereas (from my own experience at least), the Barbarian tag only allows for some savage remarks. It does slightly ruin the RPG element of the game. And I honestly don't want to be forced to pick the scholar tag to get the most enjoyable experience with the game. I don't know about you, but I don't want my bearded-battlescarred-battleaxe wielding-viking warrior to be a bloody bookworm.   What to do next?   This is likely my biggest issue with the game.. I have 1 sentence to describe this in better words..  Thank ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for online guides!..	 I would really be at a terrible loss without them. The game does a mediocre (at best) job of telling you where to go next. For instance I often found myself struggling to get through opponents 2 levels higher than me (mostly in act 2), because the game did not inform me of the best area to go to in order to level up. I initially did learn to save often so if I found myself in an unwinable battle I could always retreat, explore elsewhere (hopefully the right places), get some levels and return later. Although it was very frustrating at first. Another point I want to make is that the player journal feels incredibly clumsy to look at, so I did often find myself unsure of the next approach to take on certain quests in order to proceed, so I had to look up guides so I could figure out what to do, (the game can feel like a bit of a puzzle once in a while).   = Multiplayer experience	 Can't really comment since none of my homies, play this game (And I have no real interrest in playing it with strangers), but I have only heard great things about it.   Rating	 Despite the issues I have with the game, none of them are actually gamebreaking, and are pretty much easily fixable, and their are - as I said earlier - heavily outweighed by the positive aspects of the game. All in all it is definetly worth your hard-earned money. I will rate this game a staggering = 9/10  (Also I do apoligise for any grammatical errors).

With so many ways to play and succeed, DOS2 rekindles that old feeling of D&D the way many have wanted for a long time. If you're used to a game that holds your hand, you might find yourself confused or lost, as there's minimal help in the game. But if you want adventure, strategy and tactical gameplay, you may have found your time-killer. Well worth the money.  THE GOOD - The story is well-fleshed out and full of characters you'll see (or not see, if they die) again at some point. - Combat is tactical, complex, and sometimes downright difficult, even on the easiest setting. Sometimes it felt like sitting at a table of miniatures and contemplating the next move like a game of chess.  The AI is quite good, and the enemy may stay just out of range and teleport your characters into lava. - Characters are almost completely customizable at a certain point, so if you don't like something, feel free to swap it out when you want. - Audio is rather engaging. - The game easily remembers things you've done and never turns out the same way twice. - Carry weight feels limitless, so you won't have to worry about over-encumbrance bothering your honest gameplay. - Vendors have good gear almost all the time, refreshing frequently, though almost anyone can be traded with.  THE BAD - Inability to go back to previous zones for exploration or completion of side quests with no relation to the main story. This can lead to forgetting a map you just got used to, and having to learn a whole new one. - For some players, explorer mode may in fact be too difficult at some points, and you may feel boxed in, unable to explore or retreat. - Occasionally, controls regarding moving characters or unchaining them momentarily feels hamfisted. Taking extra steps to just make one character go somewhere is awkward. - There's almost never a time when you're not standing on a corrupt surface in combat, which requires extra effort to clean, extra effort you likely can't put in on time to change it. This means a large portion of your combat time will be spent dealing with endless DOTs and also an inability to heal your characters. - Pet Pal is an almost essential talent to have for one character, wasting some more valuable talent space for the ability to talk to rats.  THE UGLY - Crafting feels like an incomplete feature. Recipes are learned via experimentation or finding it in a book somewhere, but there are many times when you simply would have no clue how to craft things, and don't need to because vendors have what you need. Would you have thought you could make lockpicks by combining a hammer and nails? Never did discover how to make trap disarming kits.  SUMMARY Definitely a great game. Buy it and enjoy it, over and over again.

TL;DR Buy this game! Best RPG game I've ever played and in my top 3 games of all time without a doubt. There are hundreds of hours of gameplay here. The gameplay is quality unlike games like Skyrim which pretty much relies on mods to be fun for extended play sessions, which this game also offers. Dialog and story is also some of the best you'll find in recent games with  every piece of dialog being voiced which is just a great thing for an Indie game to do.  Seriously 9.9/10 game.  This is honestly the best RPG I have ever played and one of the best games I've played in general. This is one of the few single-player games that I just can't stop playing.   Before I played this game me and my friends played a lot of D&D, but we couldn't find enough time to play as much as we'd like since we were in our final year of school. So for ages I looked for a game that could emulate that same expirence. Being able to do what I want, having funny moments as well as epic. When one of my friends showed me this I was hooked.   The mechanics are almost the exact same as old school table top games, so iif you're into that turn based combat you'll love this, but even someone like me that normally hates those kind of combat mechanics in games I just loved these just because of how polished they were. The combat suprisingly has a lot of depth to it. There's so many different spells and equipment and many of them interact with eachother in their own ways.  The story and dialog is also one of the best I've ever seen in a game. Most of the dialog has so much character and is of such high quality, only of the voices feel as they were acted poorly, but 10000x better than you'll see in any Bethesda game. The fact that all of the dialog in the game is voice acted is also just an amaznig thing. It makes it feel as you're living in a real world and it also helps with the consistancy where some lines would be voiced and some wouldn't. This wouldn't mean anything iff the story wasn't good, which thankfully it isn't. The story is so good. It pulls you emotionally in so many different directions and you have to make so many decisions that make or break relationships and have an effect on what happens for the rest of the game.  Character creation is also pretty good, different races and classes having different traits and abilities as per usual. This part is the only part that I find to be pretty hard on new characters since some races and classes are harder to play than others, which can make it difficult and punishing. This can become a non-issue early in the game since you have the choice to pretty much change everything about you if you're not happy about it.  The one thing that I wish could be different about the game is its modding cababilities. Sadly as of now there aren't any mods anywhere near as big as mods that you find in Bethesda games, but thankfully this isn't a Bethesda game so you don't need mods to make it interesting lmao. This game does have the ability to act as your own Dungeon Master and make a whole game for you, your friends and your fellow steam gamers. and you also have the ability to download other peoples campains which just extends the hundreds of hours in the base game.  This game is almost a perfect example of what a game should be. For the gamer by not constantly trying to ram microtransactions down every hole in your body, have hundreds of high quality content from launch. Constant interaction with the community, THESE GUYS MAKE VLOGS MAN!!! and last but not least they don't do what every triple-a developer is doing now and making all their content and just releasing it as expansions. These guys are just about to release a FREE expansion that adds hundreds of more hours of gameplay which I would be more than happy to pay for since it is actually worth it and it's made to add value to the game instead of be a stupid cash grab.     SO IN SUMMARY. Buy this game, its amazing how an indie studio made on of the best games of recent times from a kickstarter with a reasonably small studio compared to multi-billion dollar companies that make subpar games at best. These people really care about what they create and it shows in their final product. I recommend this game to everyone and I feel like a better person everytime I do so.

AHHHHHHHHH where to start. You are thrust into a world of magic without knowing what to do, but you use something called the HUMAN BRAIN to explore and inspect the world around you talking to every detailed and voice acted character, listening to the smooth Chocolaty voice of the narrator. [ AI 7/10 ]  Story - The story is kinda Celica BUT it works how everything molds together and even better for each main quest there are usually about 10 different ways you can do it or you could just skip it all together (this might only be for the first section the skipping part IDK that yet)  Map(s) - There's about 4 of them and they are each with there own story and problems you can choose to fix or simply just kill them all the people (BTW I tested this and yes you can kill every one IKR AMAZING I LOVE KILLING!!!!!) no people no problem. Every map is diverse and different from the last with different looks and settings which only helps the game to feel EVEN MORE ALIVE. (Maps 10/10) They are all ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING fantastic love em.  Quest system and shizz - For you to start a quest you must speak to someone who has one right? YAH YEET pick up a sword BOOM you just started a quest pick up a phoenix egg BOOOM you just started.... well I guess ended a quest but hey that's for you to find out. The quest system is pretty regular compared to most quest systems BUT GUESS WHAT there is no back and forth quest EX: Hey you send this letter to queen stupid face so she can send me back and equally useless letter so I can send her back another and another etc... This game Has NON of the thankfully also you can get a quest from animals these Devs were on like weed or something when making this game because some of the quests are AMAZING there was one where I had to kill a chicken. Conclusion - This game is a must buy for D&D players strategy players and also starters it is well optimized and loading is like zipping fast but in some areas, they do throw a lot at you so be wary of that, and if the game is on sale it's even MORE worth it. So it's a Buy. [This Game is a 9/10 With a Badass seal of approval]  Quick shizz:  Cons - Kinda repetitive at times/story can lead you astray in the last part /  Pros - Good combat / Replayable / Great sound design / Awesome music / Good effects or graphics / Gorry / Charm / Fun even if you don't have friends :D (like me ;-; ).

Pros:One of the best co-op experiences I've ever played. Assuming you're playing with a patient, like-minded group. Amazing story. Well crafted characters. I love the new physical/magic armor system. Status effects aren't as overpowered as they were in the first game (They're still insanely good.) AI. It's brutally efficient. Most of the time. Beautiful graphics engine, with all the expected graphical options. I believe all the dialog has a voice over, and the acting is excellent. The animals with human voices are especially hilarious. (Using the Pet Pal talent.) Reasonably priced at $45. No Loot Boxes/Season Passes/Micro-Transactions. If they put out and old-school style expansion pack I'd buy it in a heartbeat. Origin characters are a great addition over the first game. It adds a ton of replayability. GM Mode is amazing. You could run a full D&D campaign over the internet with your friends using this tool. Dev team is still very active in fixing bugs. An instant classic, right up there with Baldur's Gate. Steam Workshop supports adds a ton of content to the game. Neutral:Running the game two player with the Lone Wolf talent is super unbalanced. I'm kind of enjoying it though. Above level 5 or 6 Lone Wolf makes tactician mode feel like normal mode. That being said the very beginning of the game on tactician is really rough with only two people. The game is still kind of linear, but nowhere near as bad as the first game. Cons:If you're playing this game as a four person group, progressing through the storyline can sometimes feel like herding cats. Scholar tag seems overly important. Make sure you have at least one character in your party with it. There are several quests that require you to have it in order to finish. Armor scaling gets out of hand past the early teen levels. Picked up items being automatically added to your hotbars. Polymorph skills that add additional skills automatically added to hotbars. Can't fix this without using a mod, and I don't want to disable my achievements. Never played the first, but I've been loving everything about this so far. I've always enjoyed the style of game that feels pseudo pen-and-paper D&D (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Neverwinter Nights, etc.). But with those, and even D&D itself, I have a similar gripe with special moves and spells, which tend to work on a very limited, "x uses per day" system. Divinity 2 has a similar feel to those kinds of games, but most abilities and spells have a turn cooldown.  Also, where the default in those other games mentioned was real-time with options to pause on triggers, or to manually pause and unpause, combat in this is solely turn-based. Battles tend to feel a lot more strategic as a result. Also a bit chaotic, as elemental effects get thrown across the field all the time. The important thing to note is that all of your characters are likely to get set on fire or be poisoned in most battles. It's inevitable.  I haven't played multiplayer, but it's been great playing single player because of the character stories. A full party of 4, and I'm really wanting to know more about all the pre-made characters. While you can make a fully custom character, I recommend playing the first time with one of the characters that has a backstory. It's really adding to the lore to have a character with a much more fleshed out backstory than I'm used to seeing in these kinds of games, and it's been adding another layer of fun to not just roleplay, but try to roleplay my character (in dialog, you'll get prompts for why a certain option is choosable, and you'll sometimes have your character's name next to an option to show it's choosable because of their backstory, which I don't think you'd get if you made a fully custom character).  If you've enjoyed other cRPGs then all I can say is two thumbs up -- would recommend.
