It's a long game, but a good game. II just finished my first playthrough at 110 hours. I didn't complete EVERY quest but I did come to some sort of resolution for most of them. Divinity Original Sin 2 is a rich and beautiful world to explore with an explosive and exciting turn based combat system. The game has a very intersting story that is 99% voiced which goes a long way in immersing you into this world. I never knew that I needed games like this to be voiced and to have a narrator. Take note Pillars of Eternity 2. It gives you this sense of going on a real Dungeons and Dragons style adventure. It conjures up feelings of Baulder's Gate 2 while being very modern and engaging. This is the divinitive CRPG experience in gaming today. I firmly believe it will be a classic like the CRPGs of old.   The game isn't without it's flaws though. Firstly the last two acts slog a bit. There are still tons of interesting things that happen and a few jaw-dropping moments, but some parts I struggled to boot my PC up and play the game. This comes right into the second flaw, the game is a little too long. You definitely get your money's worth. This game would give you good value per dollar even if it cost $100, and it only cost $45 US. It's a freaking steal. However, when it takes 100+ hours to beat a game while seeing most of it's content sometimes you just burn out a bit. Finally there are some flaws with the actual gameplay a few times. Some of the puzzles are unecessarily difficult, sometimes it feels like the enemy gets 10 turns for every 1 turn you get, and it has performance issues in a few spots.   However, overall this game is the best game of 2017. It's an absolute steal at $45 and the game tells you a story you won't soon forget. Easy reccomendation to anyone even slightly interested in CRPGs.

First I want to talk about the character creation, I found it a bit annoying to navigate and felt it would have been much better if everything was on one screen instead of multiple screens, Fallout 2 did this well, you can increase your main attributes and pick and choose skills/traits, all on one screen. The creation itself is pretty standard, pick your preset "class" although you can choose which abilities you want to start with, your preset will determine the pool of abilities you get, if you choose a rogue you get rogue abilities, if you choose a summoner, you get summoner abilities. The talents in this game are absolutely terrible, there are 1-2 amazing ones, 3-4 decent ones and the rest are pretty crappy and not worth picking up. Stuff like hothead, which gives you 10% accuracy and 10% critical chance, this is pretty insignificant but you know whatever its decent I guess but oh wait it is only at full health, and if you don't know, this game's combat is pretty much all about having poison and fire and all kinds of stuff happening on the battlefield, your characters will almost definitely be on fire or poisoned, it is pretty much impossible to avoid it from happening, and while your healer(s) will probably be able to keep you topped up, it just seems not worth the effort for such a small buff.  I now want to start talking about how fun the combat is, I started as a rogue and it was pretty boring to start with but as I progressed and my party progressed I was able to cast tons of different abilities and spells to change the battlefield to something that is advantageous to me. For example, I started as an undead, and being a rogue I just blinked on-top of the enemy and dropped poison at my feet, this allowed me to gain a small amount of healing and also damage the enemy, but that is just a very small advantage. You can mix elements to totally screw with your enemies, you can drop some rain down (this makes them wet) and then just use an aoe chill spell and this will freeze everybody and they will be helpless for a turn, allowing you to bash their heads in. And later on you gain the ability to change these elements even more, but that is somewhat spoilerific so I will refrain from going into details on that. Not only is it really fun strategizing how you are going to fight in battles, but every spell looks amazing and the game in general looks spectacular.  The quests in this game are excellent, there are no generic "kill 20 goblins and bring me their toenails" quests which makes you look forward to the next quest you will run into, everything is voiced, which you wouldn't really expect from a game that has so many different outcomes in dialogue in and out of quests. The voice acting is very good I would say, besides the NPC dialogue you will regularly hear the narrator talk, and he has a very good voice, they did a good job of making you feel like you were in the moment experiencing everything, the great descriptive writing allows you to close your eyes and picture whatever the narrator is talking about. Something I quite like is how your character creation changes NPC dialgoue, most NPC's will reward you in some way for simply being their race, some characters are seemingly racist and despise elves or dwarves (these characters are usually not involved in quests so you don't miss out on anything). There are also some NPC's that reward you in some way for having certain Character Tags, a soldier will relate to another soldier which increases relation with them, this gives a discount when trading with them which helps a bit. The game really feels as though you would have had a completely different outcome in a quest for simply having changed 1 or 2 things in character creation. It makes you eager to finish the game and restart as a totally different character and hear all of the dialogue you totally missed the first time around.  That mostly concludes my thoughts on the game, just gonna put some arbitrary numbers here.  -Gameplay 4/5 The combat is extremely fun and challenging too albeit a tad annoying when you take on too many enemies and wonder why you are incapable of winning.  -Story/Quests 4/5 All of the quests I have done I enjoyed and I look forward to seeing how the story of my character progresses once I leave the Island.  -Graphics 4/5 Not absolutely mindblowing but definitely looks good.  Overall I would say the game is very good, one of the best RPG's I have played in my life and I haven't even beaten it yet. I look forward to the rest of the game, I put 30 hours into just the first zone of the game, so I hope the rest of the game has the same amount of content and I will easily see 200 hours worth of content in this game depending on how thoroughly you play through each quest and explore everything.

Amazing and very promising game. As it prequel, Divinity Original Sin 1, it is an awesome, interesting and funny game.   I really liked that they had different options for player who prefers the story over the combat or vice versa. I personally prefer the rol part over the combat, so this was a welcomed surprise for me. The combat system, turn based, is in my opinion a smart choice they made. A refreshing touch after all the more 'action' based RPGS, like Skyrim. You can really plan a strategy and take your time to give orders to your characters. Or you can ignore combat and focus on the story. I loved the graphics the locations are beautiful, and I really enjoyed that they were not the typical ‚ÄòEuropean medieval forest‚Äô type but rather deserts or tropical islands. I loved that this time we were able to play as different species (I played as the Red Prince) and specially that you could chose a premade character or a new one (with any option for species/sex/race etc). I really liked that the ‚Äònon chosen characters‚Äô end up being your companions. It is something that I always wanted from the first Dragon Age. Every character had a very specific personality and very interesting backstories, the same as a very funny banter.  I would only complain about the lack of lore connecting this game with the others in the Divinity Series. I found it a little bit confusing, specially regarding the first Divine divinity. I would only complain about many parts of the game still being bug (like many quests and some characters like Fane). This was disappointing but I hope that will improve with further patches.  In my opinion it is one of the most addictive and fun games that I played lately.

Everything that made the first game amazing, with the fat cut and a ton of new stuff. I loved the story, the detailed graphics, the wonderful voice acting, the music that has only improved from the incredible soudtracks of the other Divinity games, the new gameplay mechanics and skills, and just about everything. The annoying "skill tier" system of the last game has been greatly downplayed by the memory stat, meaning the only limit to what skills you can use are slots to equip them in. The combat has been improved by enemies who teleport themselves and you, inflict status effects, and generally act a lot smarter than the last game. I found the tactic of "start a big fire and teleport anyone who tries to escape back into the fire" that made short work of most enemies in the last game uneffective here, and that made combat more dynamic. Everyone now has physical and magical defense which guard against not only health loss but status effects, so it may become necessary to recover someones magic armor if you know the enemy might charm you. There are dozen of examples like this. There are plenty of standard skills like fire, warrior, necromancy etc but the one that really stood out to me was polymorph. Spread wings and fly around the battlefield or turn enemies into helpless chickens or grow bull horns and charge enemies from great distance. There are so many great skill combos and plenty of tricky enemies to use them on. I honestly believe this game will go down as one of the greatest RPGs of all time along greats like Deus Ex and Baldur's Gate. It offers the same level of freedom in quest design, combat, and story that all the greats do. I have heard a lot of games like Mario Kart referred to as "friendship ruiners" and this game is the exact opposite. Its fun solo sure but if you have a nerdy friend or spouse or whoever, this game will be a great bonding excercise. It supports controllers in a smooth satisfying way for such a complex game. I look forward to another chapter of this fantastic series and an eventual console port so I can buy and enjoy this masterpiece all over again

I highly recommend this game! I have almost 100 hours into this game and they've been a GOOD 100 hours. The most surprising part of this game is that the story is good. You have to make serious decisions that can have lasting ramifications on the game. The story is great, but the game play is also great. Mind you, it's pretty hard. Just when you feel like you're doing really well, the enemies ramp up and get harder. So this is a pretty challenging game, but it's also very satisfying.  I really enjoy the different builds and the ability to reset your character. That means that if you get bored with a play style or run into a really difficult section, you can respec. As soon as I beat it, I will likely play through it again as a lone wolf.   There were a few bugs that I ran into, but reloading and doing something else first would fix it. For example, if interacting with a certain object causes the game to crash, travel to another area, do some trading, then come back. Or use a different character.   I have only two major complaints. The first is inventory management. Moving things around is tedious. I like having the Wares system, which is where you can move an item into this category called "Wares", then sell all your wares at once to a vendor. Saves time with the vendor, but not placing them into wares. I also had my strength hero be the pack mule. So I'd have to move the item to the Red Prince, then right click and move to wares. Tedious, but manageable.   The second complaint is the persuasion system. It seemed like I failed literally every persuasion attempt for the first half of the game. I gave up on making it work. See, I would see an Intelligence-based persuasion attempt and would say, "Ok, I'll use my dude who has maxed intelligence." FAIL. What the heck?! Turns out that not only do you need high intelligence, you need high persuasion, which is a stat you can level up. Later, when I had more points to spare, I maxed out persuasion on two characters, one finesse based, one int based. That way, I always have someone who can win that persuasion. It was minor and I was able to live with failing literally every persuasion attempt.   Anyway, I give this game a 9/10. The only reason I don't give it a 10/10 is because my summoner can't have more than one summon out at a time! I want to summon my spirit wolf, summon my incarnate, and summon a bone widow from my summoner main! But alas, you can only have one summon out at a time.   BUY THIS GAME

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a masterpiece cRPG. It's got an awesome balance between fun, roleplaying, exploration, tactical combat and nice stories. Its got an enormous amount of choices to make in both playstyle and solving puzzles. Those puzzles, as well as combat can sometimes be unforgivingly hard though, so prepare to quicksave often.

This game can only be decscribed as a labor of love, and Larian Studios should be praised for what they have accomplished. In many ways this game is the gold standard for what a sequel should look like. The combat is exceptional, it lets you approach a combat situation from multiple angles, environmental interaction is wide and vary, and percise usage of skills is critical to controlling the battlefield. The story is entertaining, and every side mission you happend upon is either hilarious or contributes to the lore of the world  with great voice acting for every major/minor NPC (even the animals are voiced and some will even give you questlines). Finally the environment of the game itself is gorgeous, ad the amount of detail that the developers have put into this game only gives it a more immersive feel as you explore the game. It is a must have, and is a golden example of what we should expect from game developers from any genre/franchise.

Divinity Original Sin 2 was the first game of the Divine games that I had tried / pickup and really enjoyed myself when getting through the game and making progress with my original party. From my personal experience, DOS 2 offers unique ways to solve different quests while also being punishing if you screw it up and not letting you get a retry button (unless you reload a save). From the character selection to the origin characters, divinity has a very vast variety of options to choose for your characters skills, do you want to be a tanky mage? or how about being an rogue who can polymorph enemies into chickens. When you get into the game after making a custom character or choosing one of the six origin characters, you are able to pick up to three other origin characters to recruit into your party and journey along together till you reach your end goal. What sets this game differently from an RPG like skyrim or fallout is that you actually get to do side quest for your companions and are able to learn more about him or her through dialog, not having bland reused dialog changing with the envoirment and how they see you as an ally or an enemy depending on if you're being rude to them. On top of all of that another part that I enjoy is that all most all dialog (except some that have been added recently to put players in the right direction and some that are just bugged) are 100% voice acted, from the Red Prince to a dog in Fort Joy each entity has its own character and appeal to them. One thing that makes divinity shine from most RPGs is that you can physically kill any NPC you want, from entire towns to some of Fort Joys residence (But killing origin characters will cause problems with the main story line so avoid doing so) allowing you to kill a trading that you might have a grudge over if you want some of their loot from their store. Finally the loot system is extravagant allowing you to have different loot while looting dungeons in different play throughs based on Lucky Charm and loot tables that were generated in the game, while also not completely dropping the NPC's inventory if killed making it more useful to pickpocket them for their better wears before killing. Overall I love DOS 2 as a game, it personally has to be one of my favorite games released this year, should you pay $45? Yes this game is worth every cent the COOP is amazing and the story and side quest will have your save be longer than 40 hours or more depending on if you go into the nitty gritty.

The game starts a little rough/boring when you're on the ship (I did not like it at all), but after that short area the game slowly opens up and before you know it you have been absorbed into it. The attention to detail (all animals are voiced but you only talk to them if you spend a point on the required ability), the flexibility that your abilities come with opens up many options for battles and exploration that is mostly limited by your imagination, and the little hand holding when it comes to exploration (you must talk and explore around instead of waiting for ! marks and waypoints) allows for a greater immersion. I got this game not expecting much outside of a regular RPG, but what I got was an old school DnD-esque game with a lot of depth and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• me if that's not something that we haven't seen in ages. If you liked games like Baldurs Gate and the more recent Pillars of Eternity then this game will grab a hold of you and never let you go.

This game varies wildly between really great and confusingly terrible.  Good:  -The combat is amazing and the ways you interact with the world are interesting and sometimes novel. -There are some pretty fun / interesting / unique puzzles. -The voice acting is pretty good. (except anything involving goblins, they obnoxiously hiss all their s's) There are few enough of them now that it isn't a problem.  Bad  -Inventory management is a nightmare. I'm pretty sure it was made to be as obtuse as possible, which is a problem when you're contantly getting buried under garbage you need to sift through. This has been improved, but it's still tedious.  -The puzzles that aren't good (most of them) are really awful. They are either ridiculously tedious or obtuse, or both. The devs apparently thought that searching rooms pixel by pixel to find tiny camouflaged buttons is fun gameplay. It is not fun gameplay. It happens all the goddamn time.  This is absolutely still the case, some of the puzzles are goddamn idiotic and will absolutely destroy your immersion and enjoyment. Pixel hunts are much less common at least.   -The difficulty curve is strange.  The first main zone (levels 3 through ~9) is far harder than the rest of the game, and is capped off by a boss that is frankly complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t.   Difficulty curve is still real frontloaded, but the bigger problem is accidentally wandering into encounters that are 2 to 3 levels higher than the one you're supposed to go to because they were closer, and the game wasn't clear about the order you're expected to do things in.   - Every once in a while the game will just instantly kill you in a way you couldn't reasonably have expected. This isn't a huge problem since quicksaves are fast and easy but it's still frustrating.   This doesn't happen anymore as far as I can tell.   -So much running. So much of your time in this game will just be spent running through places you've already been.    The game has great combat but everything that isn't the combat tends to be tedious garbage or trying to figure out what the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• the game wants you to do because it never bothered to tell you.  Pretty mediocre on average but it does enough different and there are enough fun and unique moments that it's worth trying out. (It's long as hell though so set aside some time. Oh yes, also there are issues with overclocked CPUs and GPUs.  Come on Larian, get your technical issues as sorted out as you've gotten the combat in this game.

Let me start off by saying that I don't normally write reviews for games unless they are exceptional. This game lies in one of the few exceptions where I have to.  I bought this game when it first released but I didn't have a good computer to actually fully enjoy it. Fast forward to recently when I did buy one and I fully spent the time to play this game. At first, it seemed difficult for me as I never played the first Divinity and tried to learn my way around the game. Not that long after, I got familiar with the story and the lore. From someone who doesn't enjoy care about the plot of most RPG's or MMORPG's, this game somehow brought the story forward for me to be interested in. I personally built an attatchment to my character and my companions as we continued on this adventure through Divinity. It was an amazing experience and that was when I knew what a gem this game was.  Some of the elements that I found compelling about this game was:   The voice acting - The many actors who portrayed the characters in this game did not disappoint. At times, I was just shocked at the amount of emotion and passion placed into each line of dialogue. My personal favorite was the voice actor for Lohse, whom I felt went above and beyond what some would just skim past. Also a big round of applause to those actors who put themselves out there to voice each animal or dungeon rat that was available throughout the game.   The combat - The understanding of many tactical aspects of each combat situation made it harrowing for me, in a fun sort of way. It was fun to experiment different strategies to clear a particular room of enemies or be faced with decisions that could affect whether or not my party makes it out of combat alive. The high-ground/low-ground system made it particularly mindful to pay attention to your surroundings while the natural elemental occurences (such as oil, poison, fire, etc,) keep you on your toes.   The storytelling - As stated in the above paragraph, the story is phenomenal. I found myself always wondering what would happen next and how my actions would affect the world down the line. It was truly one of the times where I found myself relating to my character, as if I were them rather than me controlling them. I truly loved the way the world was set up and how mostly everything had some role to play either in the narrative of the story or just to contribute to the feel of the world.   The world - Speaking of the feel of the world, everything was how it should be to establish a world that felt dynamic and alive. NPC's truly made their experiences feel real with some having problems that seemed normal and how they were portrayed. I sometimes imagined the theoretical lives of these NPC's and treated them as if they were real people with their own past experiences. When a game can make you engrossed into their world, you know it is good.   Music - The music was excellent at many areas and shifts according to the environment that you were placed in. Dungeons or naturally spooky areas had a feeling of dread but the suspensful and harrowing music helped contribute to the feel of this.  The music that played during the ending fight actually had me tearing up as even though it was something that I heard so many times, knowing that this was final area made it truly special and evoked a lot of memories and emotions of the overall adventure   Overall, I had just finished my first campaign and am planning on finishing more as to learn more about the companions that I did not choose at first and to see all the possible routes that I can go through before I eventually clear up the game. The game's amazing and a big thanks for Larian Studios for putting out such a masterpiece. I don't ever do reviews normally because I always think, why the heck would anyone be interested in what you've got to say?! lol! But this is how strongly I feel about this game!   A bit about me ('cos hey this is what you came to read right?! Nah, I just thought if you're like me you might enjoy this game too) I'm a 37 yr old female gamer and I love games ranging from GTA:V, Mass Effect, Battlefield, CoD, The Elder Scrolls Online, Skyrim, Dishonoured, God of War, The Witcher 3, Final Fantasy to Stardew Valley, Command and Conquer, Tropico etc, as well as all the retro Nintendo classics on NES, SNES, N64 and Gamecube etc.  So I've got a pretty eclectic mix of games I like, and I'm definitely not a gaming pro, more a casual gamer who just happens to get absolutely addicted to great games!  I stumbled on this one day browsing my queue and I'm beyond happy I did.  I actually think the storyline's ten times better than Skyrim (and boy do I loooooove Skyrim!).  The graphics are stunning and the music is so on point it's unreal. I've sank over 130 hrs into DOS:2 and if I didn't work full-time for a living I'd have probably sank in triple that amount, this is how engaging I've found it so far!   From having played games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and Neverwinter Nights back in the day, DOS:2 immediately caught my eye as I fancied a nostalgia trip.... but damn it was SO much more than that! The narration is brilliantly engaging, witty and fantastically acted, and the love that Larian have put into building their characters backstories is blindingly obvious and unparalleled.  There's so much depth in there and it's so well padded out that I honestly can't fault it in the slightest.  Larian just became one of my favourite studios and I wish I'd known about DOS:2 when they were securing funding over on Kickstarter, because hell yeah I would have backed them!  The only thing I struggled with to begin with was the difficulty, in that modern games tend to spoon feed us tidbits and tips on what we should be doing in a game, they're full of map-markers and quest highlights on the map etc. specifically guiding us to the people and places we need to see, the tasks we need to do.  DOS:2 on the other hand demands that you think on your feet and outside the box! Sure it has a journal function with your quests loosely written in (actually in a journal format though), but it's absolutely down to you to work out how to accomplish that quest and there's zero hand holding.  But to be honest with you, it's actually something I've come to love about this game, for once it's a game that actually really requires to start using your brain, otherwise you're going to miss key elements of a fantastic story.  Enough waffling from me, just do yourself a favour and if you love RPGs of any kind, buy this! - I'm over 130 hrs in and I'm on Act 4 already looking forward to my next play through!

Divinity Original Sin 2 is an isometric computer RPG in the tradition of old-school pen & paper RPGs (such as Dungeons & Dragons) brought to the digital age.  In DOS2, you'll take on the role of one of six characters (or create one of your own) to explore, interact with friends and foes through interesting dialogue options, and engage in tactical turn-based combat encounters.  Whether you build your own character or play through the story of one of the six Origin characters, you'll be able to fully customize your character by choosing skills, assigning attributes, and picking talents that all synergize to make interesting and unique builds that change your options for interacting with the environment, with NPCs, and in combat.  As you play, you'll recruit the aid of up to three other characters (chosen either from the remaining available Origin characters or hired from a mercenary captain), but be warned; while choosing to travel with fellow Origin characters will open up new and interesting storylines to explore, your goals will sometimes be at odds. Like your main character, you'll also be able to customize your companions, creating a party that can stand up to the challenges that await you.   Alternatively, play with up to three additional players, and explore Rivellon together in jolly cooperation.  Although DOS2 is not procedurally-generated, and encounters are placed and not random, the choices you make and actions you take have long-term consequences that can dramatically alter your play experience, but in a way that feels surprisingly natural - even intended!  DOS2 is complex, and what seems intimidating to start quickly becomes a deep and engaging experience that both challenges you mechanically and drives you on to experience more and more of the story it has to offer.

One of the best RPGs I have ever played, Divinity: Original Sin 2 truly is a work of art. From character creation to waking up in the prologue, the player will experience a familiar and welcoming feeling similar to creating a character for a tabletop RPG. This is pen-and-paper put into video game form in the truest sense.   Character creation is simple, and handled rather well. Though there is a slight lack in customization where one must choose face x through y and skin color x through y. Although the amount of races to choose is actually impressive. Alternatively, rather than playing a custom character, the player can experience the story from the perspective of one of the six, well-written, story characters. The races are vast and different in their own right with Human, Lizard, Dwarf, Elf, and Undead to choose from. They each face their own difficulties but all have unique boons or bonuses. Each class is just a combination of skills, a preset of gear and skills to start the player off with as customization and 'build-your-own' is heavily emphasized soon after the prologue. The player even has a choice to select a pseudo-background for their customized character of anything between a noble, mystic or barbarian with plenty more to be earned through the Roleplay elements.  Combat is very in-depth and ties in well with character customization. Skill trees and the skills, themselves, interract with the world differently in, sometimes, unexpected ways. The way combat feels is amazing, satisfying as it is turn-based combat done well. Abilities and spells, positioning, and the wide range of items make it one of the best features in this game, though one that is difficult to master. Spells can set the ground ablaze, clouds of poison can be created, and a combination of thing A and thing B can create explosions, electrified hallways, and giant spiders made of bone. Feedback, something important for combat, feels good. Powerful spells feel powerful and two-handed weapons feel weighty and hit hard. An overall enjoyable experience.  For those less combat-savvy, there is always the option to talk yourself out of a situation. The Rp elements are some of the finest done that I have seen in recent years. Skyrim has nothing on this. Each conversation and attempt at persuasion can change the experience of playing through the game. Accidentally anger a skeleton? Talk her to death- Yes, that was a thing that happened. Got caught stealing? Convince them otherwise! Need help solving a theft? Talk to a rat! The conversations and interractions with NPCs around the world are some of the best I've ever seen. From sad tales of a family lost to the hilarity of a cow attempting to tell your future. Or, simply murder them all if you can. There is freedom here that is just waiting to be explored.  On top of all of this, however, is the fact that this game has a co-operative feature of up to four players. Each player can choose to create a customized character or take the role of one of the story characters. While it is set up for an enjoyable single-player game, the ability to enjoy the full game with friends or family is also very welcome. The party is able to split up completely and roam the world if desired. There are also ways to troll your friends by Dying poison red, and giving it to them as a gift. Or, of course, you can all become Heroes.  The storytelling in this game is deep and rich as is player choice and freedom. The combat system is well thought out and satisfying. Even the character creation, simple as it is, gives the player more freedom than in most games to change almost everything stat-wise. It is easy to see that this game is made with love, and the developers have shown it clearly enough through this game that I regret not being able to support it on kickstarter. I cannot recommend this game enough. It is a gem and a must-have, even if you are not a fan of turn-based strategy games. This is, first and foremost, an RPG. If you have ever played D&D, Pathfinder, or any other table-top game then Divinity: Original Sin 2 is for you.

tl;dr:  Divinity OS2 is one of the best RPG's and one of the best Co-Op games out right now, and quite possibly the best game I have played in years.  A friend of mine got me this game as a Christmas gift, and I have not been able to put it down since. I enjoyed Divinity OS1 before, but this game manages to outdo it in most aspects still.   The story is amazing. It truly makes you feel like every small decision you make matters, and changes both the course of the game, the way your characters personality forms and how they interact with party members and the world in general(and obviously how they react to you as well).   Most if not all dialogue is fully voiced by great voice actors(including the narrator), the sound track is atmospheric and immerses you straight into the fantasy world, and the graphics and world design are gorgeous.   When I played the OS1 for the first time the slow-paced combat kind of turned me off at first (I thought it was quite hard to survive, and kind of confusing), but once I got more into it I grew to like it, and with Divinity OS2 all my doubts about the turn based combat have vanished. It is a lot of fun to plan out your next moves with your friend. The game wants you to be creative and tactical in combat, so you better not try to run head first into every fight, or else you will probably end up dying many times.Rather you will often use the environment to your advantage( which reacts to pretty much anything you do ) applying status effects, luring enemies away to overwhelm them in numbers and combining elements with your party members to cause havoc.   The companions have rich stories, are fully voiced and quite interesting (I had a hard time picking a follower because they're all quite cool).   That's pretty much all there is to say: if you like (Old-School) RPG's and don't mind the slower paced more tactical combat system, this is probably the best game out there right now.

Narrative: DOS 2 has a true fantasy story. It is one steeped in mystery and pushes the boundaries of creativity.  Each character has a unique subplot completely entangled with the main story. The side quests tie in with the games central themes and main narrative very well. Accordingly, they dont seem out of place or tacked on but are very believeable in the world crafted by larian studios. Music: The music works. It sets the tone quite nicely for the various parts of the world. It goes from epic to playful to somber to tragic in parallel with the envirement or scenario. Gameplay: The gameplay is very strategic with nuanced application. You must defeat intelligent and powerful Antagonists. Your set of abilities can be used envirementaly and you must keep your wits about you for the entirety of the game for both battle and exploration.  Characters: the ensemble cast of main characters each have their own ambitions, dreams, and philosophy. They are not just along for the ride. If you dont want to play as one of them you can create a character whose complexity and depth extends as far as yourself. Most if not all of the NPCs have believable ambitions and reasons for either deterring you or assisting you. there are many factions of npcs and 2/3 of them will seek your destruction depending on your choice so replayability is permitted. I have finished this game once and this is a reflection of that experience.  Since this is truly a great game, I wish everyone to play through and experience its wonders, for that is why I recommend the exploration mode for anyone that is turned off by the difficulty, so they can focus on exploration. I say that because the world and its characters are a spectacle to behold. This is the purest Role Playing Game i have played and I look forward to the future of its developer, Larian Studios.

Highly Recommended 5/5  Myself as a fan of D&D, coming from games like Baldur's Gate I & II: Shadows of Amn, Throne of Bhaal and Enhanced Edtion, IsewindDale, Pillars of Eternity, Neverwinter and many other titles this game was exceptionally good and a breath of fresh air, it is both Dynamic and Immersive, the story is deep, thrilling and intriguing, the characters are full of life and awe, even the side quests are interesting, funny, scary and powerful, the artwork and graphics are beautiful, the music is immersive, dramatic and very appropriate. The game also has a powerful way of making you think and leaves you baffled with the simplest of tasks sometimes and it's amazing how well it works as a whole.  The combat & environments are amazing and take the best of all my past D&D experiences to new levels and excels in ways other games fall short, having the ability to try any skill tree, wear any armour, use any weapon and off hand is amazing and other games i suppose just do not see the power of the possibilities it all offers, giving players the option to be and play exactly how they want to, also giving groups far more  utility and a much better role-play experience. The combat and AI combinations are amazing and synergize so well it can lead to very intense immersive battles that require good communication and well planned tactical combinations between groups to succeed.  To make things better they have incorporated the D&D experience through Game Master Mode allowing players to create their own story and encounters and battles with their own take on the D&D game similar to Tabletop Simulator but of course with a much better gameplay experience, taking things further a full workshop allowing the community to develop their own content including classes, weapons, spells, maps and much more, anything they want to create, they can.  All that together makes this game, in my opinion, the best D&D Coop/Multiplayer style Fantasy RPG of the past 10 years, I cannot find a single fault for this game I have enjoyed it immensely and its only gotten better since playing with groups and developing content for it. This review is somewhat limited as I have yet to fully complete the story, nor tried the dnd mode, yet I have a good idea of everything the game has to offer.   I think Larian have done a fantastic job in creating a grounded, well-rounded, and enthralling RPG. The narrative is imagnitive and captivating. Characters and npcs are unique and interesting, with good voice acting they really feel like individuals who each have their own personalilty, some could respond well to charm, others might threaten to kill you. Combat is challenging, fluid, and forces you to stay alert, using your head to figure out the best action to take. The visuals are gorgeous for the type of game it is and help to preserve the verisimiltude of the world.   One thing I would note is that the game is designed to be challenging by nature and is sometimes very slow and frustating, so if you lack patience and prefer only action, it might not be the game for you. For those of us who grew up playing Final Fantasy or other turn-based games, it is a very refreshing reminder of how fun these games can be if done right, especially with the unique twists this title adds. I would fully recommend the game, to the stage I am even using it for a college project where my task is to create an informative video, similar to ones seen by Mark Brown.

Divinity Original Sin 2 is by far the best RPG game that I've played this year.  The story is fantastic and changes based on the choices you make, the combat is interesting, and the game is fairly challenging. While in character creation, you are prompted to pick a pre-made origin character or to create your own. I highly recommend using an origin character as all of their dialog is voiced and they have their own unique twist to the overall story. As for the combat, there are almost always ways to interact with your surroundings during a fight whether it be terrain to climb, barrels of oil to burn, or even puddles of water that can be frozen. The combat also gets much harder as you increase the difficulty and really forces you to use your surroundings to your advantage. The only downside to this is that if you're running a cheesy build ranger and rogue each with the lone wolf trait, you can make quick work of almost any enemy from the early-mid-game and on. My biggest gripe about Divinity Original Sin 2 is that things are added automatically to your hot bar as you pick them up or learn a skill. I personally spent 71 hours on my first play through and did quite a few of the side-quests. If you actually read the items that you pick up and do more of the side quests, you could easily get 100+ hours out of one play through. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's into RPG games, especially those with turn-based combat.

At the cusp of completion.   I think this game has some major drawbacks. One being the difficulty spikes. I am referring always to classic mode for I have not tried any higher. You are doing well, almost a little too easy but nothing rediculous, and then BAM. You are fighting a group that kicks your‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•so hard your teeth hurt. You reload and adapt and thats fun. But sometimes there is a fight that is just plain unfair.(Not much of a spoiler) There is a boss called Eternal Aetera. This is without a doubt the most rediculously hardest fight in the game so far and I bet the harder than the final. She basicly swamps your team by suprise with a sudden group of phantom wolves. She starts the fight and summons 2 more right on top of you and they attack first. In two or three hits they kill someone or leave them critical. Then she will do several attacks in one turn one of them being a group killer: Hail strike. She has a huge amount of armor and magic armor, and she can keep summoning wolves once killed. I have tried every damn strategy there is. I tried rushing, kiting, charming, status effects. I even tried breaking the dialogue to cheese behind the fight with the pyramids. I must be missing something. I had to lower the difficulty just to beat her. A few fights are this way so I think thats a draw back. I love difficulty and challange but unfairness I cant handle.  Another draw back is the source points. I dont think the magic spells should use up these source points. I think the source skills should because regaining your source is kind of rare. You spend a lot of cash getting these awesome spells you level  and put points in for but you need the damn source to use it.   Another thing I dont like is the limited of AP points. It just feels like it limits the strategy and you do the same battle over and over. Turn 1 you teleport or travel to them. Turn 2 you use your strongest attacks. But with that said it still is very very good and fun. You still get a good dose of strategy too.  One thing I really hate about this game is the cryptic quests. Nothing holds your hand and thats a good thing. But the problem isnt doing the quest, its the completion. The problem I am finding is that so many quests seem to intermingle with eachother that actually turning them in is a god damn mystery. First playthrough on the first chapter: I have done about all the quests I could, but, I didnt know how the hell to turn them in so they left me unrewarded when completing the chapter. I dont know maybe I was just too impatient or not reading carefully. But there are so many cryptic steps to these quests that its overwhelming and annoying.  It's too precise, you must kind of be linear, but there are many ways to go about it. Thats the fun part. But trying to actually turn them in and deciphering which quest is actually what for each pertaining method is a huge pain in the‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•  Oh and there's bugs (current state)  I love the game and highly recomend it. I dont think it's better than the first one. Theres a ton of dialogue with a good portion of it worthless. It's pretty slow. But the game is very long and it's got good graphics, good music, good story, good level up system and good combat system. UI could be better. Cluttery inventory is unavoidable in this game.  If you like the first game you will like this one. The modding community looks really good. But I think the first game is better. Well worth the price.

This game has filled the void in my body that great games like Geneforge have left in their wake. What makes this game so good? (+ is a Positive, - is a Negative)  +The combat is fun.  +The animations are fluid and easy on the eyes. +I can stab my allies and friends and nobody cares. +I can kill my allies and friends and nobody cares. +I can pillage the corpses of my allies and friends and NOBODY CARES. Except my friends. If you didn't want to die, you should have given me the ring! IT GAVE 2 WIT POINTS! YOU DIDN'T NEED IT! +You can customize your character to a decent degree for an alpha that only sports around 30% of the game's content. +You can turn your tank into the game's scariest kamikaze by lining up oil barrels, wearing a cursed ring and soul shackling yourself to the boss for some hilarious burst damage that leaves crippled enemies floundering around in necrofire. -There isn't enough game to keep me satisfied yet. It has about 2-3 hours of content on Explorer. Ignore this mode ENTIRELY. It makes the game too easy and you end up oneshotting most units. Classic is the right difficulty for beginners in my humble opinion. Even with a party of just 2-3 characters, Classic is entirely doable.  (Advice)  Quickly stat Thievery and aquire Cloak and Dagger for your Thief/Assassin. A good thief can steal tomes from vendors that would otherwise cost over 250 gold for free. Cloak and Dagger is simply the most game-changing move Thieves/Assassins can get. This move is beyond invaluable for a mere 1 AP cost. Self Teleport on a short cooldown that clears away nearby ground effects on use, potentially saving allies nearby you when you teleport away, AND allows you to get to unreachable areas, teleport to those pesky backliners and quickly put you in the position to stun and wreak havoc on the enemy backline. Combined with Teleportation, this gives your Thief/Assassin a crazy amount of control over the battlefield.  Mages should aquire Fossil Strike and some form of AoE fire spell as soon as they can. Having a built in oil barrel makes blocking areas off and burning difficult enemies down quickly so much easier. It also gives you an immense amount of control over the battlefiel with a targetable slow field.  First Aid. This cannot be stressed enough how amazing this Huntsman heal is. It removes every debuff in the game but Cursed and Frozen AND heals a set 30% of hp, making it scale without any of your stat points being tosssed into water magic. It also applies rested.  Necromancers. You want one. Especially if they choose Geomancy as a secondary magical build. The amount of debuffs, self healing and battlefield control they bring is crazy. Blood Rain into Contamination makes the entire battlefield into a poison bog. Add some fire and watch the NPCs panic. Pick Zombie and you will be insanely hard to kill outside of a burst.  (Feedback) I would love to be able to change the instruments in-game AND for each member of the party AND enemies. Being able to do this would be awesome. Enemies could be a more somber or erratic instrument, while my controlled characters would be more vibrant to let me know when it was my turn more clearly. Just a thought~

Fantastic strategy RPG that doubles as a platform for online D&D.  Pros: -80 to 100 hour campaign -Massive replay value -Fun and creative turn-based strategy combat -Completely free-form leveling system -After the beginning area you can respec all your characters for free forever -Every line of dialogue is voice-acted, complete with an amazing narrator -Comes bundled with a complete creation kit you can use to make mods, maps, and campaigns -Easy to use co-op, plus a GM mode. -You can kill anyone you want. -No forced morality system. -Quests are very creative and usually have different and interesting outcomes.  Cons: -Tactician mode (hard difficulty) requires you to cheese most fights -Usable items you pick up will automatically be placed on your hotbar, cluttering it unless you manually disable that option -Some quests can be bugged if you accidentally do things before the game expected you to. It's never game breaking, but it can be annoying having unfinished quests cluttering your log. -Ambient voice acting gets very annoying, especially if you are at a vendor sorting out your items to sell and you have to hear the same line from nearby NPC's over and over. -Sometimes it's hard to select specific targets if there's a lot of things near eachother, and the slightest movement of your mouse can accidently change your target just as you cast your ability.   All in all, one of the best RPG's to come out in a long time and I highly recommend it.

At first I was hesitant at getting this. It looks great, and like a lot of fun, but maybe not worth the price. I thought maybe I'd pick up the game on a sale or something.  But I'm very glad I got it.  The story is very rich and there's so many ways to play. I'm excited for my second and third play throughs.   You can steal from anybody, kill anyone, befriend NPCs, talk to your followers if you choose to have them, and each story is different from character creation. Each race is treated differently, you have different dialogue options if you're an Outlaw, or Scholar, or even if you play a smart Wizard, you can persuade people with your smarts, or intimidate people with your strength.   The combat is very fun, and comboing spells and attacks is awesome.  Classes aren't really set in stone either. If you're a Fighter but decide you want to shock people, or grow some wings, you can very much do so.   And the GM mode is amazing.   As a Game Master for D&D games, I've always wanted a game to play it in, to immerse the players, and let them explore with out having to explain every small detail. And this game does it very well. You can create custom items, NPCs (even down to what hat they wear), allies, and customize the pre set maps the game gives you. I would honestly buy a DLC that includes more maps. But there are plently right now, I'm just afraid that through multiple play throughs we'll all think "Oh, this map again."  This game is a masterpiece, but it's not perfect.  The combat is very hard, even on the easiest difficulty it sometimes feels like I need to kill a couple NPCs who don't deserve it so I can level up and continue the story. And sometimes this makes the game feel linear. I don't know if I'm missing something, or I chose bad classes for my party, but either way that's a big down side for me.  That being said, at the time of posting this review I'm 71 hours in, and I havent even completed my first play through, which is a good thing. I'm taking my time, exploring the world, talking to every NPC and living the world.  UPDATE (very minor spoilers):  I finished the game, and I have to say while the ending was good, it was very buggy. I was unable to use res scrolls, enemies would teleport everywhere, and some other minor things.  Arx also felt very bland for what it could have been. Driftwood and all of Reaper's Coast felt huge, and there was so much story there, but Arx... You were there for one thing, and that was to beat the game. I tried to find more to do there, I tried to find side quests, just anything, but there was nothing. Maybe I missed stuff, maybe I didn't. Either way I feel the game no longer deserves my original score of 8.5/10.  8/10

I'm surprised that I haven't written a review of this game since I first started playing it. This game from my own perspective offers quite a bit.   Story: Every single quest has multiple ways of being approached and there is no system of good or evil. You could be doing good thing for terrible people or bad things for noble causes. You could just be pure evil for the sake of being a jerk, and you could make every kindhearted decision out there. There is no wrong choice and anytime you block a certain path due to a choice you made, there is always another option to be explored.  For the amount of choices that this game gives you in terms of social and story progression, it's worth a full price buy in that alone.  Gameplay: Honestly, there is no such thing as a game without bugs. For all the bugs that this game has, it has a devoted team of developers to constantly patch and repair whatever the community reports to them. For every feature the community asks of the devs, they take everything into careful consideration. The combat mechanics are simple and complex at the same time. Every attack has it's own property, physical or magic. Physical damage has no sub categories while magic damage splits into, fire, water, earth, poison and wind. What makes the magical damage so complex is how the elements interact with each other and the environment to make the gameplay more immersive.   Unfortunately, if you want to play the game for pure optimization and not immersion, most people go into pure physical damage builds to ignore the majority of elemental immunities that certain enemies might have in the game.  To sum it up, the game is great and worth more than it sells for.

This game does not hold your hand. Remiscent of older AD&D CRPG's. You control a small 4-player party Baldur's Gate-style around a big world map. Each character in your party has unique skills and abilities. Learn them, train them, master them. You can only have four (4) characters in your party so choose wisely.  Expect brutally and sometimes unfair dice-roll turn-based combat. As for questing, again, don't expect any hand-holding, you either figure things out on your own or you look up a walkthrough. Your quest journal is light on hints as well. They DO give hints but they only give you a nudge in the right direction. NPC conversations contain more detailed hints so you have to really pay attention to what they're saying. Oh and important NPC's CAN die and mess up your progress and you will either have to find another way to complete a quest or reload a previous save. Or just live with the death of that NPC and move on. And speaking of saving, this is a game where you either save-scum or you live with the consequences of your choices.  I can recommend this to hardcore CRPG players who are looking for fun and a challenge. I can't recommend it for RPG-lite players who are used to thinbgs like Oblivion or Skyrim.  My overall assesment of this game is: "Brutally challenging and interesting without being difficult for difficluty's sake like Dark Souls"

I just finished my first playthrough last night. Let's get this out of the way: this game is something special. It improves on almost every gripe I had with the original (mainly just story and pacing) and just knocks it out of the park. This is a new gold standard for what a modern RPG should be.    What's Good The companions are memorable, well-written, and have realistic motivations that make negotiating their place in your party really engaging as you strive for the end-goal of the game. (I mean, it makes sense, you can play them as the main character if you wish!)  Combat rewards creativity, exploration, and experimentation without ever feeling like it's unfair towards the player--some fights are tough as nails, but they're just puzzles that you've been given an entire toolbox to solve. It's incredible just how many viable strategies you can employ to build a party and the myriad tactical decisions you can make in combat with those interactions.  Some of the quests and puzzles are pretty inspired--I'm a DM for tabletop group and I can appreciate how hard it is to make a puzzle that's challenging and feels organic to its context while delivering on fun. So hard to do, and 90% of the quests and puzzles in D:OS2 deliver. The quests often have multiple paths to resolution, which can be incredibly satisfying.    (Minor) Gripes I only encountered a few bugs over the course of my game and none of them were show-stopping. (A few dialogue options that didn't make sense because of my choices; quicksave reload breaking a script in combat and requiring rollback; a few quests not updating / reflecting change after I made major progress in them.) The lion's share of these happened in the last two major areas of the game--which I totally understand given the sheer scope of the game.   Long story short: there hasn't been an RPG this rich in a long time. It's worth every penny of the price tag.

review: Being the child of both rpg and turn-based strategy games, Divinity: Original Sins II delivers the best the two genres have to offer.  It can be played alone or with friends comfortably.  It doesn't feel like you [i\have[/i] to play it one way or the other.  In fact, DOSII can be almost defined by its range of options.  From cosmetics to functionality, Larian has done a wonderful job of creating a game that allows the player to experience a unique story every time.

Let me start off by saying that I don't normally write reviews for games unless they are exceptional. This game lies in one of the few exceptions where I have to.  I bought this game when it first released but I didn't have a good computer to actually fully enjoy it. Fast forward to recently when I did buy one and I fully spent the time to play this game. At first, it seemed difficult for me as I never played the first Divinity and tried to learn my way around the game. Not that long after, I got familiar with the story and the lore. From someone who doesn't enjoy care about the plot of most RPG's or MMORPG's, this game somehow brought the story forward for me to be interested in. I personally built an attatchment to my character and my companions as we continued on this adventure through Divinity. It was an amazing experience and that was when I knew what a gem this game was.  Some of the elements that I found compelling about this game was:   The voice acting - The many actors who portrayed the characters in this game did not disappoint. At times, I was just shocked at the amount of emotion and passion placed into each line of dialogue. My personal favorite was the voice actor for Lohse, whom I felt went above and beyond what some would just skim past. Also a big round of applause to those actors who put themselves out there to voice each animal or dungeon rat that was available throughout the game.   The combat - The understanding of many tactical aspects of each combat situation made it harrowing for me, in a fun sort of way. It was fun to experiment different strategies to clear a particular room of enemies or be faced with decisions that could affect whether or not my party makes it out of combat alive. The high-ground/low-ground system made it particularly mindful to pay attention to your surroundings while the natural elemental occurences (such as oil, poison, fire, etc,) keep you on your toes.   The storytelling - As stated in the above paragraph, the story is phenomenal. I found myself always wondering what would happen next and how my actions would affect the world down the line. It was truly one of the times where I found myself relating to my character, as if I were them rather than me controlling them. I truly loved the way the world was set up and how mostly everything had some role to play either in the narrative of the story or just to contribute to the feel of the world.   The world - Speaking of the feel of the world, everything was how it should be to establish a world that felt dynamic and alive. NPC's truly made their experiences feel real with some having problems that seemed normal and how they were portrayed. I sometimes imagined the theoretical lives of these NPC's and treated them as if they were real people with their own past experiences. When a game can make you engrossed into their world, you know it is good.   Music - The music was excellent at many areas and shifts according to the environment that you were placed in. Dungeons or naturally spooky areas had a feeling of dread but the suspensful and harrowing music helped contribute to the feel of this.  The music that played during the ending fight actually had me tearing up as even though it was something that I heard so many times, knowing that this was final area made it truly special and evoked a lot of memories and emotions of the overall adventure   Overall, I had just finished my first campaign and am planning on finishing more as to learn more about the companions that I did not choose at first and to see all the possible routes that I can go through before I eventually clear up the game. The game's amazing and a big thanks for Larian Studios for putting out such a masterpiece. I can't wait for the Definitive Edition to come out but until then, there are many mods and more to keep you continuously entertained. 10/10

A vast improvement compared to the first (DOS:EE) installment of the modern series.  Pros: - In-depth turn based combat system - Beautiful visuals, both in and out of combat - Deep lore in relation to the world that you explore and the characters that inhabit it - Multiple ways to go about accomplishing a central objective - Origin characters with a rich backstory exist along custom player-made characters - Replayability is present for 2 or 3 playthroughs in total as long as you don't get bored of the main story - Infinite respeccing options allowing you to completely change each of your characters on the fly with no penalty     whatsoever - Magnificent soundtrack and audio work  Cons: - Although an improvement compared to DOS:EE, the game at times is still fairly unintuitive (looking at you, Arx) - Some minor bugs pose an equally minor annoyance (some characters keep infinitely looping dialogue, audio bugs) - Very lackluster ending - Unable to go back to previous areas after having moved on to the next act / area - Unable to free roam and tie off any loose ends after completeing the game    Conclusion:DOS:2 is a very fun game that I find was worth the money that I've invested into it. I bought it the moment it came out of early access and have sunk a total of 64 hours into it. You can definitely sink more time into this (around 75 or 80 hours total maybe) if you go around and finish every side quest and origin character questline. As I've already mentioned it's a shame that we can't go back and freeroam all of the areas once we finish the game. This was an issue in DOS:EE as well and it's sad to see that the same problem persists here. Either way I must give credit to Larian for a near flawless second installment. If you're on the fence about buying this game I would advise you to wait for the winter sale and see if it drops in price, and if it doesn't, then buy it anyway. The price will not change from $45.

RPG of the decade.  - This is higher than tripple A, this game will ruin every other RPG for years perhaps even a decade  - Fantastic story, so much choice - Incedible combat, huge amount of depth - Graphics are great - Sound track is perfect - Has an really good strangly cheery grim humour - Love all the hidden secrets and storylines - Storyline tag system has alot of fun suprises - Alot of replayablity - Voice acting is extremely well done

This is overall a really good game, I have played lots of RPG's and this is one of those that stays in your memory.   PROS:  - Excellent artwork - Amazing soundtrack and voice acting - Lots of details - Well written dialogues - Companions are useful and interesting  CONS:  - Last act looks a bit too rushed - Minor bugs, probably fixed by now - Crafting feels unfinished in some recipes but it is pretty extense  FULL REVIEW:  It has amazing artwork and an outstanding amount of details that you just can't overlook.   The dialogue is another thing that is really well written, it contains easter eggs, fun jokes and serious or sensitive  lines that will hit you, that goes hand in hand with the voice acting and sound track.  The story stays consistent and it is well made, no matter your choices you won't see a decrease in quality  (I had several saves).  As a bad point I can say the last act looks and feels a bit rushed. Also I have encountered several tiny bugs, but they didn't really trouble me while playing.  The crafting part to me looks lacking, I had several things that couldn't find on any wiki, reddit or similar how to use them or they were kind of useless.  I was not really fond of the armor design (some looked too huge, or they had outstanding stats and looked like plain clothes), or the fact that you have dyes but cannot change the armour color in any way, but maybe that's planned (?).   So my final review is really positive over all of the cons I found, I think It's still worth playing 100%.

I am unsure where to begin with Divinity 2 at this point. This game has been and still is an amazing journey you can take on alone or with your friends.  I am hardly convinced with most of the games I play but Divinity has me on a collar. I cannot look away or stop playing it. I already am at 50H and haven't even experienced the whole singleplayer campaign.   The fact that you can talk with every single NPC, including animals (if you got the "Pet Pal" Talent early on), that you can explore every corner, find new clues and ways to secret caves or find treasure chests. All those aspects are a big yes for me to recommend Divinity2.   But was that all? Hell no. I haven't even covered 20 percent of what this game is capable of yet! I really enjoy freedom. I want to choose what to do, how to do it and, that should I take the wrong path in a conversation, have to deal with the backfire. Each race reacts differently towards NPC's (as do they. A lot of racism going on in this game) while adding more tags to your character such as "Barbarian""Scholar""Outlaw""Mystic""Soldier""Jester" and "Noble" gives you the options to get more information out of them or successfully persuing them after they saw you stealing. (I have to add this since it caused me great pain. Do NOT click on a trader while they are walking by. I accidentally stole a bottle of wine instead of talking to the trader and hell on earth broke out. Never steal wine guys. NEVER.)   Each races armor looks different depending on what armor you give them. The same helmet looks differently for each race which means just getting out all the armor sets probably took ages and I am glad they put so much detail and work in this game. You can see the development teams heart in it. A great game that is meant to be so much more.  It is sometimes hard to keep the playerbase or even raise those numbers shouldn't there be options to replay the game after "finishing". Divinity did everything right. I am putting the word "finish" like this simply because of the fact that you will be having a hard time completing this game 100% if not impossible. So many options depending on what you chose while creating your character, while talking, whom you talk too and how. So many options to go, so much to explore, so many ways you can complete a single quest will make it hard for you to not get lost in this wonderful world <3  And I haven't even started to talk about the Game Master aspect. So far I have't been able to look at them simply because of the fact that the moment I have freetime I play the campaign.... I might be addicted at this point.  The option to create your own campaign, invite your friends or upload your work on Divnity's Steam Workshop will give you a never ending adventure.  My friendgroup started to use Divinity as DnD platform. Our GM creates the world and through Divinity you don't need to only imagine it, you can actually see and play your personal adventure.  Since the game is turn based you have everything a little RP heart needs to be happy.   In short: If you enjoy exploring, a never ending adventure and have a great time with your friends while playing Divnity's campaign, a downloaded one from the workshop or your own this is the game for you to play.  A long awaited tripple A game that has been worth all the wait. Hands up for an amazing adventure I will be enjoying for a long time!

At the cusp of completion.   I think this game has some major drawbacks. One being the difficulty spikes. I am referring always to classic mode for I have not tried any higher. You are doing well, almost a little too easy but nothing rediculous, and then BAM. You are fighting a group that kicks your‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•so hard your teeth hurt. You reload and adapt and thats fun. But sometimes there is a fight that is just plain unfair.(Not much of a spoiler) There is a boss called Eternal Aetera. This is without a doubt the most rediculously hardest fight in the game so far and I bet the harder than the final. She basicly swamps your team by suprise with a sudden group of phantom wolves. She starts the fight and summons 2 more right on top of you and they attack first. In two or three hits they kill someone or leave them critical. Then she will do several attacks in one turn one of them being a group killer: Hail strike. She has a huge amount of armor and magic armor, and she can keep summoning wolves once killed. I have tried every damn strategy there is. I tried rushing, kiting, charming, status effects. I even tried breaking the dialogue to cheese behind the fight with the pyramids. I must be missing something. I had to lower the difficulty just to beat her. A few fights are this way so I think thats a draw back. I love difficulty and challange but unfairness I cant handle.  Another draw back is the source points. I dont think the magic spells should use up these source points. I think the source skills should because regaining your source is kind of rare. You spend a lot of cash getting these awesome spells you level  and put points in for but you need the damn source to use it.   Another thing I dont like is the limited of AP points. It just feels like it limits the strategy and you do the same battle over and over. Turn 1 you teleport or travel to them. Turn 2 you use your strongest attacks. But with that said it still is very very good and fun. You still get a good dose of strategy too.  One thing I really hate about this game is the cryptic quests. Nothing holds your hand and thats a good thing. But the problem isnt doing the quest, its the completion. The problem I am finding is that so many quests seem to intermingle with eachother that actually turning them in is a god damn mystery. First playthrough on the first chapter: I have done about all the quests I could, but, I didnt know how the hell to turn them in so they left me unrewarded when completing the chapter. I dont know maybe I was just too impatient or not reading carefully. But there are so many cryptic steps to these quests that its overwhelming and annoying.  It's too precise, you must kind of be linear, but there are many ways to go about it. Thats the fun part. But trying to actually turn them in and deciphering which quest is actually what for each pertaining method is a huge pain in the‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•  Oh and there's bugs (current state)  I love the game and highly recomend it. I dont think it's better than the first one. Theres a ton of dialogue with a good portion of it worthless. It's pretty slow. But the game is very long and it's got good graphics, good music, good story, good level up system and good combat system. UI could be better. Cluttery inventory is unavoidable in this game.  If you like the first game you will like this one. The modding community looks really good. But I think the first game is better. Well worth the price.

Do you like strategic roleplaying games like Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum, Fallout 1 & 2, Dragon Age (the first one), or XCOM 2?  Well, you're going to love this.  This game combines the roleplaying depth of Dungeons & Dragons with a strategic feeling similar to XCom 2. Practically speaking, what this means is that outside of combat, you can do damn well near anything you can think of. In combat, you can do the same. If you want to break into that house, kill that lady, steal that gold, and escape into the night, you can. If you want to be the daring hero, and save shackled stowaways on a sinking ship, you can. This game gives you the freedom to truly explore the "RP" factor of Roleplaying games. Very few games these days can hold a candle to the amount of roleplaying this game encourages.   I think a number of groups of Dungeons and Dragons players will likely abandon tradtional and even virtual play, and just move their games over to Divinity: Original Sin 2. It's easy to learn, hard to master - not unlike D&D - and it's also aesthetically gorgeous in both music and graphics. Can't recommend this game enough. Buy it.

I found the story as well as the voice acting in certain parts cheesy. I didn't play any previous games, so I might not be fit to judge the story but that's the impression I got. It didn't really bother me though, maybe they were going for the old school clich√© RPG story.   The funnest part of the game is the countless ways you can tackle quests or objectives. I'm not a big fan of turn-based combat but the one in DOS2 really did it for me. It's challenging and the way you and enemies can interact with the environment (for example wet ground) is really awesome and leads to alot of funny moments co-op.   Every side quest felt unique and it didn't feel like I was doing anything pointless.   The RPG elements are implemented amazingly well. I was impressed by how much your civil abilities, attributes, race as well as the backgrounds you chose at the start (Scholar, Jester, Noble..) of the game affect your dialogue options and ways you can do quests. The game doesn't tie you down when it comes to character builds and there are lots of interesting skills you can combine and play around with. The one thing I didn't like so much was the lack of armor variation for races other than humans, they all look kind of the same to me.  I played through the whole game in co-op which made the experience much more enjoyable. If you can find a friend who's willing to play with you from beginning to end it's tons of fun. I also have a save where I started a playthrough with an NPC companion (Fane). I was pleasantly surprised by how much depth NPC companions have. They have their very own storyline that which you completely miss out on if you don't make them join your party.  I recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a decent RPG, even people who prefer action RPGs.

Have you ever asked yourself what would happen if they could make D&D into an actual videogame? Well look no further! I've been on the fence about buying this game for a while, I finally picked up this game on sale and I'm so far 17 hours into playing this game. All I can say is this may be the greatest RPG I have ever played. Does it have the greatest graphics? No. It is mouse click controls as opposed to WASD. This game more than makes up for all of that with the richness of it's story and lore. In additition the character customization as well as the sheer amount of decisions you can make to complete a quest are vast and astounding. For a game that is not that graphics intense it is still 26 GB and you can see where all that memory goes. You can talk to every single NPC and animal (if you have that skill) in this world and they all have a voice you can actually listen to. You can kill any NPC you want but keep in mind that everything has a consequence in this game. Combat is interesting and again, depending on what skills you have, can be approached in multiple ways depending on the challenge. You can be a ranger with wings, fly up to the high ground and have a tactical advantage. Have a battlemage, shock the most powerful foe, stun lock him while the rest of your party kills all the others. Be a rogue and give every enemy the suprise buttsecks.... everything is a possibility in this game. If you have looked at the game description and been intrigued but maybe not convinced to buy this game, don't even think about it just buy it. You will get your money's worth. This is a game I see myself replaying multiple times in the future.
