With that said, that aspect is still part of the game but to a lesser extent. They added new spells to target certain types of armor and overall, it just feels like I can break through the armor easier and be able to use my spells to their full effect. Caster will have lots of magical armor so you want to send in your dude with lots of physical attacks and lock him down.   I can't recommend this game enough. Well lets start off with a brief description of the game. You're a captive on a ship, a Sourceror, one of the most hated people across the land. Your foul magic attracts monstrosities known as the Voidwoken, nightmares from another dimension that seek to claim this world as their own. However, things quickly roll out of hand, and it ends with the ships destruction. Finding yourself on the prison island known as Fort Joy, you discover that you're no ordinary Sourceror; you have the potential to become a GOD. From there, the game plays out quite literally as YOU choose it, be it as a benevolent hero seeking to save the world or as a malicious villain who seeks to gain ultimate power. And, just maybe, you'll find an option that no one else expected, one that takes you through the Void itself... and finding power that scoffs at the Gods themselves.  As you can probably tell, there's a lot of choices to be made in Divinity 2 : Original Sin, and maybe you're thinking "Oh god, it's another one of these games that plays out as a visual novel instead of a rpg". Well if you are thinking that, shut the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up, strap in, and read up ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• because there's quite a bit more to the game than that.   Now, the best part about this game is it's combat system and character progression; there are few other games where I can actually feel the progression of my character and the impact it has on the world around me. For example, in my very first TRUE playthrough of the game, 100% it, I did it with just two characters, both of them basically assassins; it was hard at first of course, but by the end of the game I could clear a room of 12 heavily armored characters with 2 characters and taking no damage. It truly felt powerful, and is one of my favorite gaming playthroughs of all time. So I thought, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it, lets try a magical playthrough, might not be as fun as the first, but we'll get through it. Well. Lets just say a full elementalist party is quite a unique experience. The whole 4 person party felt powerful the entire game, and we destroyed everything in sight that we deemed "Unholy" or "Unclean". Felt ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing hilarious the entire way through, and I don't regret a moment of it. For my thrid play through, I went in with a full melee team, and got the exact same results, which has blown me out of the water and clear into the sky; the fact that no matter what kind of team you play you know you'll become a force to be reckoned with is fantastic, and lets you cook up some pretty kooky team compilations. If you don't believe me, go on youtube and look up some of the SOLO builds people can make; they play on the highest difficulty and can quite literally nuke entire areas with a single character. But I digress, that's a bit off topic, and not relevant to this review. So if you've ever felt let down by a characters power or capability, trust me, you won't feel that with this game.  Let's talk diversity for a quick second here. There are 4 main races in the world, the Dwarves, Humans, Elves, and Lizards. Each race has its own unique capabilities, and it's own racial traits, meaning that yes, while you can have a Lizard assassin, making it a human so it have bonus initiative (how soon it gets to move in combat) and extra critical chance (random extra damage) means you'll have an easier time. Or maybe you'll choose a lizard for your geomancer because you have the innate ability to breath fire, and ignite your oil based abilities. A dwarven Inquisitor stands ready to rush into your opponents because they have extra defenses against all forms of damage. And maybe your necromancer is an elf because elves can eat parts of their enemies to learn memories and skills they'd normally never obtain. No matter what it is, you'll find tons of combinations based off of race alone to make a unique and fun character. But is that where it stops? Nope, that's where we're just getting started. See, there is a unique twist you can put on a character; you can make them UNDEAD. Yes, that's right, a skeleton that walks and talks, and which offers other unique pros and cons. For example, an undead character will heal when poisoned, and take damage when healed normally. Skeletons can use their bony fingers as infinite use lockpicks. And most importantly, Skeletons don't have any nasty organs to inhale Deathfog, an uncommon terrain in the game which kills anything that breaths it, meaning that Undead are free to wander through it as they please. The only real downside is having to wear a headpiece at all times. (Which isn't even a downside, like, why would you decide to not wear an important piece of equipment?) But lets say you dislike making all of that troublsome character stuff, you just want to get in and have fun. Well, there are already a ton of premade characters with their own stories and quests to go on if you so choose! There's literally no way to go wrong with making a character in this game!  Hey, we almost missed the most important part of the game, the part where you become a god and stuff! Well friendo, that's what I saved for last because that‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•is called SPOILERS, and I know that some people dislike those. So let it be said now that if you don't want to read any spoilers WHATSOEVER, then you should skip the next paragraph. Cool? Cool.  So as your character progresses through the game, they will discover the ability to use Source to fuel abilities. These are their godly powers, and are only usable by player characters and certain other npcs. This includes the abilites; Bless : Buffs an ally and clears any and all curses that afflict them. Spirit Vision : Is actually free to cast, and lets you temporarily see into the spirit realm, where you can see parts of the past, and even talk with the dead to gain their wisdom. (Or even just to taunt an enemy who bugged you.) Devour : Not it's actual name, but I don't use it often enough to remember it. It's also free to cast. You basically target an enemy corpse (or even just directly target their ghost.) and devour their essence, regaining a source point. Doing this too many times however can mark you with the "Villain" tag, which is not what you want to have on you if you're roleplaying as a benevolent hero. Gate : Again, isn't the true spell name, but works the same as the D&D version, creating a permanent link to another location within range that anyone can go through at any time. It sounds kind of dumb at first, but it lets you pull off some pretty wacky stunts in the game, and I've taken it on every character I've made so far. There are of course tons of other abilities that can be fueled by source points, far too many to list them all here, as each class has a few "Ultimate" abilities that you need source to use. But if you're interested in learning more about these godlike powers, then just look up a class guide and check out their abilities to get an idea of what you can work with!  Alright, well I think that if you've read everything I've said so far, that you'll get the idea I'm trying to tell you. The game's fantastic, and fun to play, especially with friends. One of the best campaigns we had was one where the entire party split up and fought to become the ultimate character. So if you enjoy shennanigans like that, and you love the sound of this game, then take a go at it! I really think that you'll enjoy the hell out of it!

7.5/10  I played Divinity: Original Sin 2 with a group of friends as a Persuasive Lizard, focusing on Summoning and Geomancy. Though the boulders and oil that can be thrown with Geomancy are effective, I initially focused on it to serve as a healer for our Undead tank. Undead are healed by poison, so your party's usual healer can't help them out. However, Geomancy also gave me access to Fortify which I could use to restore physical armor, and Artillery Plant, which was my favorite thing in the game. Artillery plant is a summon that exists in the Geomancy tree, whose level is determined by your Summoning skill. In the game, your most powerful skills cost "source" to cast (sort of a special type of mana). By the end of the game, you will be able to possess three source points at a given time. Source is rare to come by during most of the game, and even towards the end it's not necessarily unlimited. Artillery plant costs a single source point to cast, but then it can cast an extremely powerful spell called "Acid Spores" every two turns, among other strong abilities. If your character were to cast "Acid Spores," instead of the summon, it would cost you two source points every time!  The type of discussion you see above is what makes Divinity: Original Sin 2 so exciting. How can you support the other characters in your party in combat, and what is the optimal way to use your source or action points? If a member of your party has the "Loremaster" ability, you can examine enemies to learn their abilities, talents, and resistances. If an enemy reduces and redirects damage dealt, you may want to attack his friends first. If he has the opportunist talent, you do not want to walk away from melee range as it grants him an attack. If he has a fire resistance of 150%, fire will heal him. You want to constantly take stock of enemy composition and the skills of your party.  If Divinity: Original Sin consisted of a more linear story with more combat encounters, and lasted about 2/3 of its current length, it would be a 10/10 game for me. However, as it stands, I have a few gripes.   Although I'm sure that many players appreciate the ability to complete quests in multiple ways, I just found it frustrating. Some of the solutions are obtuse, and require a lot of poring through documents. Some of the late game puzzles, like pulling levers in a certain order or playing the enormous "pipe dream" game, were just tedious. There are many many quests, and in a multiplayer party it just felt like I was always receiving experience from somewhere because someone in my party was progressing on one of the many many quests in my quest log. While I'm sure some might say that I should've played with a different group of people, there are so many quests with so many solutions that often we made quest progress by aimlessly walking around.   Another issue I had with the title is just how quickly my character advanced. Each character has a maximum of 40 in an attribute, a maximum of 10 in each skill or combat ability, and a maximum of 5 in each civil ability. Each character in our party maxed out at least one of these categories well before the end of the game. In addition, the highest tier of skills in the game become available at level 16, also well before the endgame. Though perhaps others are drawn primarily for the story, this severely hampered my enjoyment of the game. After learning all skills I was interested in, maxing my summoning and my persuasion, I just didn't have as much to look forward to.  I enjoyed most of my time with Divinity: Original Sin 2. The argument could be made that this type of game just isn't for me, but I enjoyed the combat so much that is was worth some of the other irritations.

Highly recommended to fans of rpg and turn based games. Do you need to play the first game or any Divinity title before this? Not at all ,you can learn more about the world as you play along. Play alone (like i do since friends didnt come with the game) or play coop which your friends can drop in and out anytime or get straight into the fight with the PVP Arena mode.    The good stuff:  -Interesting main/side story and meaningful quest (no more of that boring fetch or kill this mobs quest) -Play as 1 of the 6 origin character which have predefined backstory and unique events. -Or create your own and team up with those origin character. -Dynamic relationship system which your companion can either hate/like you or if you like become intimate with -Owh did i mention that you can play as an undead that ripped other people face to use as a mask? (both origin and custom character) -Your choice and action effect the story and the game (so dont think that people will not notice that apple you just stole) -Challenging combat which force you to use every trick up your sleeve (no more potion/scroll etc that you will probably never use till the end) -Do things your way.Be persuasive,do favors or even do the exact opposite of that favor or just kill the guy and loot him its up to you. -Fully voice acted and beautiful soundtrack that fits the theme of the world -Alot of other interesting stuff like crafting,surface effect etc that you can use to your advantage or be use againts you. -Explore the world and be rewarded for it or suffer for it (who knows,you could find a curse helmet that may contain an evil spirit inside it)    The bad and not so bad stuff:  -Bugs,this game is not totally free of them.I havent found any game breaking bugs yet but remember to keep saving every 15-30 min or so.F5 quicksave is your friend here dont relied on autosave to much.  -The combat difficulty can sometimes spike alot that it can be brutal to new players,i suggest starting the game on the easiest mode (Explorer mode) and get a good feel of the game first before jumping on the more harder one like Classic mode.  -The armor system seem to have alot of mix opinion among the community (Its was absent in the first game).What this system does is that you cant apply debuff like stun to the target unless you destroy their magical armor or physical armor depending on the debuff.The good thing  is that it also apply to your party meaning that your 250 physical armor warrior can just go in and cut down those archer at the back without the fear of being knocked down and your party dont have to be feared of being 1 shotted by some enemy mage AoE spells at the start of the fight.The bad  thing is that enemy usually have 2x or sometimes more armor than you,this forced the player to make a burst dmg character to quicky remove that armor which in turn  limiting the player to mix their classes without hurting the dmg potential the character can dish out per turn.   Overall the game get a solid 9/10 from me and 1 of the few game i dont mind paying more money.Unlike some of the game that we get now that doesnt fit the unreasonably high price tag (Looking at you *AAA games*)

TL;DR  7/10 score from my side.  Longer read  - It is a good RPG game. It follows good ways of approaching the genre. And it attempts to fix problems the first game had. - There are some things which still call for improvements. But it's probably not something which will make you hate the game.  Very long read  Awesome:  - Story. Well, this is as much as it states. Who doesn't want to become a divinity? And you decide which path do you take to get there. - Combat geometry. Altitude and different surfaces make it feel great and diverse. You really want to position yourself right. You really want to make use of surfaces or prevent enemies from doing it. And in most of the cases  - you can/ - Voice acting. They have every little dialog covered and I think at least 7-8 different voices, that's great - Game looks. It is about world and is applicable for those who have fairly good PCs. Speaks for itself.  Good - They improved the initiative problem. As any turn-based game, the turn order will make it a problem of stacking the speed/initiative/whatever serves the turn order boost. Here it's no more so much of an issue. - Many immunity talents are removed which is a good decision. It's just too much of a mandatory pick in the first game. - Not such huge power creep. Over the course ov the levels, like till 15-16, you don't feel the exponential numbers growth. So it makes it managable to plan the combat - Minor fixes like ranged weapon influencing bows AND crossbows. It may be not so impressive, but when combined - it leaves a good feeling  Not-so-good (what made it 7 out of 10)  - Cannibalist elves. I mean, yes, one can argue "you live with stereotypes" - and I can't deny it's partly so, but look - if you're taking a race which is invented long before you and make it into something that's completely opposing the perception of majority - it will get tricky. If they would not call these guts-devouring people elves I would have no questions. But it's a bit over the board  - Overall game characters design. Lucky me, I play male characters where appearance means not so much. But I would imagine a disappointment for those who plays female characters. I just wonder how they managed to create face presets which seem to compete each other in ugliness. Oh well - it's about personal tastes, sure - but still.  - Items and loot. It is just too... random. It's hard to find something appealing for your character - you will always have that redundant parameter you want to replace. And may be it's not a problem for those who play a lot, but for 10-15 hours of play it may be an issue  - They removed one of the best things I liked in the first game - the D&D-like saving throws. Instead there are these magic/physical armor concepts which just looks too... simplified and makes many magic abilities weak. Especially if the damage-dealers are physical-type (rangers, fighters)  Overall - I would recommend you this game. It is worth the full price. It has it's flaws, but it follows the best canons of an RPG-type game and it won't leave you disappointed. If you're not so much into customisation and aren't obsessed with the perfection of how your avatar looks - then the visuals of this game is one of the best you can find in the genre. If you're fine with simplification of the effects/counter-effects part of the combat - you'll like the new armor system. But in any case - if you like RPG - you'll like this game

This is a great game with some nearly game-breaking flaws. There were a decent amount of bugs in my playthrough. The combat is mind-numbingly slow. Perhaps it's because there are not that many regions/maps to play, perhaps it was because the slow combat effected the rest of the game so much. I really enjoyed the creative level design and the ability to go about things in a variety of ways, with only one playthrough under my belt I'm sure that I missed a lot of these extra details. There is no throwaway function in the game, which was a breath of fresh air. I expected spirit vision to be a one-and-done or very limited use mechanic but it comes into play all the time.   If they would fix the pace of the combat this game could be vastly improved, hopefully either the developer or modders will come up with a solution. I'd recommend waiting to buy it on sale, especially since the game will probably be in a better condition at that point anyways.

EDIT: Giving this a thumbs up now, not because larian changed anything, though they have fixed a couple of bugs, but because of the mods coming out for it. Larian laid the foundation and gave a great game but the modding community makes it better.    Good game,.   In my opinion the armor system makes the game tedius.  I don't believe it was well thought out.   The way armor works is that each mob has physical armor and magical armor, then they have their health.  No crowd control that deals with physical attributes will work on a mob unless the physical armor is 0.  The same goes for magical armor and crowd control for magical attributes.  Armor also keeps mobs from being hurt, so as long as they have any armor on they won't recieve damage.   For physical armor you destroy it by beating them with weapons and a select number of spells, (remember the effect of those spells won't do anything through) and to destroy magical armor you have to hit it with spells in order for magical effects or damage to be felt.  Once the armor is destroyed you can then damage their health and inflict status effects.  This may sound great but in the end it leads to tedius battles.  Wade in, hit the mob with swords as that is the easiest way to destroy the armor, then crowd control.  There is NO chance a status effect won't work once armor is gone.  The person or NPC is pretty much dead after that.    For me this just ruins the fun of what I have come to love and enjoy about D;OS, being able to expirement with different spells and effects to see how I can control the battlefield, (or be controlled.)  This also means that traps do almost nothing.  I just walk through them because they don't hurt.  Poison, who cares.  Electic field, ok, fire, sounds lovely to stroll through, as long as my armor is ok.  Outside of combat its easy to keep your armor up.  Everything else about the game is fine.  As for me though, I think I'm going to have to wait till a mod comes out that fixes the issues I've talked about which makes me sad since I spent over $150 in order to download and buy the game.  ($44 for game, $60 for data and another $60 when I need more data since I was having to use a tethered phone.)

Narrative: DOS 2 has a true fantasy story. It is one steeped in mystery and pushes the boundaries of creativity.  Each character has a unique subplot completely entangled with the main story. The side quests tie in with the games central themes and main narrative very well. Accordingly, they dont seem out of place or tacked on but are very believeable in the world crafted by larian studios. Music: The music works. It sets the tone quite nicely for the various parts of the world. It goes from epic to playful to somber to tragic in parallel with the envirement or scenario. Gameplay: The gameplay is very strategic with nuanced application. You must defeat intelligent and powerful Antagonists. Your set of abilities can be used envirementaly and you must keep your wits about you for the entirety of the game for both battle and exploration.  Characters: the ensemble cast of main characters each have their own ambitions, dreams, and philosophy. They are not just along for the ride. If you dont want to play as one of them you can create a character whose complexity and depth extends as far as yourself. Most if not all of the NPCs have believable ambitions and reasons for either deterring you or assisting you. there are many factions of npcs and 2/3 of them will seek your destruction depending on your choice so replayability is permitted. I have finished this game once and this is a reflection of that experience.  Since this is truly a great game, I wish everyone to play through and experience its wonders, for that is why I recommend the exploration mode for anyone that is turned off by the difficulty, so they can focus on exploration. I say that because the world and its characters are a spectacle to behold. This is the purest Role Playing Game i have played and I look forward to the future of its developer, Larian Studios.

Even if you are on the fence about isometric RPG games (like me), there's a good chance you will love this game, because every aspect of it has been so well thought through and topped with a blinding amount of polish.  This game is pretty slow paced - you will want to pay attention to the lore, to the stats on your charecters/weapons, the excellent dialogue between charecters, the methodological turn-based combat and many other fine details if you are going to make the most of playing it. REVIEW UPDATED AFTER GAME COMPLETION -----------------  +Same excellent, engaging combat system as the first game. Some expanded functionality +Some quality of life UI changes which make everything better +Better skills / attributes system which makes character creation more flexible +VO in the initial release (as opposed to being added in EE of D:OS) +2 player co-op was fun; 4 player co-op is awesome +When I first reviewed this game I said the story was "marginal at best" part way through Act 2. I've since changed my view on this; the characters develop very nicely through the rest of the game, and all of the plotlines of the individual characters tie up really nicely by the end. There were lots of things in the game that really made me say "Wow. These developers really poured their blood and tears into this." However....  -I do feel the game was a bit too long. 160 hours for one playthrough was tedious, and I put the playthrough on pause for a few months and came back to it. I think they could have done without Act 3 entirely, and done a second mega act in Act 4. The playtime also would be significantly mitigated by the below mentioned quality of life changes. -Simple things like: please don't allow lucky charm to roll on equipment. It's super annoying to switch gear / drink alcohol everytime I want to look something. -Still an inventory management simulator. Developers should really break out crafting ingredients into its own menu / sorting system. I spent a lot of time crafting scrolls, potions, and grenades as combat contingencies for Honour and this would have made a big difference in my gameplay experience. -Skillbook description poorly communicates spell range, making it hard to figure out the best skills for a build -Huge minus: crafting system is incomplete. Why can i only craft chest pieces, and not gloves / legs / helmets? Why are so many recipes that were in the first game missing from this one? -Huge minus: buggy as hell. Should have stayed in Early Access longer to fix these.  I originally reviewed this game as 7.5 / 10. I'm going to go with 8.5 / 10 with my revised view of the story / characters. With QOL changes and a tighter playtime, the next instance of this franchise could easily be a 9.5+ masterpiece. I'm very excited and will definitely be contributing to a kickstarter if there is one.

Fantastic Game if you're into RPGs. They took Divinity Original Sin and made it better it most aspects. The game is engaging all the way through and provides hours upon hours of game play with different ways of getting things done. The new restructure of Stats and Abilities makes you feel alot more in line with where you should be compared to other creatures of your level without feeling broken.   They simplified the way a lot of things work and the only one that irked me was Crafting. Crafting in Divinity Original Sin and Enhanced Edition really brought a lot to the game with money making and being able to stack resistances to make up for lower end gear that you just couldn't find an Upgrade for. In Divinity Sin Original Sin 2 you can forget about that and weapon enchants are down to just Two methods. Poison Barrel or an Eternal Object for Lightning. Poison Barrel adds Poison damage which honestly hurts for a ton of fights where you're partially healing the creature you're damaging(Undead).  The Dev Team is great, even after being released as a full game for this long they are still pumping out Bug Fix Patches and Game Balance Patches which shows they care about the Game and what the Community thinks.  I'd give this game an 8/10, Larian Studios really knows what they're doing.

Total: 9.8/10  Here's my review    Customization/Progress 9.8 Customize things like: Appearance, Attributes, Abilites, Skills, Talents, Tags and your battle music whenever you kill an enemy. Its a little poor when it comes to the face/hair customization but the other things makes up for it    Gameplay 9.8 Gameplay is smooth and feels immersive. The turn-based action gives you alot of time to think for the right moves and it's a game where you can relax and not just button mash your way through like Diablo. The reason I took away 0.2 of the score is because it can be quite confusing for newbies to find out what to do (especially if you haven't played Divinity 1 before)    Graphics 9.9 Suprisingly good graphics even up-close, but the "Deathfog" is annoying to watch while the camera is moving which is why I took away 0.1 score. Updating my review yet again as early acess and patches come thru. This will be edit number 4 after completing the first set once again.   Many of my initial complaints have been addressed at this point. Dialogue is much improved and even good enough to make the sub characters feel like real characters. They each had small story points in the opening that made it feel like they were actually progressing a bit more with you on your journey compared to attack bots you used in battle. They are still not fully fleshed out but it is early access.  Items/Gear/Spells are WAAAAYYYY better this time around. I was not spending the entire time struggling to find gear to use and feeling forced to have barter and thievery maxed just to try to keep my characters functioning. I did have trouble finding decent weapons for my 2hnd Knight while I got more crossbows than I knew what to do with but some RNG is expected. I felt the early parts of the game were also improved to not feel so brutal to get your first couple levels. I had only a few glitches or bugs along the way as well. (Ben Encourage refused to hit 2 out of my 4 party members for example and Electric discharge seemed to jump way off screen instead of to another enemy), but over all completely functional with lots of different ways to approach things or if you are like me do them all.   I did still have a few complaints that still are around. For one the combat does feel really one sided. Hit armor then CC lock and win. This strat worked on every fight but the last which it still worked just wasn't 100% one sided. The single time I died on the playthrough was the opposite happened to me. I didn't even use a single turn on my side just got to watch the enemy with infinite turns CC lock kill me till party wipe. So I didn't get a lot out of the gameplay combat itself.   This is still exasperated by the fact you can only customize your starting character. You are allowed to choose your other characters jobs when they first join, but you can't tweak or customize anything so the 3 party members I grabbed had some useless traits no matter what I choose I ended up just trying to pick the least painful loss among them. So It took till around level 4-5 till I felt like I had a team I really did enjoy using with the skills and traits I wanted.   Overall it was still a lot of fun this time around. I was expecting this to be a bit more painful at first every once in a while comming back to this game to see how it progressing while knowing we have no clue about release date. However, I enjoyed this playthru enough to finish and be reminded why I wanted to support the early access in the first place.   P.S. If Larian is reading this Please Please PLEASE add a main story Dwarf! I do feel a little left out while the premade characters have unique story situations, but I can't get them on a dwarf!

D:OS 2 is a thrilling and beautful adventure across the fictional land of Rivellon in search of becoming the next divine. It continues like this until the later acts where it picks up. Thankfully, there are individual character stories that take place between for those before mentioned pre-generated characters, if you happen to have any in your party. 2017 was a good year for gaming, and Divinity: Original Sin 2 is one of the reasons for that. This RPG features top-down turn-based combat that is reminiscent of Temple of Elemental Evil, except that the encounter design here is much more varied and imaginative. The game actively encourages you to find creative solutions, sometimes things that would be considered 'cheesing' in other games, and rewards you for doing so. I found myself purposely trying to provoke fights sometimes, as they were just so much fun.   Compared to the first game, the writing is much better and more entertaining, and most of your potential companions are likeable and interesting - the resolution of Lohse's personal quest was genuinely moving. The animations, sound design and voice acting are top-notch across the board.  The main story didn't grip me quite as much, but it served its purpose of moving things along.   Of course, no game is perfect, and D:OS 2 is no exception. The loot level-scales to such an extent that a legendary axe at level 14 is worse than a regular grey axe at level 16. It means you won't experience the joy of finding a particularly good piece of equipment that will last you half the game, which is part of what made the old Infinity Engine games so fun. It also means it's a good idea to visit a vendor every time you level up, or you quickly risk falling behind. All that time spent shopping can get tedious.  I also have some issues with the way Source is handled in this game. Replenishing your Source is a very time-consuming process, so I found myself almost never using Source spells in combat.  This ties in with my assessment of the final fight, which is very hard and where you almost need to use Source (which you suddenly have limitless access to) to win - except that I had never really had a chance to experiment with that mechanic up to that point. I eventually managed to beat it, mostly through sheer luck, but it does not make for a very satisfying resolution to an otherwise great game.   All in all, despite the aforementioned flaws, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a huge improvement over the first game, which was already quite good. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is even the slightest bit interested in RPGs.

I played part the Divinity Original Sin Enhanced Edition and enjoyed that, so I decided to get DOS 2 after I saw it on sale for a modest 10% (also because my friends had the game and I wanted to play with them).   As it turns out, this game is such an improvement on the first game that I just cant go back to DOSEE. Divinity: Original Sin 2 is an amazing game that quite literally builds on every positive element of the Enhanced Edition and makes the game so much smoother and comprehensive.   YOU CAN NOW ACCESS ALL INVENTORIES OF YOUR PARTY MEMBERS IN ONE WINDOW. PRAISE LARIAN STUDIOS. Improvements were also made to many mechanics such as: Crafting, purchasing/bartering, targeting AOE spells.  The storyline is also so much more rich now that you have 5 preset characters to choose from (and the option to create your own). Right off the bat, I was much more engaged in DOS2's story than I ever was in the EE. I love their banter. I love that ALL party members can engage in dialogue, thus giving you multiple opportunities to get the "right" answers without needing to reload the game. The voice acting is great and the characters have personalities true to their plights.   If you enjoy story-rich games, this one's for you! (If the turn-based combat system deters you, there is the option to play the game in Explorer Mode to make the combat easier and thus a secondary feature).  TL;DR: This game is lots of fun! Kudos to a development team that listens to its community in order to improve on previous iterations of its game(s)!

Words cannot fully describe how wonderful the game is. After 106 hours I have finally finished it on tactician difficulty - the second highest out of 4 difficulty levels - and it's been one hell of a ride. In the pool of games that have filled the cRPG genre over time some are remembered for the gems that they are. This game truly deserves a place among those stars.    Short and quick: The best aspects The combat offers a huge variety of possibilites. 200+ spells allow you to build your character exactly to your liking. They aren't all magical, they don't all scale with intelligence like you'd expect from classical RPGs meaning you can mix a lot of combinations on your character. Don't think of spells as a 'magician only' thing. Every character will use a wide variety and it feels amazing to have this much choice in battle.  The AI will use insane combinations and synergies of spells just as much as you do. They will sacrifice their own if it gives them an advantage, they will use the environment against you.   No ridiculous RNG: Although dicerolls aren't completely banished out of the game these mechanics never feel unfair like in some other RPGs. Games based on pen & paper tend to use a lot of dicerolls but here you'll find that most mechanics have been modified to be very clear about how they work without relying on RNG. Doesn't mean critical attacks aren't possible if you want to play that way ;-)  There are no classes. Don't get mistaken by the character creation, it's only meant to be a help for the early game. You level and can spent your points on the different schools of sorcery. You're never restricted because of a 'class' and after leaving the first area you can fully respecc at any time. You can truly built your character the way you want to.  The worldbuilding is amazing. There is so much to explore, so many NPCs to talk to and stories to experience.  The characters - from simple animals to essential NPCs - are just as amazingly written as the world. Some you'll love, some you'll laugh about, some you'll hate, but never will you think they are acting out of character.   The choice is always yours. One moment you're a saint, next moment you decide an NPC isn't worth keeping alive. Although sometimes limited, there are always consequences.   To further strengthen the last point: You can play the game anyway you want and never hit a roadblock in the story. Even if you murder every NPC you see you'll be able to finish the story.   Play the entire campaign with up to 4 players. 'nuff said  The voiceacting is phenomenal. Everything in this game is voiced, including the narrator. Not only that, but the variety in voices is so large you will rarely - if ever - notice two voices sounding alike. Every unimportant guard, every NPC without a name, every animal in the wild, every character - no matter how essential they are to the story - sounds different and they manage to bring the emotions their words carry to life.  The soundtrack manages to describe the atmosphere in a wonderful way.   Although the story is rather serious, the little sprinkles of humor every now and then shine brightly.  Short and quick: The worst aspects The companions sidequests are wonderful and they influence the main story quite a lot. But everywhere else they're a little pale as they rarely voice their oppinion on what you do during the rest of the journey.   This game can easily overwhelm you. If you're familiar with the cRPG gerne you'd expect this but everyone else be warned: This is not a game you finish in a couple of hours nor is it a linear game. Having a huge freedom means your questlog will burst at times.  The difficulty is real. Even on classic - the normal mode - you'll get your‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•handed to you on a silver plater. I finished the game in 106 hours on tactician - one difficulty above classic - and my save game told me I was 'alive' for 80 hours. That means I had 26 hours of reloading because of party wipes or decisions that I regreted. I thoroughly enjoyed the difficulty but be warned: It's not to be taken lightly.   A slight negative about undeads: If you play one or have one in your party you can chose to hide your undeadness and the story will acknowledge this but the combat won't. I assume it's done for the sake of difficulty and interesting gameplay, but enemies will always know that you're an undead and chose tactics that work against undeads like e.g. hurting you with healing magic.  After all is said, it's still a cRPG. There's a lot to read, a lot of sidequests to do and a lot of possibilites in how you tailor the story around you. Don't go into this game with wrong expectations. It's huge. Having wrong expectations can easily ruin the experience for you.  You might wonder even with all the high praise you've heard about this game how it compares to the best of the cRPG genre. It's not simple to answer this as classics like Baldur's Gate can be hard to enjoy these days. Some of the most defining games of this genre came out in the late 90's to early 00's after all. Divinity: Original Sin 2 takes the things that made those classics wonderful and wraps them into a modern engine. It learned from all the mistakes that happened with the first 'Original Sin' game and improved greatly on them. So in summary, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. For me it's not only the RPG of the year, it's a strong contender for game of the year.

What to say about this game that hasn't been said already. I am not the biggest turn-based RPG fan, but Divinity: Original Sin II was recommended to me by a friend, and I am extremely glad I purchased it. 100+ hours for a first full playthrough, and I'm already considering my next.  The game itself is hard. VERY hard for a casual or novice player. This is the first game I have not felt that saving frequently amounted to save scumming. The fights are disgustingly hard when you first start out, BUT once you get a feel for the combat system and learn how to work the mechanics in your favor, it balances out quite nicely. The mechanics themselves are fantastic, and had me feeling great when I conquered battles that felt unfair and unbalanced.  That being said, avoid this game like the plague if you have no patience and want a game you can steamroll from the start. You will die, a lot, if you are inexperienced.   The storyline itself will suck you in and swallow your soul. I enjoyed it from beginning to the last sequence. That last sequence... sucked. Horribly. The battle, the story, the NPCs, everything. It was terrible. I wish the game hadn't ended because I loved it so much, to end up with that was just disheartening. There is a lot of choice in the game, and it gets ful marks from me for that. You can do anything you want, how you want, and with whoever you want. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Except for that final part, but endings don't make or break a game for me. It's the journey that matters.  Scores:  Graphics: 9/10 Gameplay: 10/10 Story: 9.5/10 (Ending gets a 3/10) Music: 7/10 (It was okay, nothing spectacular)  I'd have to give the game an overall 9.8/10 though. Even with my distaste for the ending sequence, this game is superb and deserves both your hard earned money and all the praise you can heap on it.

I always feel very lazy about writing reviews but they deserve it, even if the review is a little bit too late.   A title? A MASTERPIECE. After 117 hours in this game I finally finished it on normal mode. I did my best to explore every corner and solve every puzzle, read every book, but I ended up missing a few things.  I gotta play it again on a higher difficulty with other characters, specially with Loshe on the team.   Well, let's get to it. First of all you need to know if this game is for you. Do you like turn-based RPGs? Do you like reading the books that you find, caring about little details of the world and developing your characters regarding the lore? Do you like spending time outside the combat and just strolling around the city and getting to know its inhabbitants and its atmosphere? Then this game is definetely for you.   Why did I ask that? Well, the combat is amazing but you won't be battling every time. A lot of situations can be solved through dialogue for instance. That are a lot of other elements in the game like talking, exploration and puzzles. So you need to beware of that.  The story starts slow and you have a feeling that you won't care for it at all. But you need to see how things develop. It has ups and downs and a complexity that I can't explain to you without spoiling it. I loved it. You will care for most characters and even sidekicks, damn, it is that good. There are a lot of humor and jokes in the game, like talking to silly or arrogant animals or facing ironical situations. It doesn't diminish the experience or transform it into a goofish playthrough. No. It adds up, a lot. You feel that you are in a rich and complex world with characters that mess up, that are understandable badguys or that are just self righteous‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•    Regarding the combat system, it had a lot of improvments in comparison to the previous title. Fire, Water, Electricity, Poison, Oil, Clouds, Blood, High Ground (Yes, I have it, Anakin), Low Ground, Teleportation, Physical Armor, Magical Armor, Resistances, etc. are all things to take into account, contributing to enhance the complexity of the combat system. The enemies will try to use those elements against you and the AI is pretty decent most of the time.  However, I have to say that there are minor issues regarding battles. What annoys me the most? Fights with 5+ enemies that cast 2-3 spells each. Man, that can take a lot of your time. Dead time because you will just be watching them casting and casting. It can take forever. Also, it pisses me off when the enemy uses a spell that takes control you character - like "charm" for exemple. In those occasions the AI simply doesn't know what to do. It takes a longer time to calculate the action and will eventually drink all your potions for nothing, while you sit there waiting.   In addition to that there are some minor bugs regarding the quest log. And I feel that they could really improve the inventory system. It's better and Divinity Origial Sin 1,sure, but it can still get pretty messy, specially books. My suggestion? Make it like a library system in your headquarters. Then you could store them in a shelf to complete a specific collection, let's say alchemy recipes or Hewbert's Encyclopedia. Also, the crafting system could be better too. I know that they want it to be more based on intuition, but some times the player has no clue about the ingredients. Also, more meaningful crafted armors and weapons would be awesome.   Nevertheless, all of those are minor criticism to improve the game. It's absolutely gorgeous - visually and musically -, engaging and a true RPG experience. I feel that those AAA companies really have a lot to learn from Larian Studios. I liked Divinity Original Sin 1, but the sequel is absolutely amazing. Bravo!

I should mention that 99% of my playtime is in the starting area, restarting because my friends and I can't just choose a class we want and stick with it. And even that 1% is only like five minutes of playtime after you leave tutorial island.   This game is still great, however. There's so much to do, so many things to discover, and the combat is great, even if I find myself on fire for the majority of any given battle. Do give this game a shot if you want Dungeons and Dragons in video game form, as it's the closest thing to it that you can possibly get.

Holy crap. This game is amazing.  So heres the run down. This game is in effect a massive game of dungeons and dragons, only the game is the dungeon master rather then your friend being the dungeon master.   The RPG aspects all feel really nicely done here, with concious effort being required to decide on how best to talk your way through a situation. The fact that every character in the game comes with voice acting is simply astounding, esspecially given just how many characters there are in this game.  As far as combat is concerned, its very similar to XCOM and atlas reactor. Each character recieves a turn, with the order being determind by each characters initiave stat. Much like XCOM and atlas reactor, every action has to have its strength and weaknesses weighted against the situation. To be completely honest, the combat system feels so smooth and effective, it makes the non-combat sections feel underwhelming as a result, and believe me, they definetly are not boring.  The multiplayer aspects are really nice. Personally, I recommend only playing multiplayer with friends, but that has more to do with ensuring cooperation then anything else. One nice feature of playing with friends is that it makes every moment feel more enjoyable.  All that said, I do have a few nitpicks about this game. The ingame market system can feel annoying at times, since only one person can foot the bill for an order of gear. Similarly, there will be many occasions where you can find yourself running through the same dialog again and again in hopes of achieving the best result.  However, despite everything else I have said, the single best thing about this game is its customizability. Built into the game is an editor that allows you to alter the map, the story, and where all enemies are located, which gives the game huge replay value. On top of that, the game is perfectly capable of accepting mods, which cranks this games replay value up to eleven.  Summary: Pros: + Absolutely amazing combat system that feels very familiar to anyone who has played XCOM. + Amazing graphics quality. + Insanely rich story and lore. + Dozens of hours per campaign. + Tons of replay value. + All voice acting is well done, and if you can talk to it, it has a voice. + Loot has a heavy ammount of RNG attached to it. + Everything is right there after you download the game (an increasingly rare thing these days). + Your starting class is completely flexible, and you can change just about everything about your starting class. + You do not need to stick to a specific class as the game goes on, allowing you to adapt as you go. + A ton of workshop content, and the games less then four months old.  Cons: - Things can get a little tedious at times, particularly if your not the best at keeping your saves up to date. - Purchasing from vendors is a little annoying, and I personally feel it could stand some more quality of life features. - You may find yourself restarting fights often as you realize what actually is happening.  Conclusions: Divinity original sin 2 is simply an amazing game. Almost everything about this game screams of quality, and feels like it is the result of honest game design. When people say this is a top of the line RPG game, they are not kidding. With extreme ease of modding, and a still growing community, its easy to see why this game is being called game of the year material.  Score: 9.9/10

Great game overall.  Pros: + Complex, detailed and engaging story in an immersive fictional world + Finished the game with ~130 hours clocked from one playthrough, and I didn't complete all of the quests + High quality of voice acting throughout, dialogue options vary between characters + Combat system incredibly versatile with a huge range of possibilites and combinations + Skills and equipment can allow a high level of specialisation for certain characters, with a huge variety of abilities + Similarly, the levelling up system allows for lots of modifications, and later in the game it is possible to re-spec characters if you made poor choices early on + A high level of customatisation, good voice acting, and in depth character backstories all lends the characters credibility in a way that can make you love or hate them + Extremely varied quest lines, often there are multiple ways to solve each quest + Really laugh-out-loud funny at times  Cons: - Steep learning curve on the combat, very much thrown in at the deep end with little explanation of complex system  - The combat is actually pretty hard throughout, and more casual gamers might find the repeated loading frustrating, as a small slip up in combat can be pretty unforgiving - Similarly, the game has a bad habit of insta-killing you with no real way of predicting it (e.g. suddenly encountering over-levelled enemies, environmental hazards, or the enemy has some ability/skill that you had no way of countering until now) - Quests can sometimes be tortuous in a way that means I would never have worked out on my own e.g. a riddle once asked for fire, but this didn't work, and I found online that I had to generate a fire cloud instead (?!) which I had never come across before and could only reliably find by buying one particular spellbook from one particular unrelated vendor. I spent a lot of time looking up how I was supposed to do quests - Similarly, quests can have unexpected consequences that can be inconvenient later on and lead to missing out on future quests - As I said before, you may find yourself totally underlevelled in an unexpected battle, and this does somewhat detract from the whole open world RPG vibe in that you have no hope of defeating some of the higher levelled enemies and have to go find some lower level enemies first, effectively forcing you to follow a pre-set path eliminating the weak enemies first and then going back for the higher ones. It makes the game feel more linear, although it is satisfying to decimate the enemies who destroyed you a couple of levels ago   Overall the negative points don't massively detract from the game and it is a compelling and immersive game from start to finish with complex but satisfying combat. More importantly, you can talk to dogs!!

TL;DR: Extremely well designed RPG overall, Great visual/graphics, Engaging and well written story, deep, fun, and challenging gameplay, would totally recommend this game if you are a fan of the genre  Aesthetics (Graphics, Visuals, Music): Absolutely top notch- the amount of detail in this game is astounding on a visual level. From each character looking fantastic, to the detail in spells and animation, to the level of beauty in the environment, overall this game looks great. The only drawback to this is that it's more demanding, resource-wise, than similar games. The music is also phenomenal and really follows the mood of the story without being too intrusive.  Gameplay: the combat system in this game is pretty similar to other CRPGs, but goes above and beyond. My personal favorite touch is the amount with which the environment can contribute to combat scenarios. There is a small learning curve which basically makes it the Dark Souls of- just kidding. There is a weird issue with balance where being overleveled by just 1 or 2 levels makes some fights trivial while being underleveled by 1 or 2 levels makes some fights annoyingly difficult, but overall, the game seems to do a good job of leveling the playing field... unless you're like me and added a mod that doubles the amount of enemies. One thing that is really underappreciated is how civil abilities affect gameplay. Characters have to balance environment and gear interactions, stealth skills, luck, and persuasion/bartering all in one pool of points. This can lead to balanced jack of all trades (master of none) characters, or min-max characters. This game also allows a lot of freedom in how to play by deciding lone wolf or travelling with a full party and by allowing you to constantly respec yourself and your companions.  Story: Extremely deep and interesting. I have found myself underwelmed by  lot of RPG stories as of late, thut this game was definitely an exception. Each of the comanions/prebuilt characers have their own stories which are fairly interesting but the main story and most of the side quests are captivating. There seems to be just enough instruction that you have an idea what to do, but this game will definitely not hold your hand and tell you exatly where to go. You can get lost or have absolutely no idea where to go, but it doesn't take a lot to get you back on track. Decently replayable - story length can be 30-70 hours depending on how into the story and side quests you get.  Notes: I haven't tried the multiplayer or GM mode yet

I. Adore. This. Game.  This is one of the only RPGs I've played in recent history in which I rarely felt like I couldn't do or say exactly what I wanted in any given moment. Quests can be tranversed, subversed, or just flat-out ignored. There are multiple means to achieving your goals. In short, player freedom is abundant throughout. Pacing of the game is great at best, decent at worst. The Origin characters, and, thus, your companions, fit your pretty typical Fantasy archetypes (gruff lone wolf mercenary, snobby exiled prince, raunchy pirate dwarf), but they never feel too wholly unoriginal. In fact, by the end I grew to like my little cast of mildly predictable misfits. Their individual quests also provide some extra motivation to continue, helping along with the general pace of things. Combat is fun, clever, and rewarding to master. Few things feel as good as properly changing up the terrain with a few spells or broken barrels then using the newly doused ground to trail a lightning spell to your enemies. The combat balance in the game isn't always perfect, but it is good enough throughout most of it that the few unfairly difficult fights don't overshadow the challenging but fun ones. There's not much to say about the music in the game. It's magnificent, I love it, and I order the soundtrack on vinyl. So there. I haven't even dabbled in the Game Master mode or the various Workshop mods yet, but they look very promising and exciting. At the time of writing (June 2018), I have 128 hours or so played in the game. That was one playthrough and maybe 5 hours of my second. A Must Buy RPG Summary:  This is the best classic-rpg I've ever played and most polished indie game. It's the first example, in a long time, of a game that made me feel like paying full price was more than worth it. My reasons and dislikes are bulleted as pros & cons. If you're hesitant, try learning about the franchise before playing. The world is interesting without prior knowledge of the Divinity franchise, but I still highly recommend you catch up on the lore. At the very least the first original sin game if not all of it. If not, make sure to read the store page and view the trailers before starting. Otherwise, your introduction into the franchise backstory (universe) will be journal entries and books. There is pvp in the game, but it's far from being a highlight. It's practically dead; you'd have more luck co-oping.  Rating: Solid 9/10 Pros:  - Rich Backstory - Multiple approaches to questlines - Best looking classic isometric rpg so far - Abundance and variety of skills and abilities - Well over 100 hours worth of good content - Your character can become any class combination in the game - Great co-op, able to compete with teamates or help each other - Good writing, mostly voice acted, solves a common weakness in the genre - Both side and main quests are engaging, laced with secrets and hidden areas  - Old school, sandbox-like, lack of handholding, more freedom as a result:    o The easy mode doesn't neccessarily simplify the game, just the combat  - High replayability in both custom and original chars:    o Race influences how you're percieved and affects dialogue and quest approach    o Multiple endings based on key decisions  - Decent modding community, solves several minor complaints (disables achivements):    o Visuals like clothing, hair, face model, more loot indicators etc.    o Progression (xp tweaks, starting gear)    o Abilities reworked for the better    o Buff effects, durations etc.    o User-made campaigns Cons:  - Companions don't say much - Few questline bugs, still rewards exp - The 4 acts in the game are great, but the last one is rushed - Combat favors heavy specialization in harder difficulties (all melee, all magic) - Crafting and inventory management is a pain, adds unnecessary time (no search function)

This game starts very strong but has the common inconsistencies of RPG, Free dialogue style play. (Similar to Fallout, Elder scrolls). I have spent almost 40 hours in the game to date and have enjoyed it, however, I never feel this game draws you into the world. It doesn't deserve 9/10 ratings, it is 7/10 at best. There are some game breaking mechanics that weaken a class or particular set of abilities.  Teleport is overwhelmingly overpowered, it literally breaks every aspect of the game if you use it right. You can completely alter the desired mechanic of a fight by using it. (unfairly) For example, Whilst a boss, I teleported him to my party and immediately killed him alone, well before his allies could help him and then when a neutral add spawned, i teleported his party members to the neutral add to get cleaved and then had to just fight the neutral add.   For example, Having a mage/wizard doing damage in a party primarily built up of Physical dps (Enemies have two forms of Armour, Physical and Magical) is pointless.  Their value as damage dealers drops to zero, they will hardly break-through any magical armour alone.  "Tank" classes don't exist as taunt has too short of a range, and most times your enemies will be immune to taunt.  I enjoyed the game, but simple things like save files and fast travels legitamtely break any immersion. You can save game in the middle of a fight and alter it to achieve victory at certain points. In one quest chain, your party is separated intentionally for the purpose of the quest. However, you can just fast travel to the centre of the quest zone with each individual character, there-by eliminating any effort.  The good;  Voice acting is incredible, if you enjoy DnD, then you'll love this game. Classical mode seems like the perfect "Normal" - It is challenging/formidable if you brazenly walk into a room of enemies, but if you draw them through fire or into a choke point then it becomes an even playing field.  LoS is your friend.  Probably the best turn based strategy game i've played to date.  Sneak and Thievery is just plain OP, you can't go without it.  Being able to sneak and put explosive barrels around enemies is vital to success in many fights, especially against stronger mobs.    Buy the game and make an opinion yourself. I stopped enjoying it at close to 40 hours played. The story was boring and uninteresting and even at 40 hours (Which is half way through the game).  Still worth a pick up - but the game really comes down to personal taste, it doesn't appeal to me.  i would love to see more games with this classical mode difficulty, by far that was the most interesting aspect of the game.

This game is, by far, the best RPG game I have ever played in the history of all my 20 years of gaming. I cannot wait to put thousands of hours into it. The only issue I have with it, however, is how limited the character creation system is, but I guess no game can be absolutely perfect. That said, here's why I love this game and will enjoy playing it for likely years to come.  The story:  I've only ever gotten so far as ACT II, but even still, the story in that time is so rich it'd put the CEO of the Amazon corporation to shame. The openess of the story makes for excellent roleplay elements. It'll keep you hooked and wanting more and more the further you delve into it.  Gameplay:  The only class restrictions are literally how you choose to build your character because of where you choose to put your attribute and ability points. That sky's the limit, and any kind of character imaginable can be built and played in this game. I would even go so far as to say this game is the closest game to a D&D simulator there can be without actually being D&D.  Combat:  Generally, I'm not a fan of turn-based combat outside of games like CIV games, but the system for this game really takes the cake. While the combat is turned based, the way it's set up to function is absolutely marvelous. The great minds at Larian Studios definitely didn't go wrong with it--at all.  Customization:  This game is open to steam workshop elements and modding. It also has a Dungeon Master aspect that allows you to create and run custom campaigns for you and four of your friends. However, I recommend playing the game as the vanilla version before adding mods to it, as some of them can be quite game breaking. Trust me, though, you absolutely won't regret it.  All-in-all, this game is pretty much perfect minus my only aforementioned problem with character customization. Other than that, I would definitely recommend this game and have absolutely nothing but good things to say about it! I give this game a 9.9/10.

Wow. Just wow.  To start off, I had no idea this game was, well, this game. I'm in to RPGs like Skyrim, the Witcher, Dragon Age(ish), and fantasy stuff like that. I had always seen this game advertised on steam's front page in recommended for me, but i never took it seriously since it gave me a very "Diablo 3" kinda vibe, and that felt too grindy and un-fun for me. But eventually, I finally caved a decided to take a good look at it and felt i should try it out, since I've heard pretty much only good things (see entire review section of this game lmao). Basically, i didn't many expectations starting out.  Holy‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• This game is good. Like really good. Like REALLY, REALLY good. I did not expect to fall in love as much as I did, nor to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing binge the game and end up earning 80 hours played within a week. I believe a testament to this game's quality is how hard i fell for it, even without playing (or even really knowing about) the first Divinity. It's detailed, it's fun, it has a great story, the gameplay is engaging and does not get dull, and the sheer freedom the player has is incredible. The game's dialouge and overall feel gives me a big DnD vibe. There are many, many branches a dialouge, quests, and the story itself can break off into which will seriously affect how you go forward in the game, even affecting the ending in a very critical way, not the "good" or "bad" ending bs you normally get from choice-based gameplay like Dishonored or Mass Effect. Moreso, the games gives you more freedom in how you want to build your character, not confining people to class, but rather providing a "skill level" you must be leveled up to in order to learn certain abilities, which are all fairly low.  I don't have the ability like other people to give you a long review about every little thing, so I'll leave with this: If you are looking for a fantasy RPG that will reward you with a in-depth experience and let you truly craft your character to be exactly who YOU want them to be, then this is the game for you.  Divinity: Original Sin 2 is a calibur of game that belongs with the other incredible RPGs like Skyrim or The Witcher 3, and possibly has the potential to surpass them, in my opinion. 11/10 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing fantastic

Holy crap. This game is amazing.  So heres the run down. This game is in effect a massive game of dungeons and dragons, only the game is the dungeon master rather then your friend being the dungeon master.   The RPG aspects all feel really nicely done here, with concious effort being required to decide on how best to talk your way through a situation. The fact that every character in the game comes with voice acting is simply astounding, esspecially given just how many characters there are in this game.  As far as combat is concerned, its very similar to XCOM and atlas reactor. Each character recieves a turn, with the order being determind by each characters initiave stat. Much like XCOM and atlas reactor, every action has to have its strength and weaknesses weighted against the situation. To be completely honest, the combat system feels so smooth and effective, it makes the non-combat sections feel underwhelming as a result, and believe me, they definetly are not boring.  The multiplayer aspects are really nice. Personally, I recommend only playing multiplayer with friends, but that has more to do with ensuring cooperation then anything else. One nice feature of playing with friends is that it makes every moment feel more enjoyable.  All that said, I do have a few nitpicks about this game. The ingame market system can feel annoying at times, since only one person can foot the bill for an order of gear. Similarly, there will be many occasions where you can find yourself running through the same dialog again and again in hopes of achieving the best result.  However, despite everything else I have said, the single best thing about this game is its customizability. Built into the game is an editor that allows you to alter the map, the story, and where all enemies are located, which gives the game huge replay value. On top of that, the game is perfectly capable of accepting mods, which cranks this games replay value up to eleven.  Summary: Pros: + Absolutely amazing combat system that feels very familiar to anyone who has played XCOM. + Amazing graphics quality. + Insanely rich story and lore. + Dozens of hours per campaign. + Tons of replay value. + All voice acting is well done, and if you can talk to it, it has a voice. + Loot has a heavy ammount of RNG attached to it. + Everything is right there after you download the game (an increasingly rare thing these days). + Your starting class is completely flexible, and you can change just about everything about your starting class. + You do not need to stick to a specific class as the game goes on, allowing you to adapt as you go. + A ton of workshop content, and the games less then four months old.  Cons: - Things can get a little tedious at times, particularly if your not the best at keeping your saves up to date. - Purchasing from vendors is a little annoying, and I personally feel it could stand some more quality of life features. - You may find yourself restarting fights often as you realize what actually is happening.  Conclusions: Divinity original sin 2 is simply an amazing game. Almost everything about this game screams of quality, and feels like it is the result of honest game design. When people say this is a top of the line RPG game, they are not kidding. With extreme ease of modding, and a still growing community, its easy to see why this game is being called game of the year material.  Score: 9.9/10

At the time of writing this review, I've put about 30ish hours into the game (I torrented the game at first, don't judge me), and honestly I love this game.  I'm a big fan of RPGs in general (check my hours on basically any of the Bethesda RPGs and The Witcher 2&3) as well as an avid D&D player.  This game to me feels like playing Dungeons and Dragons but focusing on all the delicious crunch of player creation, leveling, and building.  The system feels tight and well balanced as well as having a great variety of player options to choose from.  Players are not so much locked into a specific role or archetype in this game.  Your average tanky knight character isn't just a dude with a sword and a shield, more often than not he's dabbling in earth or water magic to shore up his own defenses, or perhaps it's a rogue dabbling in necromancy.  Your mage may be wearing full plate and running into the thick of things, firing off fireballs in all directions.  The point is, the game gives you a lot of options to build and grow your character.  I've yet to "beat" the game but I've enjoyed the crunch so much, I've made a good dozen or so characters just to try out different playstyles.  Most of the issues I've had with the core gameplay have been patched, (i.e certain boss monsters skipping my characters turn because they get a forced turn one even though my character had a higher initiative, spells and attack not registering while draining AP, and other misc. bugs and oversights).  The world of Divinity is also interesting.  Worldbuilding is something I like to do in my spare time and some of the ideas presented in this game are very very cool.  Lizards are former dragons and rulers of an empire built on the backs of slaves, elves are cannibals who gain knowledge from eating flesh, and dwarves are... well I guess they're standard fantasy dwarves but ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it, dwarves are cool.  The setting of the game does a few neat things to try and separate it from it's bog-standard fantasy and I definitely appreciate that.  The writing in general, outside of general worldbuilding, is pretty compelling too.  It feels like some companions got a bit more attention than others, but each one of them feels distinct with their own backgrounds, personalities, flaws, and goals.  Dialogue is consistently well written and companions arcs as they get deeper into their questlines is nice to watch and be a part of.  Inter-party drama between companions is interesting and a nice detail not a whole lot of RPGs care to put in.  My personal favorite companion is the Red Prince; he's such a lovable ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and his voice actor is on spot.  Now onto the "role playing" itself.  A lot of people seem to have forgotten that RPGs as we know it were built upon the foundation of tabletop roleplaying games.  Y'know, games where you actually make a character and have to, to a certain extent, act out their personality and put yourself into their shoes.  Divinity lets you do that, at least to an extent that doesn't detract from the core of the game.  While I appreciate their attempts, and the writing does help make some of these roleplaying moments hit their mark, there's a disconnect between the game and it's attempt to let you roleplay.    Firstly; It's just straight up better to end almost all conflicts in the game by killing the bastard.  You gain no XP, or at least not comparable XP, for talking or slying your way out of a difficult situation when compared to just murdering the poor soul.  I understand it'd probably be a bit difficult to try and balance this out; someone passes their speech check and then murders them anyway, gaining double XP.  But there's a solution out there somewhere that is well balanced while still letting players roleplay their characters.  But as the game is right now, it's just better to murder hobo your way though most of the game.  Secondly; Persuasion mechanics are very weird and not very transparent as of now.  Usually some dialogue choices with have [Wits] or [Strength] next to them when trying to convince another character.  This gives the impression that this game is doing what Fallout New Vegas and Fallout 1 & 2 did; giving you special dialogue options just for being your character.  Your character shouldn't have to be a smooth talking son of a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to talk themselves out of every situation.  A particularly strong character can bully someone into submission; a perceptive person can read their body language and make inferences as to that persons intentions or thoughts.  You have a character with 30 Strength who wants to intimidate someone, but then you fail.  What happened?  Did you put one too many points into Contitution?  No.  Persuasion mechanics are just poorly handled.  I'm not 100% sure how they work, but some pesuasion attempts are pointless.  They SEEM to key off an ability, but in fact they don't and are just guaranteed to fail.  Some persuasion checks do seem to work ala Fallout 1/2/NV, but most require at least one point in persuasion, if not more.  Not only are the Persuasion mechanics non-transparent (unlike almost all the other bits of crunch in the game), but the game seems to be almost misleading it's players into thinking that the mechanics work a different way, when they do not.  I think the way Fallout NV handled persuasion is probably the best way an RPG can handle it.   But for the most part, just ignore my tangent on the roleplaying aspects of the game.  The rest of the experience is fantastic.  This is easily the best RPG I have played since The Witcher 3 dropped two years ago.  This game might not be for all people, but I can confidently say that it tickled my pickle.  Pros: * It's pretty. * Soundtrack is sick * Deep and meaningful character creation and building * Consistently good writing and voice action throughout * The crunch is good * Doesn't hold your hand * At least 40 hours worth of content in the base game, plus replay value, plus mods, plus multiplayer/coop, plus GM mode * You get to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• just about every companion * You get to hear the Red Prince ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• another lizard * Gay relationships  Cons: * Persuasion is poop * Roleplay is (kinda) poop * Somewhat buggy launch (last few updates were big and had major bug fixes though)

This game starts very strong but has the common inconsistencies of RPG, Free dialogue style play. (Similar to Fallout, Elder scrolls). I have spent almost 40 hours in the game to date and have enjoyed it, however, I never feel this game draws you into the world. It doesn't deserve 9/10 ratings, it is 7/10 at best. There are some game breaking mechanics that weaken a class or particular set of abilities.  Teleport is overwhelmingly overpowered, it literally breaks every aspect of the game if you use it right. You can completely alter the desired mechanic of a fight by using it. (unfairly) For example, Whilst a boss, I teleported him to my party and immediately killed him alone, well before his allies could help him and then when a neutral add spawned, i teleported his party members to the neutral add to get cleaved and then had to just fight the neutral add.   For example, Having a mage/wizard doing damage in a party primarily built up of Physical dps (Enemies have two forms of Armour, Physical and Magical) is pointless.  Their value as damage dealers drops to zero, they will hardly break-through any magical armour alone.  "Tank" classes don't exist as taunt has too short of a range, and most times your enemies will be immune to taunt.  I enjoyed the game, but simple things like save files and fast travels legitamtely break any immersion. You can save game in the middle of a fight and alter it to achieve victory at certain points. In one quest chain, your party is separated intentionally for the purpose of the quest. However, you can just fast travel to the centre of the quest zone with each individual character, there-by eliminating any effort.  The good;  Voice acting is incredible, if you enjoy DnD, then you'll love this game. Classical mode seems like the perfect "Normal" - It is challenging/formidable if you brazenly walk into a room of enemies, but if you draw them through fire or into a choke point then it becomes an even playing field.  LoS is your friend.  Probably the best turn based strategy game i've played to date.  Sneak and Thievery is just plain OP, you can't go without it.  Being able to sneak and put explosive barrels around enemies is vital to success in many fights, especially against stronger mobs.    Buy the game and make an opinion yourself. I stopped enjoying it at close to 40 hours played. The story was boring and uninteresting and even at 40 hours (Which is half way through the game).  Still worth a pick up - but the game really comes down to personal taste, it doesn't appeal to me.  i would love to see more games with this classical mode difficulty, by far that was the most interesting aspect of the game.
