Playing Divinity Original Sin feels very much like playing a Dungeons And Dragons game, and it's also the game it takes most of its inspiration from. It's an easier to understand version of DnD, and I think it is perfectly possible to release a PnP version of the core rules of the game. While these rules aren't really explained in-game, they are very intuitive and it's easy to comprehend what is going on behind combat.  I like Divinity Original Sin 2. It's a little bit different from the first game, but still it feels very fresh and the problems addressed with the first game are now gone.  Differences from the first game One of the biggest differences are now the "two-type-of-armor-system". One is physical and the other one magical. Little bit similar as in the Starfinder Pen And Paper RPG, where you got AC for physical damage and EC for Energy Damage. Other differences are balancing of the skills, damage dealing and spells. Also the action points are fixed. Crafting is different too and is now easier. The rock-paper-scissor mini game for conversations is also gone.  Another big difference are two new races, which in the beginning I wasn't really convinced of, but if you play further they fit really well into the story.  The Story The story is also in my opinion better told than in the first one.¬†¬†I'm not a fan of voice acting in general, but this game does it really well, especially since dialogue is mostly text-based and everything is also voice acted. It's very nicely done. So you don't have to listen to the voice actors to know what is coming. You can just read and respond to it faster.  What is good about this game is that the story allows for multiple solutions to certain problems. This can be from ignoring the quest and fight your way through to multiple civil solutions you can do by "roleplaying".¬† These solutions aren't always clear and not everything is handed out to you by map markers or highlighted characters. You have to find out most of the stuff yourself.  The first time I played the starter island, I dumbly fought my way out of the prison. But actually on my second try of the game, I already found 4 ways of getting out of the prison. Which made me wonder now... how much stuff I have missed or didn't see the first or even the second time I will play through this game.  Combat Combat is very similar as in DnD. It's turn-based, which is fun. But sometimes also so slow when facing many enemies at once. It can also become very difficult at times. It's not an easy game.  So when combat starts, just as in most turnbased¬†RPG's everybody gets their initiative, based on their initiative score and something else I don't have found out... That determines who gets first in combat. Note that turns always alternate between player and opponent. Your initiative only determines the order of your own characters.  The other difference in divinity from other RPG's¬†is that no matter what, you will almost always do damage. The percentage of missing an attack is very low. I think characters can dodge an attack if they have the appropriate talent or if the attacker simply just missed. When dealing damage, you first have to destroy their respective armor and then you can lower their HP. Which is pretty cool. So you don't have to roll to hit against an armor number, which makes it possible and more fun to attack a higher level enemy with multiple characters. It gives you the sense that your attacks actually do something instead of miss. There is also a chance you do critical damage with each weapon. That percentage is also determined by your wits. And the percentage damage it does extra is determined by the weapon stats itself.  Damage dealt is also more fun than in D&D. You always do minimal damage with certain weapons. So if you have sword and it does between 5-8 damage it would be in DND 1d4+4. There is no way you do only 1 damage, there is no way you can roll bad. Also the damage of weapons and spells increase with your attributes.  Character Creation The damage you do, they hp you have, etc... is based on your attributes. Which is very similar to abilities in D&D. The names are sometimes different, but they work in the same way. The only new one is "Wits", it effects your critical chance, initiative and perception.  Next to attributes are abilities. Which are called skills in DnD. These increase characters effectiveness with weapons or allow you to take more skills. There are two kinds of abilities in the game. Combat and Civil abilities. Some help with bartering or sneaking other with damage of certain weapon types.  Then there are skills, which are also are a little bit like skills in D&D. They determine the effectiveness of your spells and weapons. The huge difference is that you can always learn a new skill, thus getting the proficiency with everything related to that skill. So if you want to cast fire spells with a certain character, just give him the pyromania skill. These skills get their bonuses from their respected attributes and scale with level. The weapon related skills scale with the weapons you have.  The skills you can actually do are those you have learned from skill books, which act like the feats from pathfinder or DnD 3.5. You can find those books or buy them from vendors. These are plenty and easy to find and mostly bossfights will reward you with one. The number of skills you can remember are determined by character level.  And then at last you have the talents, which are also a little bit like feats or special abilities in DnD. The talents are passive and give you certain perks. Like talking with animals, or you heal more if you are alone, stuff like that.  Similarities with DnD What also came over from 3.5 DND is that the range and damage of your ranged attacks are higher when having the higher ground. That you can flank enemies and that you can have attacks of opportunity. The different kind of states the characters can be in are also the same: sleepy, diseased, slowed, poisoned and they are also healed in almost the same way. The different kinds of terrain also work the same and make the combat very entertaining because it's a huge part of the game. It's also one of the first basic tricks for every DM in a rpg to make combat interesting by having cool environments.  O, yeah, graphics and stuff... Furthermore, the graphics and sounds are very good. The user interface is very well done with many effects to make it enjoyable to use.  Actually I'm not really into graphics of games and while this game is obviously more demanding and detailed in its graphics and sound in comparison to the first game, I still prefer... the original - not even the definitive edition - of the first game. Because of the more cartoony look. If you know me, my favorite type of graphics are those of the computer games between the years 1998 and 2004. Those were good times.  Only <3 for this game!

So good it will make you question WTF everyone else is spending time and money on when they develop an RPG. It's the best turn-based RPG I've played in a very long time, and one where I actually feel like I'm playing a role. Which is especially good since you all know we can't count on Final Fantasy for that fix anymore.  The Good: Fully voiced campaign, including all NPC's! (Even big budget titles don't do this!) All playable characters are customizable, and able to be used as their own character, including recruited companions. Pick an origin story, or make up your own. Fun, tactical, and innovative combat system. Very Replayable. Moddable, with a custom campaign creator to boot. As if that wasn't enough, it has a D&D style Game Master mode.  The Bad: Persuasion is overpowered. Don't get me wrong, I like having a charming character who can talk their way out of some situations, but it seems like most things in this game have persuasion options, sometimes when it wouldn't even make sense for someone to be convinced otherwise. It requires little effort to make a character to fulfill the necessary requirements, as it's easy to pump your main character full of persuasion and let other characters handle other areas. Sometimes I consider this a great boon to the role-playing side of things, but it also makes for a weaker experience in gameplay. One of the weakest aspects of the game in fact, IMO.  While Larian did an excellent job desiging the areas and leveling, enemy level scaling still doesn't exist. I know some people like those moments where you revisit an earlier part of a level and you can just murder everything, but I prefer every combat encounter to have weight.  I enjoy little moments in games like Elder Scrolls, where NPC's act racist, especially toward non-human races, because it's realistic, helps immersion, and gives you an added cause, with characters and concepts to combat. You want to do your character's race justice, perhaps change opinions, or get vengence. It's good for role playing. But in this game TOO MANY characters are racist. I get that they want to add text that changes based on a character's race but, good land, does everyone hate the lizard-folk? It seems like they do! Even the *animals* slander my main character. It just takes a good, immersive idea too far, and just pushes it to the point of being expected and annoying.  Overall, however, the positives outweigh the negatives by far. This is now one of my favorite games of all time, and I could not recommend it more.

Awesome!  So me and 3 of my mates are playing the campaign together - Each of us for the first time so it's all fresh and fun!  Last night we were attacking a group on a balcony which drew aggro from 3 below - There were 2 stairways up to us, one directly and one that went ALL the way around the balcony.  Within a turn or two, two of the guys at the bottom start running up to us. On the close stairway I cast rain and lightning it, stunning the two. After the lightning effect wears off, I oiled a portion of the area and slowed them down. During this time, we finish of most of the enemies up high. The third guy however walked in circles at the bottom seemingly ignoring us...  After a turn or two more, the 2 guys on the stairs reached myself so I teleported one of them back to the bottom to give us some extra time. When I did this, the third guy STILL at the bottom decided to ATTACK his own TEAMMATE to heal himself!! He was on full health!! He just attacked poor Timothy for no reason hahaha!!  Sooooo, a few turns later, the second guy had run back up the stairs and we'd dealt with him and all the others. Just the third guy remaining... He, who obviously wanted no part in this fight, had decided to, for whatever reason, to go up the other stairs and ALLLLLLLL the way around...  So, we decided to set a plan of ambush - Because at this point we were all laughing and just mocking this particular guy anyway - So we all gathered on the balcony that the path led to just around a corner, except for our support guy who stood right at the back of the path.. I set a layer of ice, and some oil, and then we just skipped turns for him to run to us.  Finally, one turn away, JUST around this corner we could see him. I froze the poor guy, and someone else warmed him up just to toy with him. We were all laughing given how long it took for him to get there... HIS TURN!! FINALLY!! We figured we'd let him hit just one of us just because.. But no!! What's this?? He's run past me... And my friend... And another... And then past 2 minions... Where's he going?!?! hahahaha. He ran directly at the support guy but ran out of AP and just stood next to him thinking for a while, then passed his go! Hahahaha!! He'd just about made it around the entire balcony when we finally killed him..  God damn that was funny!! Cannot wait till we're all online tonight :D    Basically the same game as the first but with improvements in skills, choices, graphics, etc. Highly recommended!

TL;DR Buy this game! Best RPG game I've ever played and in my top 3 games of all time without a doubt. There are hundreds of hours of gameplay here. The gameplay is quality unlike games like Skyrim which pretty much relies on mods to be fun for extended play sessions, which this game also offers. Dialog and story is also some of the best you'll find in recent games with  every piece of dialog being voiced which is just a great thing for an Indie game to do.  Seriously 9.9/10 game.  This is honestly the best RPG I have ever played and one of the best games I've played in general. This is one of the few single-player games that I just can't stop playing.   Before I played this game me and my friends played a lot of D&D, but we couldn't find enough time to play as much as we'd like since we were in our final year of school. So for ages I looked for a game that could emulate that same expirence. Being able to do what I want, having funny moments as well as epic. When one of my friends showed me this I was hooked.   The mechanics are almost the exact same as old school table top games, so iif you're into that turn based combat you'll love this, but even someone like me that normally hates those kind of combat mechanics in games I just loved these just because of how polished they were. The combat suprisingly has a lot of depth to it. There's so many different spells and equipment and many of them interact with eachother in their own ways.  The story and dialog is also one of the best I've ever seen in a game. Most of the dialog has so much character and is of such high quality, only of the voices feel as they were acted poorly, but 10000x better than you'll see in any Bethesda game. The fact that all of the dialog in the game is voice acted is also just an amaznig thing. It makes it feel as you're living in a real world and it also helps with the consistancy where some lines would be voiced and some wouldn't. This wouldn't mean anything iff the story wasn't good, which thankfully it isn't. The story is so good. It pulls you emotionally in so many different directions and you have to make so many decisions that make or break relationships and have an effect on what happens for the rest of the game.  Character creation is also pretty good, different races and classes having different traits and abilities as per usual. This part is the only part that I find to be pretty hard on new characters since some races and classes are harder to play than others, which can make it difficult and punishing. This can become a non-issue early in the game since you have the choice to pretty much change everything about you if you're not happy about it.  The one thing that I wish could be different about the game is its modding cababilities. Sadly as of now there aren't any mods anywhere near as big as mods that you find in Bethesda games, but thankfully this isn't a Bethesda game so you don't need mods to make it interesting lmao. This game does have the ability to act as your own Dungeon Master and make a whole game for you, your friends and your fellow steam gamers. and you also have the ability to download other peoples campains which just extends the hundreds of hours in the base game.  This game is almost a perfect example of what a game should be. For the gamer by not constantly trying to ram microtransactions down every hole in your body, have hundreds of high quality content from launch. Constant interaction with the community, THESE GUYS MAKE VLOGS MAN!!! and last but not least they don't do what every triple-a developer is doing now and making all their content and just releasing it as expansions. These guys are just about to release a FREE expansion that adds hundreds of more hours of gameplay which I would be more than happy to pay for since it is actually worth it and it's made to add value to the game instead of be a stupid cash grab.     SO IN SUMMARY. Great game, great engine, fun combat.   Not Quite as good as Pillars of Eternity though. I found myself comparing the 2 a lot during my 100 hour play through of the campaign to the end.  During that play through I spent half my time playing the game and half my time loading quick saves. It might just be how I deal with multiple outcomes in situations but it also came from making constant stupid mistakes. This game really shows you just how smart or dumb you are as a person, or at least makes you feel like a complete idiot so many times.    Part of the reason why Divinity 2 made me feel like a dummy was probably due to how much I had to rely on Google and Game Wiki's to get quests done or to get through situations or puzzles. Too often it felt like the game hadnt given me enough clues or any at all to progress through some situations, and that can be completely on me most the time for being thick in the head, but I found more than a few times that it happened turned out to be something that I would never have discovered no matter how switched on I was. For example theres a moment you have to put a specific framed picture onto a plaque on the ground to unlock a hatch you wouldnt even know was there to continue the story and there was no way of guessing you had to do that and the only clue it gave was so vague that I wouldnt have put 2 and 2 together in a million years. Moments like that made the game as frustrating as it was enjoyable.  Theres something about Pillars of Eternity's flow through the locations and storyline that was just so much more peacful, Immersive and enjoyable for me compared to Divinity 2, but when I compare these games together PoE only just comes out on top against Divinity for the reasons I mentioned above.  I recommend this game, but I must say, before you start, book a week off school or work and turn your phone off, because its all you're going to do until you finish it.

The game itself is great and a true continuation and development of all that was loved and praised about the first Original Sin; however, and it's a big however, the engine is buggy as hell.  There's an odd core usage issue which means that multi core cpus are not utilized and the game dumps everything onto a single core - notice the strange frame skip stutter when panning?  That's a core usage issue and nothing else.  It seems the devs either don't care to fix the issue or can't fix the issue, which means one has to set the processor affinity to a single core and then back to all cores in task manager every single time one plays the game.  Not cool.  So if they sort that out, it's a highly recommended game; if not, it's still recommended but be prepared to tune your system every playthrough.  Oh yes, also there are issues with overclocked CPUs and GPUs.  Come on Larian, get your technical issues as sorted out as you've gotten the combat in this game.

After beating the game on classic difficulty.  Pros: Fun tactical combat Largely voiced, either by the narrator or the NPCs. Good story and writing in general Smart enemy AI Animations satisfying to watch Sounds are well done Good music. Not as good as Nier: Automata. But still fairly good. A long game. First run took me ~130 hours, looking through every nook and cranny I could find, reading everything, using no walkthroughs. Tons of replayability. Many different choices, several different races and origin stories with different perspectives. Multiplayer (which I haven't touched yet) Mod support (which I haven't touched yet) Tons of flexibility as far as what your character can become. Many side quests which are well done, Several of which span across acts. Clearly defined "Point of no return" points.  Cons: Doesn't hold your hand as much as other games. (Which I personally like, but some people might not.) Balance issues between the classes (Debateable) Noticeable drop in quality in the final act. MIssing voiceovers. One notorious and buggy enemy encounter where weak enemies keep respawning, potentially for hours, with no xp gain. Quests more screwy. One NPC talked to a party member calling them someone else who has never been in the party. Needs patching. (My main complaint) The crafting system largely expects you to experiment. No materials are lost upon a failed combination. But I'm not going to bash things together all day until something works. At the end of the game I was still mostly unsure if most of the stuff I collected had any use. There are anvils and blacksmithing tools, but crafting armor/weapons/food dishes never seemed worth it and were a waste of space. Etc. Inventory system needs to be more user friendly. Like selecting multiple things at once. Or a search function. The storage box needs to be broken down into categories just like your inventory is.  Overall, tons of bang for your buck, which is what I'm all about. 9/10. Would be 10/10 if it wasn't for the issues in the final act.

Early Access Review:   Original Sin 2 is what exactly what every RPG gamer has been looking for - there's a potency to its' immersion that every EA title should aim to hit. This is the caliber of gaming you (EA devs) should truly attempt to employ!!!! It's an absolute masterpiece of Early Access gaming. A true game of D&D mixed with chess.......Larian said they posted this game on steam with a laugh, and I know why!! Ok I'll stop with the hype and explain.   (Graphics, optimization, controls, gameplay, sound.)   Graphics/Animations: 10/10  Right from the jump you notice how polished the world and characters look. From beautiful landscapes to fluid animations, I love it!!!! Nothing left to say here! Excellent job!   Optimization: 10/10  No loading screens.. LIKE EVER during your gaming experience! Excellent work!   Controls: 9/10  No complaints other than the restriction of your camera angles. Part of the experience is viewing a gorgeous and artistic world... You can never look at the sky....and view your character from better angles.. sad. Although, you can rebind your keys, you can rotate and zoom in - You feel like you're in control. Great job!   Gameplay: 9.5/10  This is where the bulk of the game lies. From story to combat - the immersion starts with the world appearance and story narrative, then ends with a blast with its' combat delivery. The combat is spaced out making you feel like you're not always in a chat box, and you'll be satisfied in casting, buffing or even simple melee attacks.  You can be whatever you want to be. Unless you want to be an orc...you can't be an orc - BUT what you can do from what they have to offer makes you feel like you're totally in control of your character's person.   Yes, customization is quite limited. I like my rpgs to let me customize my character to the "T" ... and this does limit you in that aspect to a certain extent...better than most games but coming from MMOs you may be disappointed. Given a more customizable character and maybe even adding a few other races .. you'll never play the same character again. Character creation is key in this type of genre - still ... Excellent work!   Music/Sound: 9.5/10  The sound and music is fantastic! ... I'd still love to hear a larger variety of music during gameplay...This will probably end up being a 10 simply because they will add voice acting and more music throughout the future acts. Excellent job!   Overall: 10/10  The story, the adventure, the combat, the scenery, the ..... oh you get it already!!!! What a phenomonal game. RPG lovers, MMO lovers...hack'n'slash lovers... VIDEO GAME LOVERS! You'll love this. I wouldn't post my first review on steam if I didn't believe this to be a game for everyone on steam. Do enjoy! Thanks Larian!

One of the best games I have ever played.  Several bugs and lack of features make it fall just short of that #1 however.  My main concerns are in multiplayer. You have to play as the hosts party characters and not your own. That means playing an archer with a level 2 bow, all stats in wits and other useless talents. There is also an endless amount of bugs with multiplayer. For example, if I am host and start a multiplayer and someone joins me as say The Red Prince and I save, restart whatever, that character then becomes bugged. Instead of reverting back to The Red Prince after that player leaves, he bears that persons name and is unable to be reset, or even dismissed. You normally can talk to npc's in your party and say you want to go your seperate ways and recruit another party member, nope. bugged.  Another example is I use one of my npc's for dialect options since they have persuasion stats and my main is undead. Someone joined the game and took control of MY character and when I leveled up he butchered his stats and skills and those remained on my character after I kicked him and / or restarted the game.  These things make multiplayer extremely frustrating and have forced me to start brand new games probably about 6 times now. I haven't even been able to get through act 1. I am very wary to play in multiplayer due to all these reasons and despite preferring multiplayer in it's theory am forced to play single player to avoid game breaking bugs like those i mentioned. I wish I could provide some feedback or get some kind of bug fix on this bug I don't see an option for that. Thankfully the developer is very involved in the game and will probably fix this at some point. I am now hoping that a user created mod will fix many of these issues in the future (thank god this game has mods)  Despite all my frustrations this game is absolutely incredible in every other aspect. Everything is voiced, every npc which is amazing. Graphics are good (not great) especially for this type of game. Quests are actually fun and not all fetch they actually have lore. There is an absolute freedom: you can kill every npc and still proceed with the game. The gameplay is some of the best ever. This genre has been ruined in the past decade with games like the Final Fantasy series dropping the traditional turn-based combat for an active combat. Yeah, thats nice in some circumstances but it is extremely boring hacking and slashing repetitively just like every other game. The combat in D:OS2 is calculated, and detailed. Everything is listed and heavily focused on strategy and statuses. The game encourages using environments such as high ground and environmentals like barrels and puddles in order to gain favor in battle.   The best part of the game is the fact it's challenging. The default difficulty will probably be too hard for average gamers and those not familiar with the genre or the first game. There are two higher difficulties on top of that which are extremely challenging (I normally play on the highest difficulty in every other game) The next best thing would be that the developers aren't EA, Ubisoft, Activision, etc and force paywalls on an incomplete game and don't support the game after launch. This dev actually cares and I have personally downloaded atleast one patch per day and they have already stated that they are going to implement being able to use your own character in multiplayer which is something I look forward to. Can't wait to see what's next for this game.

Words cannot fully describe how wonderful the game is. After 106 hours I have finally finished it on tactician difficulty - the second highest out of 4 difficulty levels - and it's been one hell of a ride. In the pool of games that have filled the cRPG genre over time some are remembered for the gems that they are. This game truly deserves a place among those stars.    Short and quick: The best aspects The combat offers a huge variety of possibilites. 200+ spells allow you to build your character exactly to your liking. They aren't all magical, they don't all scale with intelligence like you'd expect from classical RPGs meaning you can mix a lot of combinations on your character. Don't think of spells as a 'magician only' thing. Every character will use a wide variety and it feels amazing to have this much choice in battle.  The AI will use insane combinations and synergies of spells just as much as you do. They will sacrifice their own if it gives them an advantage, they will use the environment against you.   No ridiculous RNG: Although dicerolls aren't completely banished out of the game these mechanics never feel unfair like in some other RPGs. Games based on pen & paper tend to use a lot of dicerolls but here you'll find that most mechanics have been modified to be very clear about how they work without relying on RNG. Doesn't mean critical attacks aren't possible if you want to play that way ;-)  There are no classes. Don't get mistaken by the character creation, it's only meant to be a help for the early game. You level and can spent your points on the different schools of sorcery. You're never restricted because of a 'class' and after leaving the first area you can fully respecc at any time. You can truly built your character the way you want to.  The worldbuilding is amazing. There is so much to explore, so many NPCs to talk to and stories to experience.  The characters - from simple animals to essential NPCs - are just as amazingly written as the world. Some you'll love, some you'll laugh about, some you'll hate, but never will you think they are acting out of character.   The choice is always yours. One moment you're a saint, next moment you decide an NPC isn't worth keeping alive. Although sometimes limited, there are always consequences.   To further strengthen the last point: You can play the game anyway you want and never hit a roadblock in the story. Even if you murder every NPC you see you'll be able to finish the story.   Play the entire campaign with up to 4 players. 'nuff said  The voiceacting is phenomenal. Everything in this game is voiced, including the narrator. Not only that, but the variety in voices is so large you will rarely - if ever - notice two voices sounding alike. Every unimportant guard, every NPC without a name, every animal in the wild, every character - no matter how essential they are to the story - sounds different and they manage to bring the emotions their words carry to life.  The soundtrack manages to describe the atmosphere in a wonderful way.   Although the story is rather serious, the little sprinkles of humor every now and then shine brightly.  Short and quick: The worst aspects The companions sidequests are wonderful and they influence the main story quite a lot. But everywhere else they're a little pale as they rarely voice their oppinion on what you do during the rest of the journey.   This game can easily overwhelm you. If you're familiar with the cRPG gerne you'd expect this but everyone else be warned: This is not a game you finish in a couple of hours nor is it a linear game. Having a huge freedom means your questlog will burst at times.  The difficulty is real. Even on classic - the normal mode - you'll get your‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•handed to you on a silver plater. I finished the game in 106 hours on tactician - one difficulty above classic - and my save game told me I was 'alive' for 80 hours. That means I had 26 hours of reloading because of party wipes or decisions that I regreted. I thoroughly enjoyed the difficulty but be warned: It's not to be taken lightly.   A slight negative about undeads: If you play one or have one in your party you can chose to hide your undeadness and the story will acknowledge this but the combat won't. I assume it's done for the sake of difficulty and interesting gameplay, but enemies will always know that you're an undead and chose tactics that work against undeads like e.g. hurting you with healing magic.  After all is said, it's still a cRPG. There's a lot to read, a lot of sidequests to do and a lot of possibilites in how you tailor the story around you. Don't go into this game with wrong expectations. It's huge. Having wrong expectations can easily ruin the experience for you.  You might wonder even with all the high praise you've heard about this game how it compares to the best of the cRPG genre. It's not simple to answer this as classics like Baldur's Gate can be hard to enjoy these days. Some of the most defining games of this genre came out in the late 90's to early 00's after all. Divinity: Original Sin 2 takes the things that made those classics wonderful and wraps them into a modern engine. It learned from all the mistakes that happened with the first 'Original Sin' game and improved greatly on them. So in summary, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. For me it's not only the RPG of the year, it's a strong contender for game of the year.

I played part the Divinity Original Sin Enhanced Edition and enjoyed that, so I decided to get DOS 2 after I saw it on sale for a modest 10% (also because my friends had the game and I wanted to play with them).   As it turns out, this game is such an improvement on the first game that I just cant go back to DOSEE. Divinity: Original Sin 2 is an amazing game that quite literally builds on every positive element of the Enhanced Edition and makes the game so much smoother and comprehensive.   YOU CAN NOW ACCESS ALL INVENTORIES OF YOUR PARTY MEMBERS IN ONE WINDOW. PRAISE LARIAN STUDIOS. Improvements were also made to many mechanics such as: Crafting, purchasing/bartering, targeting AOE spells.  The storyline is also so much more rich now that you have 5 preset characters to choose from (and the option to create your own). Right off the bat, I was much more engaged in DOS2's story than I ever was in the EE. I love their banter. I love that ALL party members can engage in dialogue, thus giving you multiple opportunities to get the "right" answers without needing to reload the game. The voice acting is great and the characters have personalities true to their plights.   If you enjoy story-rich games, this one's for you! (If the turn-based combat system deters you, there is the option to play the game in Explorer Mode to make the combat easier and thus a secondary feature).  TL;DR: This game is lots of fun! Kudos to a development team that listens to its community in order to improve on previous iterations of its game(s)!

THE STORY: This is by far the most densely rich lore I‚Äôve played through from any game I‚Äôve played, where almost everyone and everything is connected in one way or another. Creating a living and breathing world, where one‚Äôs actions and decisions will affect their adventures through Rivellon. The part where this game shines the most, is how it gives the player choices on how they want to advance the story in any way the player chooses to play. Choose to be good, evil, just or whatever mood you choose, this game adapts to it and guides you to the end that your choices led to. While I‚Äôve only completed Fane‚Äôs Story (in the moment of writing this), the endings it gives you will satisfy however you played. While you can choose how your adventure ends, the game lets you know how those actions will affect Rivellon in the future. The reason why I love this story is how grim and real this story plays out, no one is truly good or evil, it‚Äôs all a grey area, but it‚Äôs your choice on how you want to navigate in it.  THE COMBAT: There was never a dull moment every time I went into battle, or stumble on to one. While combat is turn-based, pre-battle is when things become interesting. Some approaches I found to be more fun is laying out traps and pre-emptive attacks on unknowing enemies. I can go into combat with my enemies clinging on 5% health and wipe them out with one attack. This is true liberty that this game gives to players, it gives you the tools and it‚Äôs up to you on how to use them. And this is just combat, skills can give a creative twist to combat. You can chain attacks to deliver devastating blows to your enemies or toy around with them by unleashing various Statues Effects and skills that can either immobilize them or transform them into chickens. All this creates a simple yet complex toy box you can play with. Finding out what seems fun and effective will make you want to seek out the next battle and unleash your battle plan.  THE MUSIC: I do not, in any way, have any complaints or criticisms about the music. The only thing I can say is that it is Divine. The music makes Rivellon and in turn makes you believe that it is a real place and these characters who live in it are part of a giant play. The 4 instruments that you can pick (while you build your character) creates the mood in how you want to play and you can change it any time you want.  This is the best RPG for this generation. While there are quite a few bugs the developer needs to fix, this doesn‚Äôt affect how much I love this game.

I'm going to be honest here; I didn't like the first Original Sin.  I found the combat surprisingly clunky, the "two protagonist" playstyle akin to mashing action figures together as a child and the NPCs bland and empty.  Just everything about it wasn't as good as the raving crowds claimed.    This?  This is amazing.  This is so far one of my favorite PC RPGs I've ever played...and I'm old enough to remember the original Ultima and Gold Box DnD games.  Most areas and quests have multiple solutions and you're not really punished for taking one over the other.  There are a few areas where lockpicking is basically required but besides that stealth, conversation or brute force are typically viable options to dealing with a problem.  Combat feels tactical (something most RPGs frankly don't really do anymore) with your choices in positioning, abilities and terrain manipulation meaning the difference between victory or defeat more often than just pure stats.  With careful planning you can beat groups of enemies better geared and higher levels than you, though it's still unlikely as one lucky crit can one shot a character.  There are very few mindless "throw away" battles once you leave the tutorial island.  Almost every encounter will be an actual fight for your life.  There are some areas the game can be improved further.  While your companions will pipe up more and put more of their character on display than the original, it's not quite enough.  The process in which it happens is sterile and lacks organic interaction.   Instead of the NPCs talking as if the other NPCs were standing around them, they spout their one line and that's it.  If, say, the Red Prince spoke to Fane or Sebille during the journey it would go a long way to viewing them as characters instead of interchangable henchmen that happened to have a  bit of backstory or a sidequest attached. So yes, as much as people like to‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•on Bioware...this could benefit by being more like Bioware in that regard.  Another complaint is I never feel like I'm at the point I'm supposed to be at with gear.  I consistantly feel like I'm a few levels behind with my armor and health offering a totally negligable amount of protection with some enemies wiping my party before I even get a turn.  I don't even know how the game can really "fix" this other than perhaps tossing in an NPC somewhere explaining that each level gives shops DRAMATICALLY better gear and the difference between level 10 and level 12 is roughly 150% increase in defense.   Oh and do ignore the publications out there that act like plaiyng Undead is sooo hard.  You literally NEVER have a reason to not be in full armor and you can easily heal from poison damage and poison potions.  It's really not a challenge at all.  Edit and Addtions:  I had originally complained at some poor coding regarding playing a non-origin character and how playing an undead PC made the game think you were Fane leading to some broken quests and ridiculous immersion breaking dialogue.  It seems since launch most of these issues have been patched and some major story moments have been reworked.  It's disappointing they were in the game at all as I can't fathom why anyone would WANT to play as an "origin" companion instead of a real character and why playing a real character would end up being so buggy but...that's just me.

I'm the type of person that will flat out stop playing a game if the story fails to engage me. With Divinity 2, the Story was interesting and I felt like there was a lot to be said for being able to approach the game as a character I design vs. one of the compelling Origin characters.  Origin Characters/Companions. Not every companion/Origin is created equal; yes, some companions generally are better than others. Some may have a personality that some individuals find intolerable. But. Unlike many games, your companions classes are completely customizable. You aren't stuck leaving behind a person you enjoy having in your party because their ability tree is junk. That feature alone, is worthy of praise.   Crafting: Most games I play have stupid crafting systems. Divinity 2 is no exception, but you can ignore it for the most part, except in the case of creating a few quest items. It is not the worst system, but neither do I find it particularly enjoyable. It's there if you want it, but don't expect to craft some badass weapons without dling a bunch of mods.  The story itself, in my opinion, is superior to it's predecessor. The Lore felt accessible, rather than confusing and off-putting. The romance system seemed rather nice. Keeping in mind that I've only followed the paths of Ifan, Lohse, and Sebille, I can certify that those three were all satisfying, but in very different ways. I've read that the other ones leave something to be desired, but I can say that the romance doesn't make me want to roll my eyes nor experience disappointment,   The turn-based combat enables an individual to strategize and play to the strengths of their charactersl  I could write more, but I will say that I put off purchasing this game for a year because Divinity Original Sin 1 was okay, maybe even good, but it wasn't memorable to me. Divinity Original Sin 2 broke free of that mould of mediocrity and left an impression with me that has firmly snared a memorable top five games that I've played in my life.   Take from this what you will!

Well lets start off with a brief description of the game. You're a captive on a ship, a Sourceror, one of the most hated people across the land. Your foul magic attracts monstrosities known as the Voidwoken, nightmares from another dimension that seek to claim this world as their own. However, things quickly roll out of hand, and it ends with the ships destruction. Finding yourself on the prison island known as Fort Joy, you discover that you're no ordinary Sourceror; you have the potential to become a GOD. From there, the game plays out quite literally as YOU choose it, be it as a benevolent hero seeking to save the world or as a malicious villain who seeks to gain ultimate power. And, just maybe, you'll find an option that no one else expected, one that takes you through the Void itself... and finding power that scoffs at the Gods themselves.  As you can probably tell, there's a lot of choices to be made in Divinity 2 : Original Sin, and maybe you're thinking "Oh god, it's another one of these games that plays out as a visual novel instead of a rpg". Well if you are thinking that, shut the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up, strap in, and read up ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• because there's quite a bit more to the game than that.   Now, the best part about this game is it's combat system and character progression; there are few other games where I can actually feel the progression of my character and the impact it has on the world around me. For example, in my very first TRUE playthrough of the game, 100% it, I did it with just two characters, both of them basically assassins; it was hard at first of course, but by the end of the game I could clear a room of 12 heavily armored characters with 2 characters and taking no damage. It truly felt powerful, and is one of my favorite gaming playthroughs of all time. So I thought, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• it, lets try a magical playthrough, might not be as fun as the first, but we'll get through it. Well. Lets just say a full elementalist party is quite a unique experience. The whole 4 person party felt powerful the entire game, and we destroyed everything in sight that we deemed "Unholy" or "Unclean". Felt ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing hilarious the entire way through, and I don't regret a moment of it. For my thrid play through, I went in with a full melee team, and got the exact same results, which has blown me out of the water and clear into the sky; the fact that no matter what kind of team you play you know you'll become a force to be reckoned with is fantastic, and lets you cook up some pretty kooky team compilations. If you don't believe me, go on youtube and look up some of the SOLO builds people can make; they play on the highest difficulty and can quite literally nuke entire areas with a single character. But I digress, that's a bit off topic, and not relevant to this review. So if you've ever felt let down by a characters power or capability, trust me, you won't feel that with this game.  Let's talk diversity for a quick second here. There are 4 main races in the world, the Dwarves, Humans, Elves, and Lizards. Each race has its own unique capabilities, and it's own racial traits, meaning that yes, while you can have a Lizard assassin, making it a human so it have bonus initiative (how soon it gets to move in combat) and extra critical chance (random extra damage) means you'll have an easier time. Or maybe you'll choose a lizard for your geomancer because you have the innate ability to breath fire, and ignite your oil based abilities. A dwarven Inquisitor stands ready to rush into your opponents because they have extra defenses against all forms of damage. And maybe your necromancer is an elf because elves can eat parts of their enemies to learn memories and skills they'd normally never obtain. No matter what it is, you'll find tons of combinations based off of race alone to make a unique and fun character. But is that where it stops? Nope, that's where we're just getting started. See, there is a unique twist you can put on a character; you can make them UNDEAD. Yes, that's right, a skeleton that walks and talks, and which offers other unique pros and cons. For example, an undead character will heal when poisoned, and take damage when healed normally. Skeletons can use their bony fingers as infinite use lockpicks. And most importantly, Skeletons don't have any nasty organs to inhale Deathfog, an uncommon terrain in the game which kills anything that breaths it, meaning that Undead are free to wander through it as they please. The only real downside is having to wear a headpiece at all times. (Which isn't even a downside, like, why would you decide to not wear an important piece of equipment?) But lets say you dislike making all of that troublsome character stuff, you just want to get in and have fun. Well, there are already a ton of premade characters with their own stories and quests to go on if you so choose! There's literally no way to go wrong with making a character in this game!  Hey, we almost missed the most important part of the game, the part where you become a god and stuff! Well friendo, that's what I saved for last because that‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•is called SPOILERS, and I know that some people dislike those. So let it be said now that if you don't want to read any spoilers WHATSOEVER, then you should skip the next paragraph. Cool? Cool.  So as your character progresses through the game, they will discover the ability to use Source to fuel abilities. These are their godly powers, and are only usable by player characters and certain other npcs. This includes the abilites; Bless : Buffs an ally and clears any and all curses that afflict them. Spirit Vision : Is actually free to cast, and lets you temporarily see into the spirit realm, where you can see parts of the past, and even talk with the dead to gain their wisdom. (Or even just to taunt an enemy who bugged you.) Devour : Not it's actual name, but I don't use it often enough to remember it. It's also free to cast. You basically target an enemy corpse (or even just directly target their ghost.) and devour their essence, regaining a source point. Doing this too many times however can mark you with the "Villain" tag, which is not what you want to have on you if you're roleplaying as a benevolent hero. Gate : Again, isn't the true spell name, but works the same as the D&D version, creating a permanent link to another location within range that anyone can go through at any time. It sounds kind of dumb at first, but it lets you pull off some pretty wacky stunts in the game, and I've taken it on every character I've made so far. There are of course tons of other abilities that can be fueled by source points, far too many to list them all here, as each class has a few "Ultimate" abilities that you need source to use. But if you're interested in learning more about these godlike powers, then just look up a class guide and check out their abilities to get an idea of what you can work with!  Alright, well I think that if you've read everything I've said so far, that you'll get the idea I'm trying to tell you. The game's fantastic, and fun to play, especially with friends. One of the best campaigns we had was one where the entire party split up and fought to become the ultimate character. So if you enjoy shennanigans like that, and you love the sound of this game, then take a go at it! I really think that you'll enjoy the hell out of it!

*NOMINATED FOR CRY HAVOC AWARD* You can break the game and do OP stuff if you feel like it.  Very long! Very complex! Very complicated! Fairly difficult! Full of variety! Good amount of (literal) replay value!  My friend and I have been going through Hard mode in co-op. Our game's reached the 100 hour mark now and we are at most 3/4 of the way through the game. By comparison, we've finished Original Sin 1 together in 90 hours!  Many changes since the first game, some welcome, some need to grow on you, but at the same time it doesn't feel like a different game. It's still Original Sin.  Certain issues exist, but they're mostly related to design philosophies. So far we've only encountered some minor cosmetic bugs. The type that get fixed when you do a simple reload.  Examples of replay value include:  -Vast increase in difficulty between normal and hard mode. -You can make crazy character builds on Easy and Normal, while focusing on a challenge in Hard. -Permadeath mode. -Playable Undead characters who heal from poison and get damaged by regular heals. -Lone Wolf talent that changes the way you play, makes you stronger but lowers your party size. -A fast and simple mod on the Workshop lets you increase the party size from 4 to 6 or 7. -Potentially even more mods.

1 hour in, and I already love this game.  You can tell they put a ton of effort into making every step a smooth experience. There is a ton of polish. And the world building is fantastic. I feel like I'm reading a LOTR series, except I get to take part in the events. There are kings and queens and emperors, and monsters and villains and heros and gods, and things going on over here and over there while I'm doing my thing.  Most current RPGs make it really hard for me to imagine myself as taking part in the story. For DOS2, it takes almost no effort. I really want to know what happened to my characters ancestors, and what my friend wants to do, and what their family is doing, etc. I can make decisions based on how I would react in each situation.  And on top of all of that, they have coop too! Like WTF, they don't know when to stop!  It really feels like a labor of love.
